version.description:
Remarkable compilation of clips from a huge variety of sources across Bruce's entire career. There is everything here from pro-shot footage, stage shot camcorder footage , TV chats show appearances, Awards shows, Benefit shows, political rally's, monument dedications and even a home wedding video !  
The quality varies as much as the content. Some of the earlier footage in particular comes from high generation sources and much of it is now available in better quality elsewhere. However, there are some real gems that you won't find on other DVDs. Highly recommended for the sheer thoroughness with which Bruce's career is covered.

The excellent audio is from the soundboard. Many of the songs are cut and there is no image at times. Transferred in XP mode from a SVHS source.  
This is one of the essentials.

version.description: Here we have the forty five minute edit of the Barcelona '02 show that was broadcast as a prime time TV Special on CBS in February 2003. The 2003 Grammy Awards appearance is included as filler. The source appears to be a VHS recording for both broadcasts. This DVD can be largely ignored, since both the Barcelona and Grammy performances are available in better quality elsewhere.

version.description:
The Charlotte 85 footage is pro-shot from single camera. The image is rather distant and grainy, but there is little evidence of generation loss. The audio is from a very good soundboard source. Some tracks are cut. It is entertaining stuff to watch, despite the fairly poor image quality. Highlights include the Nebraska set, especially "Johnny Bye Bye". 
Also included on the same disc is 8mm colour footage from St Paul  on 19 Feb 77, filmed from the balcony at the side of the stage. Both image and sound are rather distant. However, it is still interesting to watch, since footage from this era is so rare.

version.name: Bologna 02
version.description: Bruce followed up his live appearance on MTV/VH1 by treating an enthusiastic Italian crowd to one of the most interesting shows of the initial European leg of "The Rising" tour. Among the non-standard songs in the set list were "Something in the Night", "You Can Look" and a solo piano "For You". The first encore opened with the tour debut of "Stand on It" and Elliot Murphy made a guest appearance for "Born to Run". FedeUd has made an admirable effort to pull together four different video sources of the show. Two of these are shot from the right side of the arena, the other two from the left. The majority of the footage is stage shot, but there are also several looks at the giant screen included in the mix. The four-camera coverage provides tremendous potential, but the resulting mix is let down by the quality of the sources. All of the views are a little unsteady and none of them provide many real close-ups. Worse yet, the two left-side videos have been taken from VCDs and the image quality suffers badly from the high compression and low resolution of that format. The other two sources are much better, but still lack the sharpness of the best videos from the tour. The problems with the image quality are compounded by hit and miss synchronisation with the dubbed audio (unfortunately, more miss than hit). On the plus side, there are some high production values to be found here. The DVDs feature excellently designed menus, a nice photomontage intro and even a credit sequence. FedeUD has obviously put a great deal of effort into this one, but the poor image quality and synchronisation issues make it a hard-going viewing experience at times.

This b&w footage was shot for the closed-circuit TV screens in the theatre. The image is grainy and has poor contrast. There are also bands of interference running across the screen at times. This is the complete show, with audio dubbed from CC's Passaic Night soundboard recording. 
Despite the relatively poor image quality, this is arguably Bruce's greatest ever show and so this DVD is essential viewing.

version.name: Passaic Restored

songlist: Darkness on the Edge of Town

version.description: If ever there were a "worthy" candidate for an upgrade, this title was it. A fantastic performance by Bruce, but originally in less than stellar quality. And for years, that was the case. Not any more.  Miles Hai took it upon himself to attempt a serious upgrade to the picture quality of this historic footage. Using the "Passic Night" DVDs as source material he got to work. According to his information logs at the time of this set release, he 'painstakingly restored each camera angle shot individually, then peiced the whole thing back together'. Unhappy with the orginial audio, he also dubbed it with the superior sounding "Piece De Resistance" boot CD (to a fantastic effect). All told, the upgrade turn outto be a great success (you can compare the screenshots here to the previous version and see for yourself). It is not a pefect release however, as there are audio sync issues sprinkled here and then (difficult to sync audio with video that is garbled), in particular, on the final song of Disc 2 (Raise Your Hand)it is very noticable. The video is still flawed, but that is due to its source and not the upgrade. And even though the picture is greatly improved, it is difficult to make out detail or definition. Final word? This is the version to get. Its the best out there so far.

version.name: Cincinnati Lights Remixed

songlist: Darkness on the Edge of Town
Does This Bus Stop at 82nd Street?

version.description:
Brought to us by ScratchMonkey and the CTC, this set was held in the hands of the “ubers” until late 2006 when it was “leaked” to the wider community as part of TattooDad’s efforts. 
This DVD is the same as the original release with two differences. Unlike the original production, the remixed edition does not contain bonus material of the Letterman and Conan 2002 TV appearances. But more importantly, it has also been perfectly dubbed from an excellent IEM source. It is a superbly authored DVD, almost professional in appearance, with introduction sequences and menus with audio. Two cameras are mixed together, one primarily filming the stage, the other focusing on the big screen. The camera filming the screen is used most often.  
When the original production was released in 2003 it was a defining moment- it was one of the first, if not the first, multi-cam DVD for Bruce fans. Amazing progress has been made since then but this is the granddaddy of audience shot DVDs, the “Citizen Kane” if you like, and for that reason alone it deserves a place in any collection, particularly now it is available with awesome audio.

version.name: Jacksonville '03

songlist: Let's Go, Let's Go, Let's Go

version.description: Bruce was really starting to mix up the set list on The Rising Tour by early 2003. The highlights in Jacksonville were "Better Days", "Tougher Than the Rest" and "Let's Go, Let's Go, Let's Go" (the latter as a tribute to Hank Ballard, who passed away the day before the show). This excellent footage from a single handheld DV camcorder was shot from the right side of the arena. For the most part, the image is exceptionally clear and reasonably steady. The filmer switches to the big screen for a few songs, but here the image is less clear and off-centre. Fortunately, the majority is stage shot. The camcorder audio is disappointingly distant, but still enjoyable. Overall, one of the best 2003 arena DVDs.

version.name: N/A
version.description:
Superb show.  First show of the tour without Patti.  Bruce is very much on his game in Providence.  "War" opens the show for only the second time, and several rarities make their first 2003 appearance -- "Night," "The Fuse," and "Spirit in the Night." "If I Should Fall Behind" takes the solo piano slot. 
 
The "local special" was a poignant one, as Springsteen and the E Street Band played one for the victims of The Station tragedy (on February 20, nearly 100 people died in a fire at the Rhode Island nightclub) -- "Bobby Jean" opened the encore, dedicated to those who died in the flames.
 
Spirit In The Night is a definite highlight.  Excellent crowd as well. Picture quality is almost perfect, at times, the camera is a little shaky due to minor obstructions, but not significantly so.

version.name: A Spirit in the Night

bonus: VH1 Special 'Terror in the Front Row'

version.description: "A Spirit in the Night" from ScrewDevil has been produced as a memorial to Matt, a fellow taper and friend of the filmers who was among the 99 people killed in the Rhode Island nightclub fire on 20 February 2003. Disc 1 starts with a montage of CNN news clips covering the tragedy. This fades into a scrolling dedication to Matt over the instrumental segment from "Your Missing". The Providence show itself (just 5 weeks after the fire) opens with a defiant rendition of "War". This isn't the only statement on the events unfolding in Iraq; an impassioned speech offers a full band "Born in the USA" as "a prayer for peace". Rarities making the set list include "Spirit in the Night" and a tender solo piano version of "If I Should Fall Behind". Bruce dedicates "Bobby Jean" (a song about lost friendship) to those that died in the flames. Patti was unable to make the show due to illness (Bruce jokes "she's sick, sick of me"), but she still gets an intro during "Mary's Place". This superb 2-cam mix uses the previously circulated stage-shot video from the right of the arena together with a new source from left centre. Picture quality from both cameras is uniformly excellent and a great audience tape has been used to dub the audio. The images are slightly unsteady at times, but the filmers do a good job of following the action on stage. One or both cameras occasionally switch to the screen, particularly when Bruce is at the piano. There is some use of black & white ("Night") and/or a low frame rate (e.g. "Countin on a Miracle") for special effect. "Into the Fire" is mixed with amateur footage of the nightclub fire for astonishingly moving results. Also included on the discs are a VH1 Special on the Rhode Island fire and similar events in rock history ("Terror in the Front Row") and more CNN clips covering the inquiry into the tragedy (including interviews with members of Great White and Kiss). This DVD collection is as a great record of a standout show and a fitting tribute to Matt. This is some of ScrewDevil's best work. A definite "must-have".

version.name: Blue Cross Boss

songlist: My Love Will Not Let You Down

version.description: By the time the "Rising" tour hit Rochester, Bruce was really starting to mix up the set list. This terrific show was full of surprises, with "No Surrender" as the opener, "Blinded By the Light" and "Nothing Man" in the main set and "Fire" by request in the encores. Patti Scialfa was out sick for the second night in a row (so Bruce smooches with her mike stand instead during "Mary's Place"). The superb "Blue Cross Boss" from Cheesesteak Productions takes the previously circulated video of the show as its source. The majority is stage shot, although it switches to the screen for "Empty Sky" and most of the final encore. The most striking thing about the footage is the location of the filmer. He/she is at the back of the arena and so is able to get a great head-on shot of the stage. The zoom is used for some good close-ups without any apparent loss of picture definition. In fact, the image is razor sharp with great colour balance. The show is nicely filmed from a tripod with steady pans to the appropriate band members during their solos. There is a regular stream of bodies passing across the field of view, but they appear as a brief flicker and are only a minor distraction. The audio, while not outstanding, is good enough to compliment the superb video. Most importantly, there are no synchronisation problems like those present on the previous dubbed version. Disc 2 starts with a nice slide show of still pictures of the city and the band over the intro to "Backstreets" (there is no image on the source video at this point). Hidden away as a Bonus Feature at the end of Disc 2 are four and a half minutes of multi-cam pro shot footage from the beginning of the show. We get the band's stage entrance, together with incomplete clips of "The Rising" and "Lonesome Day". This was presumably filmed for local TV news coverage and quality is close to perfect. The disc menus stay with the "Blue Cross" theme, with the Song Selection sub-menus cleverly mimicking a medical bill. Artwork isn't normally discussed here, but an exception is required in this case. The DVD cover design by Gchord is simply stunning. If you have the previous DVD from the show then this is definitely a worthwhile upgrade. If you don't, then this should be high on your "Wants" list.

version.name: Meltdown at the Ice Palace

songlist: Darkness on the Edge of Town
Does This Bus Stop at 82nd Street?
It's Hard to Be a Saint in the City

version.description: The Rising Tour's stop in Tampa brought a shake-up to the set-list, with the inclusion of nine song that were not performed the previous night in Miami. It was a show full of highlights for fans of the early material, including a pairing of tracks from the first album ("Does This Bus Stop..." and "...Saint in the City"), a solo piano "Incident..." and a raucous "Twist and Shout" as the closer. Excellent quality audio and video of the performance has been available for some time, but they had only circulated separately. That situation is now remedied with the superb "Meltdown at the Ice Palace" (a ScrewDevil Production of a Mad Raving Stark film). The video consists of the same two camera angles as previously seen, but ScrewDevil has gone back to the master tapes to create a brand new mix. The very start of the show was not filmed, so a photomontage accompanies the opening strains of "The Rising". Only one camera source is then used for the first half of the first set (excluding "The Ties That Bind", which is cut entirely). The view comes from just left of centre at the back of the arena and the picture quality is outstanding. Despite the need to use full zoom, the image is razor shape. There is a natural colour balance and solid black tones. The camera work is slightly unsteady at times, with a few brief obstructions and the occasional off-stage shot. For most of the time though, we get a great view of the band. Some portions are shot from the screen and it takes the filmer a few moments to centre the image when he makes the switch. Once settled, the quality of the screen shots is very good. The second video source kicks in during "World's Apart". This view is from high on the left side of the arena, just behind Bruce. The autofocus occasionally locks onto the lighting rig instead of the stage, but otherwise the picture quality is equally as good as the primary source. With two camera angles to choose from, some slick editing notches up the enjoyment factor even further. Even though the video quality is highly impressive, the real star is the phenomenal audio track. It comes from the 'jambo' remix of the IEM and audience recordings. The sound is bright, bold and dynamic, with an even mix and great separation. Another bonus is that the drop-outs which marred the "Prodigal Son" version have been virtually eliminated. The only negatives that could be found are the lack of crowd noise and some minor distortion on the lead vocal. The sound is a fantastic accomplishment for an amateur release. Sadly, both cameras missed most of "Incident on 57th Street". The original DVD substituted a clip of the song from earlier in the tour. Instead, ScrewDevil makes the wise decision to stick with the glorious Tampa audio, albeit with a blank screen until the last minute or so. It goes without saying that the DVD set comes complete with menus, song chapters and a title sequence. The combination of excellent video and superb audio puts "Meltdown at the Ice Palace" among the very best DVDs from the tour. It was well worth the wait. If you haven't done so already, go and seek out a copy now. Finally, the pedantic ones among you might like to note that show actually took place at "The St. Petersburg Times Forum" and not "The Ice Palace". The arena was renamed shortly before the concert took place.

version.description:
Filmed from a fairly unique angle, the 2nd level, slightly behind the stage, on Clarence's side.  Gorgeous picture quality, one of the best from the tour, unfortunately the audio is as bad as the video is good.  The people around the filmer were a little enthusiastic - you can hear them singing.  If you want a good laugh at how most of us probably sound at a show get this DVD.  Otherwise get the dubbed audio version which is in NTSC format.
  
The last arena show of the tour was a very strong show, with "The Promised Land" as an opener, the rare "My Love Will Not Let You Down" called as an audible, solo piano "Incident", and guest Allie Weinberg (Max's daughter) on keyboards during "Ramrod."  Hungry Heart which opened the first encore is missing from the DVD.

version.description: Rehearsal footage shot in a private studio prior to the river tour. Exact date is unknown. Filmed with a single camera from front of stage. Most of the footage is a wide angle shot so there is a lack of detail but there are closeups during most songs. There are a couple of songs that are cut and a couple of songs that have multiple takes. The multiple takes feature the band working on arrangements and offers a glimpse of the band polishing material. Also of interest is The Ties that Bind which features Bruce playing the lead on a 12-string Rickenbacker.   Phoenix 7-8-1978 promotional footage is included as bonus material. This footage includes the version of Rosalita that was used for the video but includes the band introductions. Promised Land was also on the original promo reel but appears to be missing on this particular tape

version.name: In the Heat of the Night

songlist: Waitin on a Sunny Day (start cut)
Santa Claus is Coming to Town

version.description: When The Rising Tour rolled into Charlotte, the town was in the midst of blizzard conditions. However, Bruce warmed the crowd with an electrifying performance. Highlights of the set list included "Backstreets", "Where the Bands Are" and a seasonal "Santa Claus is Coming to Town". The ironically titled "In the Heat of the Night" from SDonkey features a new transfer of the previously circulated video, direct from the masters. The footage is shot from high on the left side of the arena, level with the front of the stage. In several spots during the show, the filmer struggles to get a clear shot of Bruce between the audience members in front of him. When he does manage a good view, there are some excellent close-ups. The picture quality is generally very sharp, although there is a slight red shift in the colour balance. The audio has been expertly dubbed using a very good audience tape. The vocal stands out well and there is reasonable instrument separation. Also worthy of special mention is the title sequence. It uses a rotating cube of text effect, with video superimposed on the letters. Clever stuff. The side-on, partially obstructed view may be distracting for some viewers.  However, this is a quality production that deserves a place in your collection.

Saturday night at Giants Stadium caught quite a few folks off guard after what many felt was an average show two nights earlier.  Bruce raised the stakes and when the night was over had the crowd raising their hands in joy, gratitude, and disbelief.
 
Bruce and the band busted out of the gate with the ultra-rare "Janey, Don't You Lose Heart," and that was just the begining other highlights included "Trapped," "Roll of the Dice," "Because the Night," and the second appearance of "Pretty Flamingo" since 1978.

version.name: New Jersey Rising 30th August 2003
version.description: The ninth show of the ten night Rising Tour stand at Giants Stadium caught quite a few people off guard. Bruce raised the stakes and when the night was over had the crowd raising their hands in joy, gratitude, and disbelief. Bruce and the band opened with the ultra-rare "Janey, Don't You Lose Heart," and that was just the beginning. Other highlights (and there were many) included "Trapped," "Roll of the Dice," "Because the Night," and only the second appearance of "Pretty Flamingo" since 1978. Emmylou Harris joined Bruce for a poignant "Across the Border" and the Philadelphia-based band Marah helped out on "Raise Your Hand." DVD Dubbing Guy has used the previously circulated screen shot as his video source. The handheld camera footage is extremely unsteady in the early going, but it gradually settles down until the filmer eventually manages to hold a reasonably tight view. The clarity of the image is exceptional, with great definition and true colours. The dubbed audio comes from an excellent audience recording and is a huge improvement over earlier versions of this video. This is by far the best version of the screen shot, but many people will prefer ScrewDevils's 2 cam mix.

version.name: This One's for You Buddy
version.description: Stockholm was treated to one of the best European shows in 2002. A terrific "Gloria" was the clear highlight, but the two-song solo piano spot with "Incident" and "For You" (both by request) was also outstanding. A rare "Jackson Cage" was another notable inclusion in the set list. "This One's for You Buddy" from SmackDonkey uses the previously circulated video of the show. It is shot from high on the right side of the arena, almost level with the stage. The solo piano portions are shot from the screen. Despite using a tripod, it is a little shaky at times, particularly when the filmer pans between band members or tries to avoid obstructions. The picture is very sharp and clear, although a narrow line of interference rolls down the screen occasionally during the second half of the show. However, what really sets this one apart from the rest is the outstanding dubbed audio. The sound is exceptionally clear, with great instrument separation and dynamic range. It is so good that this audience tape could almost be mistaken for a soundboard recording. The combination of great set list and sound quality make this one a "must have".

version.name: N/A
version.description:
Night 10 at Giants Stadium closed out the stand in style, with a fantastic mix of the old and the new, greatest hits and greatest misses, all for an ecstatic Labor Day weekend crowd.  The sounds of "Cynthia" hit the New Jersey air just after 8:30pm to make her live performance debut, and it made this show a real "yeah, yeah, alright!!" for diehards. Other standouts: "Lucky Town", "Spirit in the Night", "Lost in the Flood", and for the second night in a row "Because the Night" sizzled like a fried egg on a hot Texas street. Um, and that was before the encores. "Kitty's Back" kicked those off, only to be topped by the "will-he-or-won't-he" (he will!) appearance of Tom Waits' "Jersey Girl" to close things out.
 
The DVD is 98% screen shot with excellent picture quality and dubed with an above average audio boot from the show.

Three songs are in black and white; Into the Fire, No Surrender & Glory Days.  The audio is dubbed with an above average audio boot.

The DVD has a very cool introduction with pictures from the parking lot before the show.  This is the DVD to get from this night.

version.name: Ludwigshafen '03
version.description: Ludwigshafen was the second stop on the European stadium leg of "The Rising" tour. After nine months on the road, Bruce was really starting to shake up the set list. The German crowd was treated to a solo acoustic "This Hard Land" to open the show. Other highlights included "Spirit in the Night" and a full-band "Racing in the Street". Digi-TOx has used the previously circulated screen shot camcorder video of the show as his source. The image is very clear and sharp. However, the view of the giant screen only occupies about two-thirds of the frame. The various people and objects that are visible around the edge of the screen can be very distracting, although this problem improves when darkness falls during the encores. The footage is also very unsteady at times and there are frequent obstructions. "Badlands" is particularly bad, consisting almost entirely of a shot of someone's rear end. The audio has been dubbed using a very good audience recording and this certainly helps to make the DVD more enjoyable. The authored menus are also well-designed. Ultimately, the clear picture and dubbed audio can't overcome the obstructed view and the distractions around the edge of the screen. A good show, but there are several "Rising" screen shots that are much better than this one.

version.name: Barcelona 2003

songlist: My Love Will Not Let You Down

version.description: "The Rising" tour's return to Barcelona also saw Patti's return to the band for her first show of 2003 European leg. A relatively standard set list did feature the tour premier of "Sherry Darling" in response to a request from the crowd. Other highlights included "Because the Night" and "Detroit Medley". This remarkable video of the show was shot from the stadium field, directly in front of the right-hand big screen. It is reasonably steady, given the conditions under which it was filmed. Understandably, it does get a little more shaky towards the end of the show as the filmer tires from holding the camera. The most striking thing about the footage is the quality of the image, it is as sharp and clear as you are ever likely to get from an amateur screen shot. The obstructions are inevitable, but they add to the overall "being there" feel. The audio is very good for a camcorder source and there is none of the usual sync problems because of the proximity of the camera to the stage. The DVD has been authored using the master tape by "brucevideos", resulting in a very enjoyable production.

version.description: The first Rising Tour show at Crystal Palace featured "Meeting Across The River"/"Jungleland", a storming "Darlington County" and "Seven Nights To Rock" settled into the encores. "Move Over Prince Charles" from July4th1985 uses the original 2 disc DVD as the video source. This great footage is a mixture of stage and screen. It is very steady (with the aid of a tripod) and the picture is very sharp. There are a few obstructions and the occasional loss of image all together, but overall the quality is impressive. The best available audience recording of the complete show has been used to replace the original camcorder audio. The sound has better dynamic range, but the vocal is a bit hollow. The songs have been chaptered and new menus have been added, resulting in a nice overall production. A further upgrade of this DVD ("Beyond the Palace") has now been released. See separate review.

version.name: Beyond the Palace

songlist: My Love Will Not Let You Down (CC)

version.description: The first Rising Tour show at Crystal Palace featured "Meeting Across The River/Jungleland"™ and a storming "Darlington County". "Seven Nights To Rock" settled into the encores. "Beyond the Palace" from July4th1985 uses the original 2 disc DVD as the video source. This great DV camcorder footage is a mixture of stage and screen. It is very steady (with the aid of a tripod) and the picture is very sharp. There are a few obstructions and the occasional loss of image all together, but overall the quality is impressive. The dubbed audience recording used on the earlier "Move Over Prince Charles" (also from July4th1985) has been enhanced by substituting nine of the songs with the excellent quality bonus tracks from Crystal Cat's "Night After Night" CD. The tracks featuring the Crystal Cat audio are indicated by "(CC)" on the setlist. The audio levels of the remaining songs have been boosted to minimise the difference between the two sources. The new menus are backed by a sample of the line from "Born to Run" that inspired the title of the DVD. Some people may prefer the consistent sound throughout the whole show that can be found on "Move Over Prince Charles". However, the improvement on the songs that use the Crystal Cat audio is considerable and so this DVD represents a nice upgrade. It is the best version we are going to get, unless the whole show ever emerges in CC quality.

version.name: N/A

version.description:
Probably the shortest show on the European leg, and a basic setlist .  No Menus, No Chapters..You can't even skip through  the DVD...Its one long track. 
 The video is fine, slightly out of sync audio but nothing major. Average compared to some of the better 2002/3 DVDs.   Shot at the screen the entire show.  Some great screen shots, but shaky at times.

version.description: Audio on this version blows the other one away.  Video is the same, but the audio itself makes this one much more enjoyable.  DVD is authored(which also helps, considering the original is one LONG track).

version.name: Gelsenkirchen
version.summary: Golden Toad Records W/ DVD Dubbing Guy

songlist: Darkness on the Edge of Town

version.description: Awesome DVD, the picture quality is stunning and crystal clear.  The Video is absolutely steady and centered to fill out the whole screen.  The audio used to dub the DVD is a great sounding mix from two recordings of the show.  This is the DVD to get of this show.

version.name: Largo '78
version.summary: Two disc version with no extras

songlist: Darkness On The Edge Of Town

version.description: This pro shot footage taken from the closed-circuit TV feed at the Capitol Centre, Landover (not Largo) on 15 August 1978 is probably the best known unofficial Springsteen video. The source tape for this colour footage is a couple of generations away from the master. As a result, the image is a little dark and murky. There are bands of interference running across the screen at times, but very little image noise. The soundboard audio is very good. This transfer to DVD (one of several in circulation) is across two discs with no extras. It is slightly inferior to the three disc XP version (which uses the same source tape).

version.name: N/A

songlist: Darkness on the Edge of Town

version.description: Upgraded version from the 2-disc versions

version.name: N/A

songlist: Darkness on the Edge of Town

version.description: Improvement on the original 2 disc version, but now superceded.

version.name: Largo '78

songlist: Darkness on the Edge of Town

version.description: This version of the famous pro-shot Landover 78 video from "HOJO Productions" uses the original 3 DVD XP transfer as its source. However, a couple of small improvements have been made. The cut during "Jungleland" has been tidied up and the first half of "Backstreets" no longer repeats at the end of Disc 2 as well as the beginning of Disc 3. Finally, new menus have been added.

version.name: Live on the Darkness on the Edge of Town

songlist: Darkness on the Edge of Town

bonus: I Don't Want To Go Home (Cleveland 78)

version.description: "Live on the Darkness on the Edge of Town" from the Watchdog label features a newly unearthed source tape of the famous "Largo 78" pro-shot footage. This ~2nd generation copy is a major improvement in picture quality when compared to the previously circulated 3rd/4th generation versions. The washed out colours are replaced by more vivid tones and the rolling lines of interference are (mostly) absent. Whilst undeniably a great upgrade, this is still not the "Holy Grail" that some had hoped for. "Jungleland" is still cut and the tantalising clips from the show in documentaries such as "Glory Days" demonstrate that there is still plenty of room for further improvement. The bitrate is also rather low (the show is squeezed onto one and a half discs) and so an XP transfer of the same tape would probably be slightly better. The DVD also includes some truly fantastic extras. The Phoenix '78 footage will be familiar to most collectors and here it is presented from no less than four different source. The best of these (#1) appears to be from an original CBS promo tape with a razor-sharp image, but unfortunately a time stamp is superimposed on the bottom of the frame. The other sources are similar to what we've seen before, except for "Promised Land" which is in poor quality. Finally, the pro shot footage of Bruce's guest spot with Southside Johnny at the Agora Club, Cleveland in 1978 is also drawn from a stunningly good new source. The set is wrapped together with some fairly average menu designs. This currently represents the best version of this classic show.

capture.caption: Darkness on the Edge of Town

version.name: Landover, MD 1978

songlist: Darkness On The Edge of Town

version.description: A top-quality version of the infamous closed-circuit pro-shot footage from Landover (aka Largo) '78 is truly the Holy Grail of Bruce DVD collecting. We know how potentially great the quality can be from the brief clips seen in TV documentaries such as the BBC's "Glory Days". Whilst there has been a multitude of different versions circulated over the years, nothing has reached that ultimate goal. This latest DVD from "jerseyboy" is yet another contender for the crown of "best yet". The source tapes used here were apparently obtained from the late, great DJ and long-time Bruce-supporter Ed Sciaky. They are VHS dubs taken directly from the proprietary format "U-matic" masters, making the first time a 1st generation copy has emerged. The three tapes have each been transferred to separate discs in this triple set. It is immediately apparent that this represents an improvement on what has gone before. The colours are deeper, the blacks more solid and the definition sharper. Unfortunately, there are also some negative aspects. Small white lines flash in the image continuously, although it is unclear whether these are present on the source tapes or have been introduced during the transfer. The image is also considerably darker than earlier versions. There is also a noticeable dip in quality on the third disc. On balance though, the improvements outweigh these distractions and the net result is arguably the best version currently available. The discs are authored with a simple main menu, but no song selection sub menus. There are also a few brief spots of video interference on the source tapes that have been replaced by still images while the excellent audio continues interrupted. Disc 3 is padded out with some unrelated extras. These consist of a poor quality b&w tape of "Quarter to Three" from Passaic '77, a documentary on South Side Johnny that includes clips of Bruce (as previously seen on the "This is Your Life" collection) and four takes of the embarrassingly bad "Dancing in the Dark" promo video tests. It looks like the quest for the Bruce DVD collecting Holy Grail will have to continue, but jerseyboy's contribution does an excellent job of tiding us over while we wait.

capture.caption: Darkness On The Edge of Town

version.name: The Complete TV Appearances 1978-2003
version.description: Compilation of virtually all Bruce's US TV appearances between '78 and '03. Quality is consistently good throughout and appears to use low generation VHS sources. However, the Rising material on Disc 3 is available in better quality elsewhere.

version.name: No Nukes
version.description: Excerpt from "No Nukes" of Bruce's three performances featured in the movie. Ripped from the commercial laser disc release for virtually perfect quality.

version.name: Survival Sunday

songlist: Brother John is Gone (with all other artists)

version.description: This DVD includes Bruce's acoustic set at the Survival Sunday anti nuclear rally at the Hollywood Bowl. The pro shot footage comes from a single camera, possibly a TV news crew. The audio is taken from the soundboard. The image is sharp and clean, although a little distant at times. Excellent quality.

version.name: The Last Dance
version.description:
A 30-song blowout that lasted nearly 3 hours and 20 minutes, this final show was one that may have had emotions running high, but Bruce seemed committed to keeping things loose and fun. "Welcome to the Last Dance," he said before Waitin' on a Sunny Day.
The biggest surprise of the night, as a fellow legend came out to share the stage for "Highway 61 Revisited." Bruce told the crowd, "We have my great friend and inspiration with us tonight, Mr. Bob Dylan... we wouldn't be here tonight without him." 
 
Multi-Cam mix that uses the video from the screen shot version and video of the stage.  The DVD is filmed just right with enough transitions between the two cameras.   The transitions between the cameras are great and the picture quality is clear and crisp.  The audio on the DVD is average.  This is yet another MUST have DVD from the Tour.

version.name: N/A
version.description:
This is the original version to surface.  Same screen filmer as 10-1 and 10-3. This is also one of the angles used in the 2-cam "Screwdevil" mix. Very steady.  Also shows the filmer walking to and from the stadium. This DVD is completely screen shot with good cam audio, but not up to par with the other 2. 
 Great show.  Many tour premiere's and special guests.  This show, in one version or another is a must have.

version.name: N/A

songlist: Can't Help Falling in Love With You

version.description: This show was partially broadcast on East German television and radio. It is not the full concert. There were 10 songs apparently not broadcast. Of the versions that are circulating on DVD, this version is also missing 2 additional songs (Out in the Street and Boom Boom) that can be found on the 2 disc versions. There is a graphic at the beginning of each song with the name of the song. The concert is a very nice pro-shot film and this is a very good quality version. The filming has a lot of crowd shots and close ups of people in the audience - probably half the footage is of the audience! The parts that are of the band concentrate on Bruce so there ends up being little time left for the rest of the band. Paradise By The C and I'm a Coward are very spirited versions and Can't Help Falling in Love With You is a sentimental favorite with the audience waving sparklers. This is the middle quality of the 3 versions.

capture.caption: Paradise By The C - Miami Horns
Paradise By The C - Bruce and C
Dancing in the Dark - Bruce Dancin'
Can't Help Falling in Love - Bruce

version.name: N/A

songlist: Can't Help Falling in Love With You

version.description:
This show was partially broadcast on East German television and radio. It is not the full concert. There were 10 songs apparently not broadcast. Of the versions that are circulating on DVD, this version has the 2 songs (Out in the Street and Boom Boom) missing from the 1 disc version. This is the only time on the tour that Out in the Street is played. There is a graphic at the beginning of each song with the name of the song. 

The concert is a very nice pro-shot film and this is a very good quality version. The filming has a lot of crowd shots and close ups of people in the audience - probably half the footage is of the audience! The parts that are of the band concentrate on Bruce so there ends up being little time left for the rest of the band. There is an interview from German TV on this version, between Hungry Heart and Glory Days. 

Paradise By The C and I'm a Coward are very spirited versions and Can't Help Falling in Love With You is a sentimental favorite with the audience waving sparklers. This is the best quality of the 3 versions. I'm not sure it is good enough to be from a master tape though.

version.name: 80s Reel

songlist: 12-Jun-82 Central Park, NY - Rally For Disarmament
13-Dec-87 All Star Benefit for the Homeless
LA Sports Arena (alternate Tougher Than the Rest)

version.description: Consistently excellent compilation of clips from throughout the 1980s. All clips are pro shot, with the exception of Nassau Coliseum. The lowest generation sources available have been used for the best possible quality.

version.name: Springsteen's March on Atlanta

bonus: My Love Will Not Let You Down (9/27/03)

version.description: One of the Best single cam DVDs you will ever see. Filmed from the left side of the stage the picture quality is perfectly crystal clear.  The audio is dubbed from the the ALD/AUD boot known as "Wild Producing" and is awesome.  The CTC once again shows us why they are "THE BEST".

version.name: Montreal '81

songlist: Darkness on the Edge of Town
You Can Look(But You Better Not Touch)

version.description: This cine camera footage was shot from the balcony at the side of the stage. It is a little shaky and distant and the image lacks any real definition. The audio has been dubbed from a fair audience recording, although the original audio is available as an alternate stream. This opportunity to see a complete "River" show shouldn't be missed, despite the poor quality. Also included on the disc is a soundboard audio recording of the second half of the Toronto 20 Jan 81 show.

version.name: Half of the Show

songlist: Darkness on the Edge of Town
You Can Look(But You Better Not Touch)

version.description: "Half of the Show" from Brucevideos showcases both new video and new audio sources of this well-known cine film. Unfortunately, as the name suggests, both are incomplete. The video is a little unsteady and distant, but this first generation copy is a major improvement. The colours are now more solid and the better definition reveals new detail. However, it cuts out after "Thunder Road", at which point the DVD reverts back to the previously circulated second generation video. As if the picture quality upgrade wasn't enough, the new dubbed audio is simply outstanding. This excellent audience recording is perhaps the best available from "The River" Tour. What's more, the DVD offers alternative streams of both the original master tape sound and a remastered version with extra "punch". The new audio cuts out after "You Can Look" and the remainder of the show is not present on the DVD at all, since there would have been no improvement over the previous release. The usual high standard of animated menus and intro sequence that we have come to expect from Brucevideos are present and correct. This version has transformed what was frankly a difficult viewing experience into a much more enjoyable DVD. Given the rarity of "The River" footage, this is a highly recommended upgrade.

capture.caption: Darkness on the Edge of Town

version.name: Part of the Show
version.description: This pro-shot film is among the best quality unofficial footage available. It features the second set and encores from Toronto, 26 July 1984. This particular transfer to DVD (there are several in circulation) uses the tape source featuring a "BLUE MOON" logo in the corner of the screen at all times. Audio (from the soundboard) and video quality are excellent. This two disc version has a slightly better image quality than the single disc BLUE MOON version. It also features animated menus.

version.name: Hot Fun in the Summertime
version.description: This pro-shot film is among the best quality unofficial footage available. It features the second set and encores from Toronto, 26 July 1984. This particular transfer to DVD (there are several in circulation) uses the tape source featuring a "BLUE MOON" logo in the corner of the screen at all times. It was originally released as a pressed silver disc on the "Watchdog" label. The excellent audio and video are virtually identical in quality to the two Disc "Part of the Show". However, the extras alone make it worth while getting this one. Included is a BBC "Newsnight" excerpt featuring brief news crew footage from Dublin and Newcastle and pro-shot footage of "Man at the Top" from Washington, all in 1985. Interestingly, the menus have film clips as their background.

version.name: Do You Love Me
version.description: This pro-shot film is among the best quality unofficial footage available. It features the second set and encores from Toronto, 26 July 1984. This particular transfer to DVD (there are several in circulation) uses a source tape free of the "BLUE MOON" logo. However, a "Right Stuff" logo appears in the corner of the screen for a few seconds at the start of each song. It has the same excellent audio and video quality as the other versions, but the lack of the "BLUE MOON" logo makes this the one to get.

version.name: Whole Lotta Rosie
version.description:
This is pretty much the same release as "Do You Love Me" released by Right Stuff with a few key changes.  First of all the footage of Rosalita has been fixed so that for the first time on DVD there is a complete and uncut version of Rosalita.
 
Secondly there is bonus footage included on this version.  All of the footage has been previously released.circulated but as well there has been some changed made.  The most obvious one will be the editing of "Stand On It" from the Meadowlands in 1985 where the previously circulated footage had some sloppy editing that resulted in parts of the song being repeated over again at a different camera angle.
 
This DVD also has a Dolby Digital 5.1 audio setup option.  Of all the versions of this DVD out there this is the version to have.

version.name: Whole Lotta Rosie - Revisited
version.description: "Whole Lotta Rosie... Revisited" is an upgrade of the well-known Toronto '84 pro-shot footage, as found on "Whole Lotta Rosie". Hence, it includes the re-edited and complete version of "Rosalita". On this new version, the "Right Stuff" logo that appeared for a few seconds at the beginning of each song has been digitally removed. Only the frames with the logo have been re-encoded, so the rest of the video remains in the same excellent quality as before. The other difference is the audio. This version features a remastered stereo track as well as newly created surround-sound Dolby Digital 5.1 and DTS tracks. Unfortunately, the excellent extras on the original release have had to be dropped to make way for the enhanced sound. The new animated menus and intro sequence are very impressive and give the production an overall feel of quality. "Whole Lotta Rosie... Revisited" currently represents the best presentation of this superb film.

version.name: The Bridge Benefits 1986 and 1995
version.description:
"DVD Dubbing Guy" Production.  Awesome DVD!!!  1986 is pro shot, very low generation source.  Acoustic set of Bruce, Nils and Danny.  Great Version of Fire.
 
From a ladies perspective all you need to know is this..

Bruce... Fire....  OMG!!!!
 
1995 footage is filmed from video screen.

version.name: N/A
version.description: Shot from the back left center left of the arena with a very steady camera and minor obstructions.  Average audio quality.  If you want this DVD get the ScrewDevil authored version.

version.name: N/A
version.description:
The last show of a two night stand in Toronto was great and the DVD captures it wonderfully.  It's filmed from the back left side of the arena.  The camera is very steady with very few obsturctions.  It is shot directly on the stage with lots of great close ups of Bruce and the band.
 
A high energy show which included a great setlist opening with Don't Look Back.  The shows highlight was Incident on 57th Street played by request.  Other rarities included Rendezvous, a country acoustic version of No Surrender, and Jungleland.  Bruce and the band were all smiles throughout the night.  Bruce capped evening off with a 3rd encore rocking rendition of Ramrod that included a slide through Clarence's legs and a judo roll at the end of the song.

version.name: Tunnel of Love Express Tour 1988

songlist: Who Do You Love/She's the One - Copenhagen
You Can Look (But You Better Not Touch) - Copenhgn
bonus: Can't Help Falling in Love With You - East Berlin
Dancing in the Dark - Street Performance

version.description:
Nice pro-shot compilation from two of the European tour dates plus bonus tracks including camcorder footage of a few acoustic songs done as a duet with a street performer. Not a complete concert - the Copenhagen tracks cover the end of the main set and the Basel tracks cover most of the encore. 

Well filmed without the audience footage seen on the East Berlin DVD - the other pro-shot DVD of the tour. Only time on the tour that Follow That Dream was played - reportedly at the request of a fan. This release is available on the Watchdog label and is the first "official" Bruce bootleg DVD release on a factory pressed "silver" DVD.  

Bonus Tracks from: 
1988-05-02, Shoreline Amphitheater, Mountain View, CA  
1988-07-19, Radrennbahn Weissennsee, East Berlin, Germany 
1988-07-23, Copenhagen Street Performance

One of the better Reunion tour shows, dubbed with great audio.  There are three minor cuts one during Badlands, one during Out in the Street, and last during Born to Run.

version.name: Born in the USA Reel

songlist: 'Dancing in the Dark' Promo Alternate Takes

version.description: Great compilation of pro-shot live footage and TV interviews from 1984 and 1985. Picture quality varies from excellent to fair, but the best available source has been used in each case. The highlight of the set in definitely the NFL Films footage from the final show of the tour in LA, although all songs are cut. The contemporary TV segments are also interesting.

version.name: N/A

version.description: Great show, however the video is VERY shaky, and hard to watch at times. Good picture quality, despite the age.  Very good audio was used to dub the DVD.

version.name: N/A

songlist: Darkness on the Edge of Town
Twist & Shout / Do You Love Me

version.description: Not the best quality, but a good show nonetheless, and features a rare performance of Shut Out The Light. Good sound quality, and well filmed although there are obstructions throughout, and it can be a little shaky, but not excessively so.  PAL format, may not play in some US DVD players.

version.name: N/A

songlist: Twist & Shout / Do You Love Me

version.description:
Wonderful show, the only complete BITUSA pro-shot we have.  Given the heat that day, some remarkable performances - Thunder Road, Cadillac Ranch and a long Twist And Shout stand out.
  
New version of this classic video, and a substantial improvement over the old circulating DVD that was approaching unwatchable, with "VIDEO CALIBRATION" messages appearing from time to time. The second disk is especially good since it was recorded in high quality XP mode. This release is in PAL, not NTSC so it may not play on some US DVD players.
One thing to note - the video DOES look better than the screenshots suggest.

version.name: Philadelphia '85 XP

songlist: Twist & Shout / Do You Love Me

version.description: Wonderful show, the only complete BITUSA pro-shot we have. Given the heat that day, some remarkable performances - Thunder Road, Cadillac Ranch and a long Twist And Shout stand out. This four disc version uses the same high generation source tape as the newer 2 disc version. Hence, there are none of the "VIDEO CALIBRATION" errors, but still lots of noise due to generation loss. The transfer in XP mode provides only a marginal improvement in quality. This could be one of the all-time essentials, if a lower generation source ever gets into circulation.

version.name: Live on the Born in the USA Tour

songlist: Twist & Shout / Do You Love Me
Darkness On The Edge Of Town (1-16-85)

version.description: The pro shot footage of the complete "Born in the USA" show in Philadelphia is one of the most well known and widely circulated 'unofficial' Springsteen videos. The original source was apparently a VHS recording of a stadium sky box feed, but all versions to date have suffered heavily from interference on the image. This new version from the "Watchdog" label claims to be taken from a newly discovered low generation tape. The picture quality is undoubtedly cleaner than we have ever seen before, but there is still quite a bit of interference present. There is also a noticeable loss in picture detail compared to previous versions. This has led to the suspicion that this might just be the same generation that we have seen before, but cleaned up with digital filtering. Worse still, the sound quality is significantly poorer than earlier releases. The DVD also includes the previously circulated pro shot footage from Charlotte earlier the same year. It is a distant view from a single camera at the back of the arena. The low definition image and good soundboard audio are the same quality as we have seen on other versions. "Live on the Born in the USA Tour" version of the Philadelphia footage definitely looks different and can probably be considered an upgrade, but the feeling you are most likely to have after viewing this is disappointment that the quality is not better. It should be noted that this was released by "Watchdog" as a single pressed DVD9, but has been split across two DVD-Rs to make trading easier. This has resulted in the sub menus on Disc 2 listing the tracks from the whole set, but obviously only the second half can be selected.

version.name: N/A
version.description: New version of this video that includes dubbed audio from an excellent audience tape, and transforms an average video into a very watchable, entertaining DVD. Thunder Road is a highlight, along with I'm Goin' Down and The River. This DVD also includes a first - an alternate audio stream with soundboard audio on selected tracks on the second disc (tracks 1-6). Despite the video cutting out during Born To Run, the complete show is available to listen to as a hidden feature.

version.name: Old Grey Whistle Test

songlist: Born in the USA (Mountain View, 13 Oct 86)

version.description: This "Old Grey Whistle Test" TV special was originally shown by the BBC in the UK in 1986. However, the source tape used for this DVD is taken from a rebroadcast in Asian and comes complete with Chinese subtitles. The documentary features an interview with Bruce circa 1985 and a number of complete songs, although several of them are official videos. Of most interest are two performances from Philadelphia in 1984 ("Born in the USA" and "Cover Me"). A third track from Philadelphia '84 ("Detroit Medley") consists almost entirely of film of the audience ! What makes this DVD worth owning is not the OGWT documentary, but the extras. These include five complete pro-shot performances from the '85 tour. Both the main feature and the extras come from a 2nd/3rd generation source and the quality suffers accordingly.

version.name: Glory Days
version.description: This BBC documentary was first broadcast in 1987. It features a lengthy interview with Bruce as well as individual interviews with members of the band. What makes this special though, is the archive footage. Although some of it is well known (Hammersmith '75, Largo '78, Pheonix '78) it has never been seen in better quality than this. The real star, is footage from the last show of the BITUSA tour in LA in 1985. "Johnny 99" for instance, is simply stunning. If that wasn't enough, the extras are fantastic too. "Thunder Road" from LA '85 is seen in its entirety (part of it is seen during the documentary) and there are two different camera angles of "Sandy" from Hammersmith '75. The source for this DVD is a pristine off-air SVHS promo tape, resulting in a transfer as close to broadcast quality as we are ever likely to see.

dvdLocation.venue: Rock and Roll Hall of Fame 1987-1999

version.name: Rock and Roll Hall of Fame 1987-1999
version.description: This compilation features all of Bruce's appearances at the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame annual induction ceremonies to date. There is a great variety of performances with a plethora of legendary artists. The highlight is the 1999 performance at Cleveland stadium, including at duet with Bob Dylan. Audio/video quality is variable, with the older clips particularly suffering from generation loss. However, the newer clips are very good.

Highlight from the show is that Tenth Avenue includes a Tarantella (Italian folk dance), with, as Bruce said, not the Three Tenors, but the Three Accordions: Danny, Nils and Roy. Featured dancers were Bruce's mother and aunt.

Much better than the previous version.  This one is shot from the right side looking at the stage.  Filmer shoots mainly the stage, but switches to the screen once in a while.  Cam audio is pretty good, a little scratchy at times.  Excellent picture.  Periodically the filmer pans back and captures the stage and screen at the same time. Check out the screen shots for examples.  The is the Paris show to get!
 Rarities include "Be True" and "Trapped."

version.name: N/A
version.description: This was the first DVD of 5-27-2003 to surface.  The audio is still pretty good from the cam, but the dubbed version blows it away.  There are a few minor cuts and security ducks, but not a big deal.  Incredibly clear and steady picture.  Most of the time the filmer stays back with a great wide view of the stage.

version.name: N/A
version.description: One of the best from 2003.  Same video as original version, but with incredible dubbed audio thanks to DVD Dubbing Guy.  DVD is authored with menus and chapters.  This one is a must have.

version.name: N/A
version.description: Same video as previous two and this one also has dubbed audio.  Only difference is this one is NTSC instead of PAL.  Usually you see quality loss when changing formats, but you really cant tell at all with this one.  So, no matter what kind of player you have, this one is available to you.

version.name: N/A

songlist: My Love Will Not Let You Down

version.description: Set features tour debut of I'm On Fire. Light Of Day includes I Hear A Train. During 10th Avenue, Gary plays a snippet of "We gotta get out of this place" and Patti sings a verse of Rumble Doll.  Good quality, decent sound. Filmed left side, fairly distant

version.name: Bremen on Fire

songlist: My Love Will Not Let You Down

version.description: Bruce's final German Reunion show showcased the tour premier of "I'm On Fire" in an otherwise standard set list. There was also a brief snippet of "I Hear a Train" sequenced into "Light Of Day" and Patti was given her moment to shine with a verse of "Rumble Doll" during "Tenth Avenue...". "Bremen on Fire" opens with a title sequence and photomontage over the audio of the start of the show. The video then kicks in around half way through the opener. It is shot from the left side of the stadium and the filmer does a good job of holding a steady, unobstructed view of a slightly distant Bruce. The image quality is clear, but a little soft due to some minor generation loss. There is a good colour balance at the beginning. However, once the daylight gives way to the spot lights, the picture appears a little over-exposed (particularly Bruce's white shirt). The shortcomings in the picture quality are more than compensated by the excellent audio that has been dubbed from the CD of the same name. The bright and strong sound is one of the best audience recordings of the tour. This is an enjoyable watch and a nice record of the European '99 stadium shows.

version.description: This marathon 58 track, 6 hour compilation documents Bruce's record breaking 15 night stand at the Meadowlands which kicked off the first US leg of the Reunion Tour. The highlights are too numerous to mention, with many songs performed seldom if ever again on the tour. Some of the more obscure selections from "Tracks" feature heavily. It is primarily stage shot, but there are a few screen shots along the way. There are obviously a variety of sources of differing quality, but sound and picture are generally extremely good. Although it is hard to tell for sure, most of the tracks appear to be dubbed. The puzzling question regarding this particular version is why it was created in the first place. The new menus are undeniable well designed, but the audio and video content appears to be identical to the earlier authored version. If you don't already have this set, then this version is the most attractively packaged one of the lot. However, if you already have the previous menued/chaptered version then there doesn't seem to be anything here that would justify an upgrade.

version.name: Working In The Rain

version.description:

Milano fixed screen shot DVD this DVD has full 4:3 picture and absolutely no black borders. 
 The sound has been dubbed from an AWESOME remastered CD recording.  
The audio is amazing,  but there is nearly ZERO crowd noise which sometimes leads to a lack of atmosphere. So the author of this DVD decided to add another audio track with more crowd noise. You can easily change audio layers during any time while watching the DVD. The second audio layer is a mix of the CD and the original sound from the video.

version.name: Birthday Night
version.description: Philadelphia crowds always seem to get something special. The fifth night of the six night Reunion Tour stand was unique in many ways, not least because rescheduling caused by cancellation of an earlier show meant that this one now fell on the day after Bruce's 50th birthday. The showed opened by Bruce charmingly playing a fan-made birthday tribute song on a boom-box. He then proceeded by tearing into the topical "Growing Up". A host of other oldies were also scattered throughout the show, including "Spirit...", "Does This Bus Stop...?" and a rare "Fever". "Birthday Night" from Digi-TOx fits the previously circulated incomplete 2 DVD set onto a single disc. This unsteady footage is shot from the back of the arena, with the zoom unable to provide any real close-ups. The majority of the view is taken from the stage, but there are also several switches to the giant screen. The image is soft and suffers from colour saturation and a chromashift towards the blue. The camcorder audio is average at best. The video cuts out after "Fever", missing all of the encores and the "Blinded by the Light" finale. Digi-TOx has made a nice job of authoring this onto a single disc, but it is sad that the video of this amazing show isn't better.

version.name: Milan 85... 20th Anniversary Edition
version.description: This handheld camcorder footage from Bruce's legendary first ever Italian show has been in circulation in various formats for many years. Now, just in time for the 20th Anniversary, a new DVD sourced from a recently unearthed 1st generation VHS copy of the master has surfaced. The significant improvement in the picture quality is not enough to rescue Disc 1 (subtitled "Day"). The filmer shoots the stage from the stadium floor and struggles to get a clear view. In fact, you will learn far more about the haircuts and dress sense of Italians in the '80s than you will about the E Street Band's performance. The extremely shaky footage does capture the general ambience, but you are unlikely to be willing to sit through the short 29 minute running time. The DVD producers have chosen not to replace the distant camcorder audio because of the fragmented nature of the film (most songs are cut). The main attraction of this set is Disc 2 (subtitled "Night"). The filmer wisely changes his position and switches his view to the giant screen for the second set and the encores. He does a good job holding a steadier angle and there are far fewer obstructions. Allowing for the limitations in the technology of the day, picture quality is very good. All of the songs are complete and so the producers have been able to dub the audio. This fantastic stereo audience tape was recorded using two microphones mounted on poles either side of the stadium and is best known from its release on CD by Crystal Cat. Disc 2 of "Milan 85... 20th Anniversary Edition" is perhaps the best available audience shot DVD of the BITUSA tour. It is well worth the effort of tracking it down.

version.name: Living Proof

songlist: Darkness on the Edge of Town

version.description: Stockholm was the first city to get a look at "The Other Band" when it hosted the opening shows of the Human Touch/Lucky Town tour. "Living Proof" features the second of the two nights. The previously circulated DVD of the show has been used as the video source. It is shot from the right side of the arena, just forward of the stage. There are some nice close-up views, but it is very unsteady at times and there are frequent obstructions. There is also a strange telescopic effect when the zoom is used which occasionally masks the edges of the image. The picture quality is reasonably clean, but the video has been re-encoded and so there has been some slight degradation when compared to the original. A few still photographs have been interspersed throughout the video at some of the song transitions and other random moments. The main thing that "Living Proof" has to offer is the audio dubbed from Crystal Cat's CD of the same name. This good audience recording is a big improvement on the original camcorder sound, but synchronisation with the video is a little out at times. This is especially noticeable during the first song, which is unfortunate. The author has made a valiant effort to improve this stage shot video with upgraded audio. The interspersed stills are a novel touch. However, the obstructions and synchronisation issues become distracting after a while. It is also a pity that an authoring method that avoided re-encoding the video wasn't used.

version.description:
Out of the 2 versions known available, this is the one to have.  The camera source is the same as version 1(The same tracks are still cut (57 Channels and Nothin' On & My Beautiful Reward), but the better generation makes a big difference in this show.  The video was definitely edited by someone.  For instance, when a song is cut completely(which is often toward the end of the show), it fades to a white screen.  If a song is cut in the middle, and the filmer got more footage of the same song, it is continued right where he left off.  I know that is kind of a confusing description, but imagine it to be like if you kept hitting the record and stop button on your camera.  Any questions, just post a comment.  
 The video overall, shot from just a slight angle across the stage is very well shot.  The filmer zooms in and out just the right amount and pans across very well. 
 The overall quality of this one is quite good, but for a average 92-93 fan it may not be necessary because of the song cuts.  A great one to add to your collection if you enjoy that tour though.

version.name: For Love, Faith, Hope and Sex

songlist: Darkness On The Edge Of Town
All The Way Home (w/ Southside Johnny)

version.description: The tenth of Bruce's eleven shows at the Meadowlands in 1992 saw a couple of interesting additions to the set list. "For You" and "Racing in the Streets" were performed for the first (and last) time on the Human Touch/Lucky Town Tour. The other main highlight was Southside Johnny's guest spot on "All The Way Home". "For Love, Faith, Hope and Sex" from "SDonkey Productions" presents a startlingly good quality tape of the show from LAM Videos. It is the same footage as the previously circulated DVD, but this time comes direct from the master.  The set opens with a brief title sequence dubbed with the spoken intro to "Leap of Faith", hence revealing the inspiration for the title. We then join the show at the start of the second song ("Better Days" is missing). The detail and colour balance of the image are instantly striking, given the immaturity of camcorder technology at the time. The dubbed audio is also remarkably good, due in no small part to the remastering done by Rockaway Rob. The footage is shot from an acute angle on the left side of the arena. The filmer holds the camera steady and does a good job of keeping Bruce centre-frame when he roams the stage. The view is mostly unobstructed, except for the final two songs when someone stands up in front of the camera. The great picture and sound quality and steady camera work makes "For Love, Faith, Hope and Sex" one of the very best HT/LT DVDs, the only negative aspect being the side-on view. Another terrific addition to the SDonkey catalogue.

version.description:
Let's allow the man who is responsible for the amazing productions do this one!  In Stan's words:
 This two-DVD set is all the raw footage from that night except for Leap of Faith which doesn't seem to exists anywhere (maybe the cameras were shut off for the two takes of it).
  It includes all the stuff that was edited out of the official releases...  The six-minute crowd warm-up before Bruce comes out; Bruce's talking between songs (and he had a lot to say this night on a variety of subjects), and three songs ("Book of Dreams," "Souls of the Departed" and "Soul Driver") that were never shown on MTV or on the later
official releases of a VHS tape and Laserdisc of this show.
Plus the final song, "Glory Days" is show in it's entirety. 
 This has different camera shots that
were not on any of the official releases also.
 Thanks Stan!
