 Stan's "Plugged & Raw" version is the one to have!!

version.name: N/A

songlist: Darkness On The Edge Of Town

version.description:
DVD only has the first set of the show.  Very steady with excellent audio.  This show, for some reason, is not widely circulated.   Features great wide stage shots, as well as close-ups on Bruce.  Most of the video is actually mainly focused on Bruce at the Mic. 
 The show is seperated into 2 parts, as you can see on the standalone menu pic.

version.name: Washington '95

songlist: Darkness On The Edge Of Town
It's The Little Things That Count
Does This Bus Stop At 82nd St.?
My Best Was Never Good Enough
bonus: Nick's Fat City, 20 Oct 95 (w/ Joe Grushecky)

version.description: This footage was shot using a handheld camcorder from the theatre balcony, resulting in a slightly shaky picture. The image is dark and grainy and the audio is only fair. Also included on the disc is video from Bruce's guest spot with Joe Grushecky in the same year. Unfortunately, a high generation tape with poor audio was used.

version.name: Dry Lightning

songlist: Darkness On The Edge Of Town
It's The Little Things That Count
Does This Bus Stop At 82nd St.?
My Best Was Never Good Enough

version.description: "Dry Lightning" from July4th1985 uses the previously circulated DVD as the video source. This handheld footage is quite shaky and the picture is dark and grainy. There are some good close-up shots when the filmer is able to hold a steady shot. This version uses an audience recording that first appeared on the "Car Songs" CD-R to replace the dull camcorder audio on the original. The sound is now clear and strong. Menus have been added using dramatic monotone images to complete a very good release. GOTJ shows have been neglected by the DVD dubbing community in the past, so this will be a welcome upgrade for fans of the tour.

version.name: San Jose '96

songlist: Darkness On The Edge Of Town

version.description: This show during the GOTJ tour was performed as a benefit for the John Steinbeck Research Center. It was filmed with a handheld camera fairly close to the front of the stage. The image is dark, but it is reasonably steady and has better definition than some of the other Joad videos. Sound is also above average.

version.name: Once Upon a Time in the West

songlist: Darkness On The Edge Of Town

version.description: A great deal of Bruce's music owes a debt to the writings of John Steinbeck. Bruce first drew on Steinbeck's themes of sympathy and justice for the working man on the "Darkness" album and this shared message culminated in an entire album's worth of songs about the struggles of migrant workers on "The Ghost of Tom Joad". It was therefore appropriate that Bruce accepted an invitation during the Joad tour to perform a benefit for San Jose State University's John Steinbeck Research Center. "Once Upon a Time in the West" from Ultimix uses the previously circulated video of the show. Like most of the amateur videos from the tour, this footage is fairly dark. However, unlike the rest, this one is very steady and the filmer was well situated in a central location. The picture quality is good, with reasonable definition and little sign of generation loss. The outstanding feature of this DVD is the excellent audience recording used to dub the audio. It is very clear and the strong vocal sound makes it possible to understand the lengthy spoken segments (another shortcoming on many of the other GOTJ DVDs). The DVD also includes a great title sequence that features a clip of Tom Joad's famous speech from the film version of Steinbeck's "The Grapes of Wrath" ("wherever there's a cop beating a guy, I'll be there"). Ultimix should be commended for this quality production of an interesting show. Highly recommended.

version.name: Once Upon a Time in the West V2.0

songlist: Darkness On The Edge Of Town

version.description: A great deal of Bruce's music owes a debt to the writings of John Steinbeck. Bruce first drew on Steinbeck's themes of sympathy and justice for the working man on the "Darkness..." album and this shared message culminated in an entire album's worth of songs about the struggles of migrant workers on "The Ghost of Tom Joad". It was therefore appropriate that Bruce accepted an invitation during the Joad tour to perform a benefit for San Jose State University's John Steinbeck Research Center. The excellent presentation of the show on "Once Upon a Time in the West" from Ultimix has now been further improved by DVD Dubbing Guy. Most of the elements from the Ultimix version have wisely been retained, including the stylish menu designs and the supreme title sequence that uses Henry Fonda's soliloquy from "The Grapes of Wrath" to such great effect. Like most of the amateur videos from the tour, the footage is fairly dark. However, unlike the rest, this one is very steady and the filmer was well situated in a central location. The picture quality is good, with reasonable definition and little sign of generation loss. The dubbed audio on the original Ultimix version was already outstanding. However, DVD Dubbing Guy has replaced it with an even better source. The sound is vibrant, full and crystal clear. It rates as one of the very best audience recordings of the entire tour. The best video footage, best DVD production and best sound from the GOTJ tour have now all come together on the same set. "Once Upon a Time in the West V2.0" is undoubtedly an essential part of any respectable Bruce DVD collection.

version.name: N/A

songlist: My Love Will Not Let You Down
Darkness on the Edge of Town

version.description: Shot from upper right, very steady with minor obstructions.  Good audio and picture quality.  Filmer mainly shoots a wide angle of the stage however there are some good closeups.  The different color stage lights give the DVD a very unique viewing experience.

version.name: St Louis '88

songlist: Ain't Got You - She's The One

version.description: One of the best camcorder videos from the TOL tour, shot from high up to the right of the stage. The image is sharp with good contrast. The audio is also good. However, it is a little shaky and there are obstructions from the crowd at times.

version.name: Tunnel of Love Express in St. Louis

songlist: Ain't Got You - She's The One

version.description: One of the best camcorder videos from the TOL tour, shot from high up to the right of the stage. The image is sharp with good contrast. The audio is also good. However, it is a little shaky and there are obstructions from the crowd at times.

version.name: St. Louis '88 (Floor)
version.description: The St. Louis TOL concert has been available for quite some time, but this more recently surfaced footage shows the performance from a quite different perspective. Amazingly, it is shot from the 4th or 5th row on the floor in front of the stage. Not surprisingly, it is very unsteady and there are constant obstructions. However, the filmer does an admirable job of keeping Bruce in view for as much time as possible. Picture quality (direct from the 8 mm master) is very good, but low resolution and a slightly overexposed image does mean that not much fine detail is visible. Audio is also very good, with no problems making out the spoken interludes. This video first circulated on two discs, but brucevideos has combined them onto a single disc without the need for any further compression. The source tape was missing the last four songs of the night. Floor shot footage from this close to the stage is extremely rare and gives a real "being there" feel. This is a great addition to the Bruce DVD catalogue.

dvdLocation.venue: Dancing in the Dark - The Video Rehearsals

version.name: Dancing in the Dark - The Video Rehearsals

songlist: Darkness On The Edge Of Town (1/16/85)

version.description: Footage of the rehearsals of the Dancing in the Dark video filmed at Bruce's house.  DVD contains 6 or 7 takes of Bruce rehearsing the dance steps for the video.  Very interesting footage,  The only word to describe this footage is "cringeworthy."  There is more footage on this DVD then what is shown on the This Is Your Life set.  Charlotte 1985 is included as bonus footage.

version.name: Los Angeles '88
version.description: Good quality camcorder footage transferred from the master tape. Shot from slightly behind the band at the side of the stage. The image is clear, but fairly shaky. There are some crowd obstructions and a strange circular matting effect when the camera zoom is used. Audio is only average. Several songs are cut or missing altogether. The second disc is recorded in XP Mode, resulting in better quality than the first.

version.name: Torino '88

songlist: Ain't Got You - She's The One

version.description: Reasonable handheld camcorder footage, shot from the stadium field to the right of the stage. The image is clear, but very shaky with lots of crowd obstructions. It is also a bit distant. There is an annoying lens glare that dances around the image in the second half of the show. Audio is only fair.

version.name: Turin '88 Pro Shot
version.description: This terrific multi-camera pro-shot footage of the Tunnel of Love Express Tour's stop in Turin originates from an Italian TV show called "Notte Rock". It begins with Bruce's stage entrance and then cuts to the final verse of the show opener, followed by around half of the second song (a rocking rendition of "Boom Boom"). The DVD then jumps to two consecutive performances from the final set of the show. The relatively low generation source tape has lost some of the picture definition, but is otherwise excellent viewing. The soundboard audio is strong. It is always great to have the opportunity to add new pro shot footage to your collection. The total running time is 13:45. Short, but sweet.

version.name: Sheffield '88
version.description: Handheld camcorder footage shot from the stadium field, close in front of the stage. The image is clear and reasonably steady. Unfortunately, the view is almost always partially obstructed by heads in the crowd. Audio is a little distant and muffled.

version.name: Munich '88

songlist: Who Do You Love - She's The One
Twist And Shout - Do You Love Me

version.description: Handheld camcorder footage shot from the field, quite close in front of the stage. The image is a little blurred, very shaky and there are lots of obstructions from the crowd. However, the sound is good for the era.

version.name: N/A

songlist: Darkness on the Edge of Town

version.description:
Very good stage shot DVD filmed from the left side of the arena.  The picture quality is very clear and steady.  There are very minor obstructions from the person to the left of the filmer on one or two songs.  The audio is excellent.  Fans of stage shot DVDs will love this one
 
The following flaw is on the Master Tape:
During Darkness, near the beginning (14:51 of disc 1), there is an audio skip - half a verse or so is missing.

version.name: The Unplugged Rehearsals
version.description: Interesting studio camera footage of Bruce and "The Other Band" rehearsing prior to the MTV Plugged recording later that day. Most of the songs are performed a number of times. Unfortunately, the DVD uses a very high generation tape as its source. The audio holds up quite well, but the picture quality suffers badly. One for completists only.

version.name: N/A

songlist: My Love Will Not You Down

version.description: Filmed from the left of the stage very close to the stage, there are minor obstructions arms, etc but it gives the DVD the feeling of being there in the front rows.  The picture qualty and audio are both very good to excellent.

version.name: N/A

songlist: My Love Will Not You Down

version.description:
This is the DVD to get of this show, it's the same source as the other version, but this one is from the Master tapes.  It is filmed from the left and very close to the stage so arms and heads get in the way once in awhile.  The video quality is superb with some amazing close-ups.  The audio is excellent.  This is a Must Have DVD from the reunion Tour.
 
The DVD has cuts during Prove It and The Promised Land. These are on the Master Tapes

version.name: 90s Reel
version.description: Excellent compilation of US TV chat show, award show, tribute show, guest spot appearances and specials from 1993-97. Things don't start too well with a recording of the Letterman '93 appearance that suffers from ghosting. After that though, things improve dramatically with very low generation sources for most of the remaining clips. Highlights include the poignant Sinatra birthday tribute and the Rolling Stone special.

version.name: Sony Studios

songlist: Darkness On The Edge Of Town

version.description: This show was video taped in front of a small audience at Sony Sound Studios, New York. Some of the footage was later broadcast internationally to promote the Greatest Hits album. This DVD uses an excellent first generation copy as its source. However, there is a slightly irritating time counter on screen throughout. The video quality degrades briefly during "Streets of Philadelphia" and then cuts to a blue screen before resuming at the previous quality during "Prove It All Night".

version.name: Sony Studios

songlist: Darkness On The Edge Of Town

version.description:
Same as 1st version with setlist exceptions, such as:
 Version 1, the video quality degrades briefly during "Streets of Philadelphia" and then cuts to a blue screen before resuming at the previous quality during "Prove It All Night".  On this version, "Streets Of Philadelphia" is not included at all (check out the screen shot on the right).
"Prove It All Night" still has the blue screen at the begining, but the song is complete.  
 Some songs are cut from the version, therefore, version 1 is the one to have.

version.name: Sony Studios

songlist: Darkness On The Edge Of Town

version.description: The source of this Silver Visions Production is probably the "DVD Dubbing Guy" version of "Sony Studios". The first version of "Streets of Philadelphia" is cut and "Prove It All Night" fades in. What has changed is that the on-screen counter is masked throughout by a black banner with the song titles in white text. If the "DVD Dubbing Guy" disc was the source rather than the same tape, it would have been necessary to re-encode the video to achieve this. In theory at least, there will be some degradation in quality. In practice, it is very difficult to detect any difference when the two versions are compared side-by-side. This version also boasts an alternate Dolby 5.1 mix, although this has been achieved by some digital trickery since the multi-track tapes were obviously not available to the producers. Purist will argue that the "DVD Dubbing Guy" version is the one to get. However, this version does a nice job of hiding the counter without any obvious loss in quality.

version.name: NYC '95 (Broadcast Version)
version.description:
This show was video taped in front of a small audience at Sony Sound Studios, New York. This version is of the Family Channel broadcast that 

was used to promote the "Greatest Hits" album release and subsequent "Blood Brothers" film (which preimere broadcast was aired just prior to 

this). The entire broadcast is represented here (From the opening sequence to the end credits). 

The video and audio quality are excellent. There are no "timecodes" or "music title bars", as in other versions. The only irritant is the "Family 

Channel" pledge logo and phone number for the donation drive that was going on when this was broadcast, poping up once in a while. Other 

than that, a very addition to any collector's stash.

version.name: N/A
version.description:
Show opens with Badlands.  Some obstructions, but overall good picture quality with great audio.
There are a few cuts to be aware of.  Badlands has a start cut and another at the end, also there is a cut in Darlington County.

version.name: Cafe Eckstein
version.description: Bruce shot his promo video for the 1995 re-release of "Hungry Heart" at Cafe Eckstein in Berlin with German Wolfgang Niedecken & His Band. This excellent pro-shot footage features the entire performance in front of a small crowd inside the cafe with a much larger crowd outside. The unique occasion and the song selection of some great rock standards make this a very enjoyable DVD. A 15 minute "Making Of" documentary is also included, featuring footage of Bruce in and around Berlin at the time of the video shoot. There is some picture quality degradation apparent, possibly due to using a (S)VCD as the source. However, it is still very good overall.

version.name: Cafe Eckstein Version 2.0
version.description: Bruce shot his promo video for the 1995 re-release of "Hungry Heart" at Cafe Eckstein in Berlin with German Wolfgang Niedecken & His Band. This excellent pro-shot footage features the entire performance in front of a small crowd inside the cafe with a much larger crowd outside. The unique occasion and the song selection of some great rock standards make this a very enjoyable DVD. A 15 minute "Making Of" documentary is also included, featuring footage of Bruce in and around Berlin at the time of the video shoot. This upgraded version uses a master copy of the "Making of" promo tape and a 1st generation copy of the concert as its sources. There is a noticeable improvement in picture quality when compared to the original, although it is still not perfect by any means. There is a "Super Six" logo in the bottom left corner of the screen throughout the show, but any distraction this causes is more than compensated by the cleaner image. The DVD even borrows the original's menu, although the text "Version 2.0" has been added. Collectors should take the time to seek out "Version 2.0" if they are adding "Cafe Eckstein" to their library for the first time. It is also a worthwhile upgrade for those who already have a copy of the first issue.

version.name: Ghost on the Balcony
version.description: Excellent compilation of camcorder footage, pro shot live footage and TV appearances during the GOTJ tour. The DVD opens with some unique amateur video of an impromptu performance of "Thunder Road" from the theatre balcony after his show in Naples, although the song is barely audible. Following that is some great quality pro-shot footage of 5 songs from the Frankfurt '96 show. The pro shot footage from Antwerp is sadly silent. Also included is some camcorder video of the Proposition 209 Rally in '96 from very close range. The remainder of the DVD consists of familiar US and European TV appearances. Reasonably low generation sources are used throughout. It should be noted that you really need to be a fan of the song "The Ghost of Tom Joad" to view this in one sitting. There are no less than six different renditions included.

version.name: Toronto '88
version.description: Very good camcorder footage of Bruce and the E Street Band's set in Toronto on the Amnesty Tour. After briefly shooting the stage during the first song, the filmer settles on the screen for the remainder of the performance. Use of a tripod ensures that the image is rock steady. This "Ultimix" authored DVD uses a source tape suffering a bit from age and generation loss. The image is quite dark, but an excellent audience tape has been used to dub the audio. Overall, very enjoyable.

version.name: Human Rights Now!
version.description: Superb pro-shot footage of Bruce and the E Street Band's complete set in Buenos Aires during the final show of the Amnesty Tour. Audio and video quality are very good. However, generation loss and lines of interference at the bottom of the screen caused by tracking errors keep this from being one of the essentials. Incidentally, the DVD appears to have no Menu whatsoever.

version.name: Human Rights Final !

bonus: Remember When the Music (Harry Chapin Tribute)

version.description: "Human Rights Final !" (should that have been "Finale"?) from the pseudo-official Apocalypse Sound label features pro-shot footage of Bruce's complete performance from the last "Human Rights Now !" show in Buenos Aires. The video appears to come from the same ~2nd gen source as the previously circulated standalone DVD, but the image has been cropped top and bottom to remove the lines of interference that marred the original. Depending on your point of view, this is either an improvement or degradation. The SOS Racism and Harry Chapin Tribute appearances are included as bonus material, but both are available in significantly better quality on other titles. The package is completed by a slick logo sequence (Frances Ford Coppola should sue) and attractively designed menus. Some might find the cropping of the interference removes a distraction, but purist will prefer the original version with the entire frame intact.

dvdLocation.venue: Human Rights Now! Tour HBO Special

version.name: Human Rights Now! Tour HBO Special

songlist: Human Rights Now! Tour HBO Special Part 1
Human Rights Now! Tour HBO Special Part 2
Human Rights Now! Tour HBO Special Part 3

version.description: This 3 hour HBO TV Special from 1988 documents the entire 6 week Amnesty International Human Rights Now Tour. As well as on stage performances from each of the artists involved, footage from press conferences, backstage and in the streets of the various cities visited is also included. Bruce appears fleetingly on the first two discs, but his major contribution is around 45 minutes from his Buenos Aires set on Disc 3. Also included is the lengthy spoken intro to "War" from the Zimbabwe show. This XP transfer direct from a VHS recording of the original broadcast is close to perfect quality. Certainly far better than the single disc DVD of the Buenos Aires show.

dvdLocation.venue: Inside the Tunnel of Love + Rockumentary

version.name: Inside the Tunnel of Love  + Rockumentary
version.description: Here we have two hour long documentaries from MTV, although they run nearer 50 minutes each since the ads have been edited out. "Inside the Tunnel of Love" (originally broadcast in 1988) features lengthy extracts of an interview backstage on the TOL Tour. Bruce is in a philosophical mood and offers some real insight into the writing and recording of the album. Interspersed with this are a variety of official promo videos and pro-shot live footage, the best of which is from Detroit in March 1988. Unfortunately, the official promos are mostly complete, while the clips from Detroit consist of only a verse or so, rather than the other way around. The whole thing is hosted by Kurt Loder outside various Asbury Park landmarks. It stands alongside "Glory Days" as the best of all Springsteen documentaries. "Rockumentary" from 1992 is a retrospective of Bruce's entire career up to that point. Most of the clips are familiar, with a couple of interesting exceptions. These include brief semi-pro footage of a performance at Max Weinberg's wedding (in very good quality), rehearsals in both LA and New York for the HT/LT Tour and pro-shot stage footage from New Jersey and Stockholm from the same tour. An excellent 1st generation source tape for the transfer to DVD has been used. The colours are a little pale, but the image is mostly sharp and free from any interference (apart from the last couple of minutes of "Rockumentary"). Overall, definitely one to add to your collection.

version.name: N/A

songlist: Darkness on the Edge of Town

version.description:
Filmed from a tripod at the back of the arena with good picture quality and very good audio.  You can see lines of interference at the bottom of the screen.

Tour debut of Dead Man Walking, which was dedicated to Life for Life, an organization which is attempting to appeal the death penalty in Oregon.

dvdLocation.venue: Rock & Roll Hall of Fame + A Secret History

version.name: Rock

songlist: Rock and Roll Hall of Fame Induction (1999)

version.description: This DVD consists of three items from late '98/early '99. First up is Bruce's induction into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame on 15 March 1999 at the Waldorf Astoria in New York. Bono's induction speech, Bruce's acceptance speech and the four songs performed with the band are all here. Next is some terrific pro-shot footage of "Prove It All Night" from the first Reunion Tour Rehearsal Show in Asbury Park on 18 March 1999. The source for this footage is probably a TV news crew. Finally, we have the 60 minute version of the BBC documentary "Bruce Springsteen: A Secret History", first broadcast in 1998. It contains an in-depth interview filmed earlier that year, together with a collection of now familiar clips from the archive. All three items come from very good low generation source tapes, although there is still some room for improvement in picture quality.

version.name: Hot Hartford Night '92

songlist: Darkness On The Edge Of Town

version.description:
Excellent show!  Amazingly steady shot.  Filmed from slightly to the left of the stage.  Lots of great close-ups.  Filmer focuses mainly on Bruce, but does pan back and get wide shots of the stage from time to time. 
 The audio is very good even though its from the camera.  It is a little bass heavy though, but not a big deal.  
 Definitely one of the 92-93 shows to have.

version.name: Are You Feeling Lucky Tonight?

songlist: Darkness On The Edge Of Town

version.description: This remarkable footage from Hartford first circulated on a DVD that used a 2nd generation source tape. An improved version from a 1st generation source appeared later. FTD Productions have now provided us with a further upgrade by taking the 1st generation video and adding new menus and an intro sequence. The DVD opens with a slide show of professional photographs from the era to the accompaniment of the audio from "Better Days" (there are some problems with the camcorder at this point). The video then kicks in for "Local Hero" and is complete for the remainder of the show. The picture quality is very good, although there is some minor ghosting visible at times. What really sets this one apart from the rest is the fantastic quality of the camera work. It is filmed from a tripod left/centre of the stage. The image is rock steady and the filmer does a great job of panning to keep Bruce in the centre of the frame as he roams around the stage. Prudent use is also made of the zoom to pull back for the occasional wide angle shot.  The new menus and title sequence give the overall production a feeling of genuine quality. This is now the definitive version of this show and one of the best DVDs from the HT/LT Tour. A real winner.

version.name: Regensburg '99

songlist: My Love Will Not Let You Down
Darkness On The Edge Of Town

version.description: Good stage shot camcorder footage, filmed from the left side of the arena with some nice close-ups. Audio and video quality are both clear, although the focus is a little soft. The camera was mounted on a tripod, but panning is very unsteady.

capture.caption: My Love Will Not Let You Down

version.name: Wie Geht's Regensburg

songlist: My Love Will Not Let You Down
Darkness on the Edge of Town

version.description: The Regensburg show took place early in the Reunion Tour at a time when "Tracks" was still being featured regularly. The three songs from the box-set (particularly "Rendezvous") are the highlights of the set. This camcorder footage is filmed from the left side of the arena, almost level with the stage. It is very unsteady and the filmer struggles to hold a clear view of the band at times. However, there are some nice close-ups throughout the majority of the show. "Wie Geht's Regensburg" from brucevideos showcases a new video transfer, direct from the master tape. The quality is significantly improved from the previous version, with a cleaner image and slightly more balanced colours (although orange still dominates). Better yet is the audio. It is dubbed from a remarkable uncirculated tape that is one of the best audience recordings of the entire tour. The trademark brucevideos animated menus complete the package. This is a major upgrade that benefits greatly from the improved picture and sound. However, the shaky side-on view will still be distracting for the more casual collector.

version.name: Earl's Court Third Night
version.description: Nice 2 cam mix of the third show at Earl's Court on the Reunion Tour. Both cameras are handheld and in a similar position on the right side of the arena. One camera concentrates on a wide angle shot of the stage (with the occasional pan up to the screen) while the other sticks to good close-ups of Bruce. Audio is also good. There is a brief intro filmed outside the arena and the show itself features the first performance of "Meeting" for 20 years.

version.name: No Support at Earl's Court

songlist: You Can Look (But You Better Not Touch)

bonus: I Wanna Be Where The Bands Are (5/18/99)
Darkness On The Edge Of Town (5/19/99)

version.description: The main feature on "No Support at Earl's Court" is the previously circulated 2 cam mix of the Reunion Tour's third night in London. The most noteworthy inclusion in the setlist is the first performance of "Meeting Across The River" for 20 years. Both cameras are handheld and in a similar position on the right side of the arena. One camera concentrates on a wide angle shot of the stage (with the occasional pan up to the screen) while the other sticks to close-ups of Bruce. Image quality from the first generation tape is reasonably good. However, Ultimix has improved things considerably by replacing the original audio with the great audience recording lifted from Crystal Cat's "Earl's Court Night" CD. The third disc in the set includes performances from the previous two nights, using the audio from the "Earl's Court Night" bonus cuts. Unfortunately, the video from both nights is from high generation sources. Also included as an extra special bonus is "Racing In The Streets" being soundchecked prior to the second show. The rarity value of this interesting footage outweighs the fairly low quality. Menus and an intro sequence complete a very nice package. Ultimix has done a very good job of producing a nice memento of the stand.

version.name: Ft Lauderdale 2000 1st Night

songlist: Darkness On The Edge Of Town

version.description: Great 2 cam mix stage shot of the first night in Ft Lauderdale during the Reunion Tour. Picture quality from both cameras (one on each side of the arena) is excellent with some nice close-up shots. Unfortunately, the dubbed audio is only fair.

version.name: Is That Your Final Answer?

songlist: Darkness On The Edge Of Town

version.description: The Reunion Tour rolled into the Ft. Lauderdale area on 9 March 2000 for the first of two shows in the famed Spring Break destination. It also marked the third of a four show jaunt through the Sunshine State. The rarely heard "Don't Look Back" got things off to a spirited start, but the real surprise was the first performance of "Brilliant Disguise" since a European show almost a year earlier. Other highlights included the always-welcome "Backstreets". Among the pop-culture references that peppered the show, Bruce asks the crowd at one point "Is that your final answer?" The "Who Wants to be a Millionaire?" catchphrase is not only used for the title of this remarkable debut release from BruceDVDs Productions, but the design scheme as well. Each disc features a motion clip of a different band member on the main menu. These transition to reveal a song selection menu that mimics the graphics from the quiz show. The intro sequence also uses a voice over in the style of a quiz show host to introduce each band member individually (featuring more of the animated figures). The video itself is the same 2-cam mix from LAM Videos that has already circulated on DVD. The filmers are each on opposite sides of the arena to give steady views with some good close-ups. BruceDVDs Productions has gone back to the master tape to create a new transfer that has been painstakingly adjusted with several minute edits to maintain synchronisation with the soundtrack. There has also been some colour correction to compensate for the occasional white-out on the source. The result is a clean and well-defined image from both camcorders. The primary audio is an excellent IEM/AUD mix that has been created by Rockaway Rob especially for this set. It is clear and lively, with great atmosphere. As a bonus, the unmixed IEM source is available as an alternative stream. Both tracks are uncompressed. Together with the maximum bit rate used to encode the video, this causes the set extends across four discs. The outstanding production values elevate "Is That Your Final Answer?" to arguably the very best presentation of a Reunion Tour show, if not any Bruce show. BruceDVDs Productions have set a new standard with their first release that will be a hard act to follow. Make sure you don't miss out on this one.

version.name: The Alliance of Neighbors

songlist: All Just To Get To You (w/ Joe Ely)

version.description: This show (the second of two consecutive nights) was originally conceived by Max Weinberg as a tribute to Sun Records, but was transformed into a benefit for local victims of 9/11. Bruce performs with a number of ex-Sun and New Jersey artists, as well as 4 numbers by himself. The source for this XP transfer to DVD is a digital broadcast by a local cable TV channel. Picture quality is perfect. An excellent soundboard source has been used to dub the audio. The audio was dubbed by "DVD Dubbing Guy"

version.name: VH1 Legends (+ 60 Minutes)
version.description: Brought to us by ScrewDevil Bruce Springsteen: Legends is a documentary originally broadcast on VH1 in 1998. It is a straight retelling of the Springsteen story from childhood to just prior to the Reunion Tour. It uses a wide variety of interviews, video clips and photographs from the archives, although most of the material will be familiar. The 60 Minutes segment originally aired in 1995, although a 2002 rebroadcast (complete with new introduction) appears here. Its consists of an in-depth interview with Ed Bradley, interspersed with the usual archive clips. Both shows are interesting and well made. This transfer to DVD has resulted in perfect audio and video quality.

version.name: The Rising on TV Volume 1 and 2
version.description:
Bruce accompanied the launch of "The Rising" with an unprecedented blitz of US news and chat TV shows. Here we have every appearance from that period (August 2002 - February 2003). Highlights include VH1's extended version of the car ride around Asbury Park and the complete "Nightline" broadcast (including footage of tour rehearsals and an acoustic "Empty Sky" at Bruce's home). Digital TV broadcasts have been used for the source of every segment, resulting in near-perfect audio and video quality.
This is the first ScrewDevil DVD release.

version.name: The Rising on TV Volume 1
version.description: Bruce accompanied the launch of "The Rising" album with an unprecedented blitz of US TV. Here we have every appearance from that period (August 2002 - February 2003). Highlights include VH1's extended version of the car ride around Asbury Park and the complete "Nightline" broadcast (including footage of tour rehearsals and an acoustic "Empty Sky" at Bruce's home). The original version of "The Rising on TV" (the very first release from the now-legendary ScrewDevil) used digital recordings for excellent audio and video quality. Nevertheless, DVD Dubbing Guy has searched through a multitude of alternative sources to improve the quality of some clips still further. What was previously near-perfect is now as close to perfect as we are every likely to see. The segments that have been changed are the Today Show performances (new video with better contrast, but audio dubbed from the original version), the MTV VMA appearance (improved 16:9 source), the Grammies appearance (new High Definition 16:9 video source, but dubbed audio from the original) and the "Lonesome Day" promo clip (new 16:9 source). The audio across both discs has been normalized for consistency and the problem with the menu audio volume has been fixed. The original menu structure and design has been retained, with the text "v2.0 by DVD Dubbing Guy" added for identification purposes. In addition to all of the clips from the original, there is an extra contemporary performance included as a bonus. It is a beautiful solo acoustic version of "Thunder Road" from the Lenny Zakim Bunker Hill Bridge dedication in October 2002. It is taken from a SVCD, but the quality is still very good and the audio has been remastered to reduce hiss. Owners of the original "The Rising on TV" are probably very happy with the quality, but perfectionists will find this a worthwhile upgrade.

version.name: VMA Rehearsals
version.description: Raw footage from the MTV TV cameras of afternoon rehearsals for the VMA appearance in 2002. There are multiple performances of "The Rising", complete with introductions by a stand-in for James Gandolfini. There are also lots wide shots of the Rose Center Planetarium and of people standing around doing nothing ! Also included is footage of the live performance that evening, preceded by around 15 minutes of shots the crowd waiting for Bruce to come on stage. Picture and sound quality are virtually perfect, but the whole thing is somewhat repetitive.

version.name: SNL Rehearsals
version.description: Superb TV camera footage of Bruce's rehearsals for his Saturday Night Live appearance in October 2002. Included are 3 complete takes of the two songs eventually performed in the show ("Lonesome Day" and "Your Missing") and two takes of "My Hometown". "Lonesome Day" is with the E Street Band, while the other two songs are performed solo at the piano.  A VHS master is used as the source of the DVD. Picture and sound are virtually perfect.

version.name: Conan O'Brien Rehearsals
version.description: One of Bruce's best ever TV appearances has to be "Late Night with Conan O'Brien" in December 2002. This DVD contains the rehearsals for the show, consisting of several run-throughs of both "Kitty's Back" and "Merry Christmas Baby". There is also a fair bit of standing around while the crew adjust the studio equipment etc. Picture quality is excellent. Unfortunately, there are several audio drop-outs, leaving only one or two instruments audible at times. The performances from the actual broadcast are also here, including the full reprise of "Merry Christmas Baby".

version.name: Giants Stadium #4
version.description: Very good stage shot camcorder footage of the fourth night at Giants Stadium in 2003. This was one of the best shows of the stand. The image is clear and reasonably steady for a handheld, although the focus is a little soft. It also suffers from some minor pixilation at times. The audio has been dubbed from a good audience tape. The transfer to DVD has been authored by ScrewDevil. The first six songs from the show have not been included because of problems with the source recording.

version.name: Holiday Show 2nd Night

songlist: Hold Out Hold Out (Victorious Gospel Choir)

When Something is Wrong with My Baby (Sam Moore)

version.description: Superb video of the second of the three Holiday Shows in December 2003. As well as several E Street Band members, guest stars include Bon Jovi and Sam Moore. The DV camcorder footage is clear and sharp, with great colour and definition. It is fairly steady and well filmed, with very few obstructions. The camcorder audio is also very good, but a slight delay is noticeable.

version.name: I Hate Christmas

songlist: Hold Out Hold Out (Victorious Gospel Choir)
I've Got a Feeling (Victorious Gospel Choir)
None But the Brave (w/ Alliance Singers)
This Time It's for Real (w/ Southside Johnny)

When Something is Wrong with My Baby (Sam Moore)
I Don't Want to Go Home (Southside, Steven)
What's So Funny about Peace,Love and Understanding
Santa Claus is Comin' to Town (all)

version.description: Superb video of the second of the three Holiday Shows in December 2003. As well as several E Street Band members, guest stars include Bon Jovi and Sam Moore. The DV camcorder footage is clear and sharp, with great colour and definition. It is fairly steady and well filmed, with very few obstructions. This version of the DVD features audio dubbed from an excellent audience recording. Opening credits have also been added.

version.name: N/A

songlist: Darkness On The Edge Of Town
Santa Claus Is Coming To Town

version.description: Excellent show!  Shot from straight across the stage.  Filmer is very steady throughout, and gets great shots of all members.  Picture is very clear, as you can see from the screen shots.  The audio is also exceptional even though its from the camera.  This is one of the 92-93 shows to have, even if you just have a few DVDs.  This show has just recently surfaced on DVD.

version.name: N/A

songlist: Darkness On The Edge Of Town

version.description:
This one is for collectors or big fans of the 92-93 tour only.  Picture is pretty degraded and also has a "dark" tone to it.  Audio from the camera is also very muffled.  Its shot from straight across the stage.  This particular DVD also freezes up toward the end of "My Beautiful Reward" to "Working On The Highway."  
 Jon Bon Jovi and Richie Sambora guest on "Glory Days.
 There is also a improved 2 disc version of this show.

version.name: N/A

songlist: Darkness On The Edge Of Town

version.description:
This particular show (which there are 2 versions of) is a perfect example of how generation loss can affect quality.  The 1 disc version has blurry video and muffled audio.  This version is a whole different story.  It is at least 2 generations lower.
 The video is the same source as the first version.  The audio on this one is very good, not even comparable to the first.
 There is one thing that did catch my attention with the audio however:  On disc 2, before "Because The Night",you can slightly hear a click, which also seems to change the audio.  The next 2 songs (BTN and Brilliant Disguise)are way out of sync.  The audio quality is also not up to the same quality as previously during the show(but it is still better than Version 1).
 Of the 2 versions this one is no doubt the one to have.  The filmer did a great job of keeping the camera steady and getting a great variety of shots. It was also cool to see Jon Bon Jovi and Richie Sambora play on "Glory Days" too.

version.name: N/A
version.description: Very well shot show, the only thing that keeps this one at a 5 is the loss of quality.  If this one could come from the master and add dubbed audio, it would be incredible.  Camera is steady throughout.  Shot from the upper right side, it gives a different side angle, instead of the straight across the stage shots(that most of the 92-93 shows are).  Audio is also muffled on this one, similar to the previous night.  Where are the masters for this one?

version.name: N/A

songlist: Darkness On The Edge Of Town

version.description: Spectacular show, maybe even an 8 rating.  Shot from the left side of the stage, the filmer does an awesome job, its very, very steady.  The quality of the picture is what really got me.  The colors and clarity are as good as any 93 show out there.  The audio from the camera is also great.  This is definitely one to have!

version.name: 12 Years Later He's Still The Boss

songlist: Darkness On The Edge Of Town

version.description: "12 Years Later He's Still The Boss" from July4th1985 Productions takes the video from the previously circulated DVD and dubs it with audio from the bootleg CD of the same name. The footage is shot from high on the left side of the arena, but good use of the zoom provides some reasonable close-ups. It is evident that the camcorder is hand-held, but nevertheless the filmer does a terrific job of keeping the shot as steady as possible while following Bruce around the stage. Some minor generation less and colour saturation don't distract from what is otherwise very good picture quality and the sound is a significant improvement compared to the original camcorder source. The CD artwork has been borrowed to create new menus. This is an extremely enjoyable DVD and a "must have"for fans of the HT/LT Tour.

version.name: N/A

songlist: Darkness On The Edge Of Town

version.description:
First thing about this show you notice is the "double blue menu."  This means it has been copied to a standalone not once, but twice.  You can tell because the standalone menu comes back after "Roll Of The Dice" on disc 1.  
 As for the show itself, it's a mix of stage and screen, both about half of the time.  Its shot from the left side of the screen, which means you dont see hardly any of Shane or Zack except the screen.  The screen shots appear very "dark", while the stage shots actually look pretty clear(even though the double blue standalone menu).  The audio isnt too bad either.  Not as good as some of the other 92-93 shows, but considering the gen, its not too bad.

version.name: Verona Night

songlist: Darkness On The Edge Of Town

version.description: "Verona Night" features the sole Italian show from the second European leg of the Human Touch/Lucky Town tour. The video is a new mix of two camcorder sources that have circulated previously on DVD. The camera on the right side of the arena shoots the stage exclusively. The image is reasonably sharp, but fairly distant. The image from the camera on the other side is also distant, softer and somewhat dark when it switches from stage to screen. Both are handheld and so a little unsteady. Despite the fact that title borrows Crystal Cat's naming convention, the audio is not dubbed from a CD. Instead, it comes from one of the camcorders and can only be described as below average at best. The author has done a good job of mixing the sources. The transitions are smooth and there is the occasional dabble with a "screen-in-screen" effect. Unfortunately, the video streams have been re-encoded and there is a noticeable degradation when compared to the originals. A nice effort, but the poor audio will hold you back from revisiting this one very often.

version.name: A Gentleman of Verona

bonus: Born To Be Wild (01-06-93 - Oslo - Norway)

version.description:
Released as part of TattooDad’s quest to liberate “ubertrader” material, this pro-shot DVD features the second-half of the show on a cold night in Verona. The first-half of the concert is not known to exist but intriguingly the discs are marked respectively as Act 2 and Act 3 so there is scope for this to become a 3 disc set in the future, although, as with a similar video from Toronto in 1984, we probably shouldn’t hold our collective breaths for Act 1! 
This transitional period in Bruce’s career is much maligned by some fans but this performance showcases the “Other Band” after a year on the road and the DVD reveals a very competent musical outfit. The band could never hope to engender the same emotional connection with the fans as its E-Street equivalents but no-one in Verona that night would have thought anything other than they had seen a great show; the encore in particular is excellent with “My Beautiful Reward” and “ Workin’ On the Highway” being notable highlights, although the audio on the former is very slightly out of sync. Special mention too for a very nice acoustic version of  “Thunder Road”.  
As is the norm with HOJO, the production is of high quality and the Shakespearian theme is a nice touch. The video is excellent, particularly considering its age, and contains enough audience shots to ensure it doesn’t feel sterile. Unfortunately, the audio doesn’t quite reach the same standard. HOJO cleaned up the original audio to remove the hiss which marred the overall sound. It was then remixed with audience recordings to add a little atmosphere and try to overcome the distortion on the original source, presumably as a result of the audio level being set too high when it was recorded. The extent to which the distortion is still noticeable and will irritate may depend on viewers’ equipment or audio set-up; this reviewer found it difficult to listen to at certain moments on his PC but experienced no such problems when viewing the show through the magic of television.  Whatever the case, the finished mix is a significant improvement on the original source recording and audio collectors should note it has also been made available on CD. For the purists, the original soundtrack is available as optional audio on the DVD. 
The bonus video features a performance from Oslo on the final night of the 1993 European tour. Featuring Rick LaPointe , aka roadie “Chainsaw, on guitar and lead vocals, it is, frankly, scary and shouldn’t be viewed by anyone with a weak heart- ever wanted to see Roy Bittan or Shayne Fontayne “headbanging”?! You may even be thankful next time Wolfgang Niedecken or Terrence Trent D’Arby shares the stage with Bruce!  
Whether you care for the “Other Band” or not, this is a release you should hunt down.  What are you waiting for?!

version.name: Verona 93 (Brucevideos Version)
version.description: This, "self described" basic one disc version, of an outstanding source, represents a small upgrade (if you will) compared to the HOJO release. First, the 'Lip-Sync" problems has been addressed, to a nice degree. Second, a number of technical glitches have been fixed. Third, the audio (while mostly left untouched) is fixed to remove the more obvious flaws where possible. Top that off with it being on one disc, and you have the Brucevideos version of this fantastic release. It should be noted that the video and audio were not tinkered with, other than the improvements listed. The motion menu at the start was a nice touch as well. Either version you choose, this is one DVD you can not be without!

version.name: N/A

songlist: Darkness On The Edge Of Town

version.description: This one is pretty rough.  We are being nice giving it a 4 rating.  The video is quite shaky and the audio is pretty much unlistenable(has a loud hiss all of the show).  This one is without a doubt for collectors only.

version.name: Sheffield '93

songlist: Darkness On The Edge Of Town

version.description: The second show of Bruce's two night stand in Sheffield on the Human Touch/Lucky Town tour has been circulating on VHS and DVD for several years. However, 'MrCarlos' has gone to great lengths to track down the original 8 mm master tape. Spread over 3 disc for maximum bitrate, the show is now available in the best possible quality. The filmer apparently hid the camera up the sleeve of his coat and so it is hardly surprising that the footage is very shaky. The view from the seats on the right side of the arena is a little distant and there is minimal use of the zoom. It is mostly free from crowd obstructions, but the filmer occasionally points away from the stage. The main attraction here is the picture quality, which is amazingly crisp for a '93 camcorder video. This is marred only by the frequent struggles of the auto focus to hold lock. The audio is a little thin, but very good for a camcorder source. The package is authored with simple, but functional menus. The shaky view will put off the more casual collector, but MrCarlos should be congratulated for his efforts to bring the master tape into circulation. Purely from the perspective of image quality, there aren't many HT/LT shows better than this.

version.name: N/A

songlist: Darkness On The Edge Of Town

version.description: This is in the middle of all of the 92-93 shows quality wise.  Its quite good, shot from the upper left side of the stage about half-way back.  The picture itself is very steady  the filmer zooms in on Bruce quite a bit, but also does a good job of getting wide shots of the stage.  The downfall to the picture is the gen loss, but it's not as big of a deal as some of the other shows.    The audio on this one is quite good considering the gen and its from the cam.

version.name: N/A

songlist: Darkness On The Edge Of Town

version.description: Show is shot from the close right side of the stage in the upper level.  Filmer gets a lot of great shots due to this unique angle.  Picture quality is as good as to be expected from the gen, but still very watchable.  The audio has no bass whatsoever, which gets quite annoying after a while.

version.name: N/A
version.description:
The menus and chapters on this one are interesting.  You can only the first few(4 or 5) songs from the menu, otherwise you can just skip along during the show.  DVD starts out pretty shaky, but gets much better.  It's shot from just about stage level straight back of the stage, so there are obstructions.  The audio on this one is quite muffled and pretty bass heavy.  
 Features the rare "Viva Las Vegas" that was only performed twice the whole 92-93 tour.

version.name: N/A

songlist: Darkness On The Edge Of Town

version.description:
The first thing you notice when watching this DVD is the audio.  There is only audio from the right channel, nothing from the left.  The News Special is fine.  
 The video itself is pretty good, slightly shaky at times, but not a big deal.  The entire first disc is stage shot, and the entire 2nd disc is screen shot.  There is also a "white bar" across the bottom left of the screen and a counter during the entire show.    
  The audio is slightly muffled at times during the first disc, almost as if something was over the mic on the camera.  There are also some "hissing" sounds from time to time.  
 Included on this DVD is a Spanish TV news special from 1993.  Features a interview with Bruce as well as rehersal and live pro shot footage.  
 This is a show that needs an audio dub!

version.name: N/A
version.description: Shot from the front left side of the stadium, maybe 25 rows back.  Filmer does a pretty good job considering his surroundings.  Lots of obstructions from people around him and it is quite shaky..  The audio also has as slight muffle sound to it(although not as bad as other shows), along with a small "hiss".    Overall, its pretty cool to see the show from this angle, since there are not many out there from this tour this close to the stage.  Fans of the 92-93 tour should check this one out.  It's also funny to see Roy in sunglasses and a backwards hat!

version.name: N/A

bonus: Lucky Town (Top Of The Pop's - From 3-31-93)

version.description:
Show is entirely screen shot from close to the stage.  Pictures of the screen are quite fuzzy, making this one difficult to watch.  The camera is also pretty shaky at times, and being that close to the stage, there are many obstructions.  The audio itself isnt too bad though.  Many songs cut from the end of the show.
 The bonus footage on this DVD is some of, if not the best footage of the 92-93 tour.  The stage shots from this show and the performance of "Lucky Town", filmed for the "Top Of The Pops" T.V. show on 3-31-93 in Glasgow are incredible.
  This one is worth having for the bonus footage alone.

version.name: N/A
version.description: What a great DVD this could have been.  The audio is great, the picture quality is incredible...but the picture is so shaky its very difficult to watch for long.  If I had to guess, the filmer was holding the cam(maybe in the strap on his hand?) the whole time.  It is constant jittery up and down motions that make this one tough to sit through, which is unfortunate for the otherwise great quality and angle that the filmer had.  You can tell from the screen shots cause it was hard to get a still picture.  Although in comparisson to some of the others out there, beacause of the good audio, this is a good one to throw in when you are busy around the house.

version.name: N/A

songlist: Does This Bus Stop At 82nd Street?
Goin' Down That Old Dusty Road

version.description:
Great show with lots of special guests.  This show has the "double blue standalone menus" on it, so it had been copied to a standalone record twice.  Another version from a 1st gen VHS is rumored to be out there.  The video is shaky at times, but its great to see Bruce back with his hometown boys.  The audio is also quite good, and does not seem to suffer much from the gen loss.  At the end of disc one, "Glory Days" from Letterman pops on, which looks to be like this show was originally recorded over something else.
 All in all, this is a show to have.  The concert was billed as "A Concert To Fight Hunger" in New Jersey.   The show features special guests Joe Ely, Little Steve, Clarence Clemons, The Miami Horns, and Southside Johnny.

version.name: Meadowlands Night
version.description: "A Concert to Fight Hunger" was the first of two benefit shows that concluded the "Human Touch/Lucky Town" tour. There was a parade of guest stars, including Joe Ely, Little Steven, Clarence Clemons and Southside Johnny. Bruce took advantage of their presence by including a number of their own songs, together with covers of some standard oldies. "Meadowlands Night" uses the originally circulated DVD of the concert as the source of the video. The footage is shot from high on the left side of the arena and is a little shaky. However, the picture quality is reasonably sharp (despite originating from a 3rd generation VHS copy) and there is a natural colour balance. The major improvement here is the use of the excellent Crystal Cat audience recording to dub the audio. This is a big step up from the distant camcorder sound on previous version. Sadly, the video has been re-encoded as part of the authoring process, but a high bitrate has been used to minimise the loss in quality. Another unfortunate consequence of this authoring method is the bloating of the video across three discs. The greatly improved sound makes this a more enjoyable viewing experience than the original version. However, the results could have been even better, had an untouched rip of the more recently circulated 1st gen DVD been used as the video source.

version.name: N/A

songlist: My Love Will Not Let You Down

version.description:
Great show that includes the World debut of "I Wanna Be With You.", and the tour debuts of "Atlantic City," "Sherry Darling," "Cadillac Ranch," and "This Hard Land."
 
Filmed from a tripod at the back of arena, the image is rock steady with no obstructions.  The picture quality is good and the audio is very good especially since it is from the cam.

capture.caption: Bruce and the Big Man Dancing

version.name: A Night In Vienna

songlist: Darkness on the Edge of Town

version.description: Filmed from the right side of the stage.  The picture quality is superb and the audio is very good, however it is a bit shaky, but nowhere near unwatchable shaky, which is why the DVD is only rated a 6 instead of a 8 or 7.  The first few songs have a bunch of obstructions as people keep getting in the filmer's way.  This show was the World debut of "Dollhouse."

version.name: Milwaukee Lites

songlist: My Love Will Not Let You Down

version.description: Another superb release from CTC. This time we have the complete show from Miller Park (home of baseball's Milwaukee Brewers) towards the end of the Rising Tour. The intro and menus cleverly keep with the beer theme. The video is a 2 cam mix, presented in letterboxed widescreen. One camera films the stage from the right side of the park, while the other camera on the left of the park switches between stage and screen. Picture quality is excellent, although the image is a little dark. The footage from the camera on the right is a little distant and shaky at times. An excellent audience recording has been used to dub the audio. "Local Hero" from 6 days earlier in Detroit is included as an extra, complete with velvet paintings of a Doberman and Bruce Lee! This is probably not the best of the CTC releases, but the overall production still oozes quality. Everyone should add it to their collection.

version.name: Roadie Tape
version.description: This 10 minute pro-shot tape was given to Bruce's roadies as a memento of the Tunnel of Love Tour. It was filmed at the last show of the tour in Barcelona. Over half  the run time consists of shots of members of the crew setting up the stage. This is interspersed with some brief clips from the show itself, including "Glory Days", the spoken intro to "All That Heaven Will Allow" and "Twist and Shout". The XP mode transfer comes from a 3rd or 4th generation tape and the picture quality suffers accordingly.  This one is certainly high on curiosity value, but will probably not get many repeat viewings.

version.name: N/A
version.description: Filmed from the left side of the stage the video is shaky at times and has many obstructions, which is ashame because the picture quality is very good.  The DVD also contains bonus tracks from the previous night. This footage is filmed from the right side of the stage.  Unfortunately five of the seven songs are cut.

version.name: N/A
version.description:
Shot from behind the stage on the left side, this DVD gives a different perspective than any others from the 92-93 tour.  It basically shows only Bruce and Shane the entire show.  The video itself is very good, shaky once in a while.  What hurts this show is the audio.  Its pretty tough to watch all of it, especially at the begining of disc 2 where there is a big "hiss" for the first few songs.  
This show is not widely circulated, and could seriously use an audio dub if the show is available on CD.

version.name: N/A

songlist: Darkness On The Edge Of Town
I Have Faith In These Desolate Times

version.description:
The Concert to Benefit the Kristen Ann Carr Fund.
 A lot of people have had technical  problems with this DVD.  For some it would not rip, burn, or play.  This is the first copy out of 2 tries for us to get it to work.  
 The show is filmed from the right side of the stage, almost in line with it.  Shaky at times, but some great footage of one of the last nights the "other" band was together.  Features Joe Ely as well as other guests.  Bruce and Patti dancing together at the end of Brilliant Disguise is also pretty cool.  The audio is pretty good, slightly bass heavy.

version.name: N/A

songlist: My Love Will Not Let You Down
Darkness on the Edge of Town

version.description: Filmed from the right side of the stage this show was the world premiere of "Car Wash" and the tour premiere of "Downbound Train".  The video quality is average and is shaky at times.  The audio is very good at times and below average at others.  At times the audio is only coming from one channel.  Also of note is that there is no video, just audio for most of "Darlington County" and the beginning of "Downbound Train"

version.name: Christmas in Asbury Night 3

songlist: This Time It's for Real (Southside Johnny)
It's Been a Long Time (Southside Johnny)
When Something is Wrong with My Baby (Sam Moore)
Fa Fa Fa Fa Fa / I Thank You (Sam Moore)
I Don't Want to Go Home (Southside Johnny)
What's So Funny about Peace, Love and Understandin
Santa Claus is Comin' to Town (all)

version.description: The final Holiday Show in 2003, this was the longest and arguably the best of the three. This DVD from Rabid Dog Productions features the same crystal clear picture quality and good audio as the footage from the previous night (which was later dubbed and released as "I Hate Xmas"). Unfortunately, the image is a little more unsteady and there are a few more obstructions. It is also more distant, although the filmer does use the zoom more in the second half of the show. Note that the first two songs of the show performed by the Victorious Gospel Choir are missing from the source tape.

version.name: Whatever You Want For Christmas, You Got It

songlist: This Time It's for Real (Southside Johnny)
It's Been a Long Time (Southside Johnny)
When Something is Wrong with My Baby (Sam Moore)
Fa Fa Fa Fa Fa / I Thank You (Sam Moore)
I Don't Want to Go Home (Southside Johnny)
What's So Funny about Peace, Love and Understandin
Santa Claus is Comin' to Town (all)
bonus: This Time Baby's Gone For Good (7 Dec 03)

version.description: The final Holiday Show in 2003, this was the longest and arguably the best of the three. "Whatever You Want For Christmas, You Got It" from "Ruthless Copying Records" uses the previously circulated video. The picture quality is crystal clear, although it is a little unsteady and there are a few obstructions at times. It is also fairly distant, although the filmer does use the zoom more during the second half. The two Victorious Gospel Choir songs at the start of the show and Steven's introduction that are missing from the source video have been replaced by still images. However, what makes this an outstanding upgrade is the superb dubbed audio borrowed from Crystal Cat's "Christmas Soul Night". The overall result is a much more enjoyable version of the show.

capture.caption: Santa Claus is Comin' to Town

version.name: Newcastle 96

songlist: Darkness On The Edge Of Town
Sell It And They Will Come
It's The Little Things That Count

version.description: This camcorder footage, shot from the balcony of City Hall in Newcastle, features a good head and shoulders close-up view throughout. Unfortunately, it is ruined by a partial obstruction, a continuous shuddering motion and a high generation tape source. The dark and grainy image is made worse by the single disc, low bit rate transfer to DVD. The audio is distant and muffled. Definitely one for completists only.

capture.caption: Darkness On The Edge Of Town

version.name: Philadelphia '76 + Largo '92
version.description: The Main Attraction on this disc is two songs from Philadelphia in 1976 (don't be fooled by the mislabelled Menu). The source of this footage is actually a bit of a mystery. The proximity of the filmer to the stage, the excellent quality of the image (albeit a little dark and grainy) and the soundboard audio points towards a pro-shot. However, the unsteady camera movement gives it an amateur feel. The most popular theory is a TV news crew. This is by far the best footage in circulation from the Chicken Scratch Tour era and so should be included in any respectable Springsteen DVD collection. (NB: There is a "Classic Rock Video" logo on screen throughout, but it is not as intrusive as the infamous "BLUE MOON" logo on the Toronto '84 video). The remainder of the disc is padded out with the last 90 minutes of the 25 August 1992 Landover (aka Largo) show. The picture quality is relatively clear and sharp, but the view from the left of the arena is fairly distant. The audio is reasonable, given the camcorder source.

version.name: 1987-1999 TV Appearances

songlist: MTV Unplugged w/ Melissa Etheridge (15 Feb 95)
MTV Video Awards w/ Wallflowers (4 Sep 97)

version.description: Most, if not all, of the TV appearances include on this set will be familiar to many Springsteen DVD collectors. However, the big difference is the outstanding quality throughout. All of these clips come from master recordings of the broadcasts to give superb audio and video reproduction. The highlight is undoubtedly the S.O.S. Racism footage which is far better than the versions previously circulated. This one alone makes it worthwhile getting hold of the discs. Many of the other clips are also much better than can be found elsewhere. All of the usual Letterman/Leno/Awards/Benefits/Tributes are here. Also included are all of the appearances from the '98 "Tracks" European promo tour. Pro-shot GOTJ footage from Youngstown and Madrid, as well as the two opening songs from the first US Reunion Tour show in NJ are added as "Bonus Tracks". One minor criticism, and it is a minor one, is that the clips are authored as separate Titles instead of Chapters. This means that the disc returns to the Main Menu after each clip. A "Play All" would have been nice. There are quite a few TV compilations around, but this is definitely the one to get. It is hard to imagine the quality could be any better on any future unofficial DVD releases of this material.

version.name: Munich Hotel Appearance
version.description: This remarkably candid footage was shot at the Bayerischer Hof Hotel in Munich on the night before a concert in the city. Bruce, Shane Fontayne and Sam Moore join the resident Hetti Schneider Band in the hotel ballroom at what appears to be a wedding reception. Impromptu renditions of "Lucille" and "Twist and Shout" follow. The filmer ( probably a party guest) struggles among the crowd on the dance floor to get a clear view. Consequently, the video is very shakey with many obstructions. The image is slightly out of focus and suffers from colour saturation, but the audio is reasonable for a camcorder source. On-screen captions and a narrow line of interference at the bottom of the frame are present throughout. The whole things runs for around 18 minutes. Curious stuff, but hardly essential.

version.name: The Boss in Europe 92/93
version.description: This excellent compilation documents the two European legs of the HT/LT Tour. First up is a collection of single camera pro-shot clips from Spain in May 1993. It features mostly complete performances of "Better Days", "Lucky Town" and "Born in the USA" and video of Bruce arriving at an airport and a hotel. There is also a brief clip of a soundcheck, filmed from outside the stadium perimeter fence. The Italian TV Special from 1992 begins with the full extended record version of "57 Channels", accompanied by garish visuals depicting the era. An interview and complete pro-shot performances of "Better Days", "Roll of the Dice" and "Born in the USA" from the Italian shows follow. The footage from Ghent in March 1993 is perhaps the most interesting item. It includes pro-shot footage from the soundcheck ("Lucky Town" & "I Aint Got No Home"), an interview and pro-shot footage from the show ("Better Days", "Lucky Town", "57 Channels"). The 7 minute clip of "Twist and Shout" from the impromptu Munich Hotel appearance in May 1993 is from a different source than the separate DVD listed elsewhere. It is the only amateur camcorder footage on the DVD. Finally, we have the complete performance of "Lucky Town" from Glasgow in March 1993 that was filmed by the BBC for broadcast on "Top of the Pops". Tape sources are generally 1st or 2nd generation copies. Picture quality is consistently good. Pro-shot footage from 92/93 shows is relatively scarce, so this is a worthwhile addition to any collection.

version.name: Houston '84
version.description: Circulating amateur videos from the BITUSA Tour are generally fairly poor. The older camera technology and multiple analogue copying over the years often means that only low quality tapes are available. Unfortunately, this one is no exception. It is shot with a handheld camcorder from the right side of the stage. The angle of the filmer and the constant obstructions mean that only Bruce and Clarence are visible for the majority of the time. The zoom does allow a reasonably close view. The high generation tape source has resulted in poor picture definition, although the audio quality has survived reasonably well and is fairly clear. There is an occasional rapid flickering, particularly during low light levels (usually between songs). Some tape distortion is also evident. The transfer to DVD is a bit clumsy, with no menu and "Bobby Jean" split between the two discs (with the middle portion missing). The start of "Atlantic City" is slightly trimmed and the two songs performed between "Cadillac Ranch" and "Pink Cadillac" are cut altogether. The source tape ends before the final three songs of the night. Strangely, the author did take the trouble of setting the Chapters at the start of songs. For fans of the era, the DVD is still watchable. However, the more casual collector will want to give it a miss.

version.name: Osaka '85
version.description: Like most of the amateur footage from the Born in the USA Tour, this DVD is in poor quality and incomplete. It contains the first set from the last show of the Japanese leg of the tour. Things don't start out too well. The filmer appears to be hiding the camera during "Born in the USA", hence the audio is muffled and there is no image. The sound improves slightly when the camera emerges to film the second song. The angle of the filmer to the stage and obstructions to his right means that only Bruce and Clarence are visible throughout. The picture shows relatively little generation loss, but it is badly overexposed. This is not helped by the white clothes worn by Bruce and Clarence, who often appear as little more than blurs. The audio starts to break up slightly during "Darlington County" and this gets progressively worse with audio loss of several seconds at a time during "Prove It", "Glory Days" and "Thunder Road". The camera angle starts to tip to one side during "Atlantic City" and ends up pointing at the upper level of the arena for the whole of "Working on the Highway". There are also some brief periods where horizontal lines of interference roll down the screen. The DVD has no Menu, but the Chapters are at the start of the songs. It is interesting to have the opportunity to see Bruce during one of his rare Far East shows, but only the most patient fan will be able to sit through this one in its entirety.

version.name: Tokyo '85

bonus: Born In The USA (pro shot, first part only)

version.description: Like most of the BITUSA amateur camcorder footage, this DVD from the Tokyo stand of the tour is incomplete and in poor quality. Disc 1 contains most of the first show on 10 April 1985, minus the last song of the first set and the final three song encore. The first part of the DVD is very poor indeed. It is almost impossible to pick out the individual members of the band from the blur of light on the stage. Things improve slightly from "The River" onwards, when the filmer discovers the zoom control. However, the image is still unsteady and indistinct. The audio is reasonably clear and on a par with the better audience tapes from the tour. There are many cuts, with several songs missing starts or ends (or both, in the case of "Downbound Train"). Disc 2 contains five songs from the second set of the 11 April 1985 show. This time the filmer is in a more central location and uses a tripod, but the camera is tipped to one side. The audio is also rougher than the previous night. Also included on Disc 2 is a brief excerpt of an MTV Japan Special ironically titled "One Night Stand" (there were 5 shows in Tokyo). It contains pro shot footage of the first two minutes of "Born in the USA" from 10 April. Completist might want to add this one to their collection, if only for the rare pro-shot clip. However, casual collectors should avoid it.

version.name: Bruce Springsteen: A Secret History
version.description: "Bruce Springsteen: A Secret History" is a TV documentary that was first broadcast in the UK on the BBC in 1998. It contains an in-depth interview with Bruce that takes place in an Asbury Park bar and his home recording studio. This is interspersed with mostly familiar archive and promo clips. There is also an acoustic "Born in the USA", performed specially for the  documentary film crew. The source for this "OJO Production" is a master SVHS recording of the original airing. It is a significant improvement compared to the "Rock and Roll Hall of Fame/Secret History" disc, but there is still a small amount of picture grain evident. The aspect ratio is letterboxed widescreen. A worthwhile upgrade.

version.name: Pro Shot 92/93
version.description: The design of this compilation of pro-shot footage suggests that it is a follow-up to the excellent "The Boss in Europe 92/93". In fact, some traders list the two discs as "Pro Shot 92/93 Vol 1 & 2". Unfortunately, the content and quality are significantly inferior. First up is the Red Bank Rehearsal footage, but the picture quality is much worse than the previously circulating DVD dedicated to this video. Like all of the clips here, the image is noisey, possibly due to compression loss from using a (S)VCD as the source.  Tagged onto the end is a short excerpt from a MTV news bulletin that uses footage from this performance and the interview that followed. The interview is also included here as a separate Title, but it is around 10 minutes shorter than the previously seen version. The video from Milton Keynes also suffers from the loss associated with a high generation or compressed source. The clip includes performances of "Better Days", "Lucky Town" and "Atlantic City" from the show on 22 May 1993 (it is wrongly dated as 22-6-93 on the Menu). By far the most interesting item here is the footage from Auburn Hills on 17 August 1992. It starts with a sound check that seems staged specifically for the TV news cameras that are present. After the last few lines of "Lucky Town" with the band, Bruce and Patti perform a beautifully laid back acoustic version of "Across The Borderline". Bruce then sits on the edge of the stage to be interviewed by the local reporters. Finally, we get the first three songs from the show that evening ("Red Headed Woman", "Better Days" and "Local Hero"). Once again though, the picture is fairly poor. This would be terrific stuff if it were in better quality. Overall, this one is worth picking up for the Auburn Hills footage alone, despite the fairly low picture quality.

version.name: Oakland '88
version.description: There is relatively little footage in circulation of Bruce on the Amnesty Tour, so it is interesting to be able to see this complete video of his Oakland performance. The show features a rearranged "Tunnel of Love" and an acoustic "I Ain't Got No Home". Bruce should have been in a good mood as it was his birthday. The filmer is on the field, close to the front of the stage. Inevitably, the image is very shaky and there are constant obstructions from the crowd. The age of the source tape and the subsequent generation loss results in poor picture definition. The audio is reasonably clear. If you want to fill in a gap in you Bruce DVD collection, you might be interested in this one. It should be low on the priority list for everyone else.

version.name: MSG 00 8th Night

songlist: Light Of Day/CC Rider/Jenny Jenny (start cut)

version.description: This DVD features the 8th of the 10 nights at Madison Square Garden that closed out the Reunion Tour. The many highlights of this tremendous show include "Loose Ends", "Back in Your Arms Again" and an ultra-rare performance of "Mary Queen of Arkansas". This excellent 2-cam mix is probably the best amateur video of the stand, if not the whole tour. Both sources are very steady and well filmed, although they are both at very similar angles to the stage. The audio is good considering that it comes from one of the camcorders, but a dubbed recording would have elevated this to one of the essentials. Also included on the second disc is the last part of the 3rd show in the stand. Again, it is a 2-cam mix, but this time one of the cameras shoots the screen. Audio and video quality are very similar to the main show.

version.name: Bonsoir Montreal

songlist: Darkness On The Edge Of Town
It's The Little Things That Count
Does This Bus Stop at 82nd St.?
My Best Was Never Good Enough

version.description: This nicely produced DVD from SmackDonkey features a video from the Canadian leg of the GOTJ Tour that was previously uncirculated in digital format. Like all of the Joad camcorder tapes, the image is quite dark. This makes the generation loss more evident against the black backgrounds.
