However, the filmer does a good job of keeping the handheld camera steady. The audio is fairly distant, but still reasonably clear. If you are not a fan of the GOTJ Tour, then this one will probably not convert you. For those that do have an appreciation for these solo acoustic performances, this is a worthy addition and better than many of the alternatives.

version.name: Yeah, We'll Have to Have Some Tea Sometime

songlist: Darkness On The Edge Of Town
It's The Little Things That Count
Does This Bus Stop at 82nd St.
My Best Was Never Good Enough

version.description: The GOTJ shows used subdued stage lighting which made filming difficult. Like all the other videos from the tour, the image on this DVD is very dark. However, the camera is mounted on a tripod and so it is much better than the handheld effort from the previous night. The steady camera work lifts this one above most of the other DVDs from the tour. The whole thing is expertly put together by SmackDonkey, but this will probably still only appeal to fans of Bruce's solo acoustic work.

version.name: Let's Give This One A Shot

songlist: Darkness on the Edge of Town

version.description:
The 10th night of the stand opened with the first full-band performance of "No Surrender" since July 1984.  The show is filmed from the 2nd level on the right side of the stage.  The picture quality is very good with some great close ups.  The audio dubbed by "DVD Dubbing Guy" is amazing.

The show also had the first performance of "For You" since the second rehearsal show in Asbury Park along with the World debut of "Back In Your Arms."

One of the Best DVDs from the reunion Tour.

version.name: A Night in Paris Vol.2

songlist: Darkness on the Edge of Town

version.description: Filmed from the right side of the stage on a tripod so the picture is steady as a rock and there are no obstructions.  The video quality is excellent and the audio is just as good.  This is so good, people might think it is pro-shot.  The motion menus are also very impressive.

version.name: MSG 00 7th Night
version.description: Highlights of Night Seven of the ten night MSG stand at the end of the Reunion Tour included "For You," "Downbound Train," "She's the One," "Racing in the Street" and "Night". The show opened with "Another Thin Line" for the second time. "Tenth Avenue Freeze-out" includes "My Girl" and there is a taste of the Detroit Medley with "C.C. Rider" and "Jenny Take a Ride" in the middle of "Light of Day." The show is superbly captured in this great 2-cam mix. One camera films the stage directly to the right side of Bruce, while the other camera does a good job of shooting the screen. Both cameras are on tripods and so very steady. Picture quality is very clear. A good audience recording has been used to dub the audio and the menus cheekily mimic the official LINYC DVD. There are a few audio and video glitches along the way, but nothing too serious. It's a tough call to choose between this and the following night for best amateur DVD of the stand. This one has the better audio, but the side view of the stage may detract for some people.

version.name: MSG 2000 5th Night
version.description: This was the first Garden show in 2000 without "Code of Silence", but another new song took its place - the world premiere of "Another Thin Line". Night Five also brought the tour debut of "Secret Garden," plus rarities "Something in the Night," "Sherry Darling," and a full band "Incident on 57th Street." Soozie Tyrell guested on two songs and Abby Weinberg joined in on keyboards for "Ramrod." The show is captured by a single camcorder which shoots both the stage and screen. It is very steady, with a close view of the stage and a central shot of the screen. The picture quality (from a 1st generation tape) is very clear. The dubbed audio is a little distant, but a big improvement on the original sound from the cam. Disc 2 also includes the encores from 6/26 (although it is labelled as 6/12 on the Menu). It is the same 2 cam mix used for the DVD of the full show.

version.name: MSG 00 3rd Night
version.description: Night Three of the MSG ten night stand in 2000 brought a surprise tour premier of "E Street Shuffle". All three new songs ("Code of Silence", "Further on Up the Road" and "American Skin") were also in the set. Other highlights included "Racing in the Street" and "pirit in the Night". The DVD features an excellent 2 cam mix. The cameras film the stage from different sides of the arena and so compliment each other well. The camera on the left switches to the screen towards the end of the show and does a good job of keeping the image central. Both cameras are steady and the picture quality (sourced from a 1st generation tape) is very clear. The audio is average, but perfectly listenable. Also included on Disc 2 are the encores from 6/27. It is the same 2 cam mix used on the DVD of the complete show.

version.name: MSG 00 2nd Night
version.description: The second of the ten MSG shows at the end of the Reunion Tour opened with "Further On Up the Road". There was a strong one-two punch of the other two new songs ("Code of Silence"/"American Skin") and a rare "Stand On It". The show opener is missing from this good 2 cam mix, which starts with "The Promised Land". Both cameras are rock steady. One films the stage from the left side of the arena, while the other keeps the screen in the centre of the picture. Video quality is very good, although some generation loss is noticeable. What really lets this one down is the dull and muddy audio, although it is still quite listenable. Note that the discs do not have menus, standalone or otherwise.

version.name: Hey Jude
version.description: The second night of the MSG ten show stand at the end of the Reunion Tour opened with "Further On Up the Road". There was a strong one-two punch of the other two new songs ("Code of Silence"/"American Skin") and a rare "Stand On It". "Hey Jude" from July4th1985 uses the previously circulated DVD as the video source. The show opener is missing from this good 2 cam mix, which starts instead with "The Promised Land". Both cameras are rock steady. One shoots the stage from the left side of the arena, while the other fills the frame with the big screen. Picture quality is good, although some generation loss is visible. A reasonably good audience recording has been used to replace the poor camcorder audio on the original. New menus/chapters have also been added. The overall result is a nice improvement and a worthwhile upgrade.

version.name: MSG 00 1st Night

songlist: Darkness on the Edge of Town

version.description: The opener to the final stand of the Reunion Tour. After all the fuss over "American Skin (41 Shots)", Bruce started the show with a different new song, the world premiere of "Code of Silence". â€œAmerican Skin" had its first NYC airing too and Bruce let the song speak for itself with no spoken introduction. An amazing set also included "Be True," "Roll of the Dice" and for only the second time ever, "Further On Up the Road". The show is nicely captured in this excellent single camcorder footage. It is filmed from a tripod on the right side of the arena and is mostly very steady, although the camera does wander occasionally. The sharp picture quality is the best of all the MSG 2000 DVDs and the dubbed audio is also reasonabley good. The DVDs have been nicely authored by 'DVD Dubbing Guy'.

version.name: St Louis 2000
version.description: St. Louis was an extra long show, clocking in at 26 songs and over three hours. It also saw the return of Patti after a two show absence. Set list rarities included "Rendezvous", "Brilliant Disguise" and "Spirit in the Night". This DVD contains one of the best screen shots of the Reunion Tour. The filmer keeps the screen in the centre of the image with the help of a tripod. The picture quality is good, but does show some evidence of generation loss. The audio is also fairly good, considering it is sourced from the camcorder. Unfortunately, the DVD is incomplete. Disc 1 breaks up during "Badlands" and has been filled out by rewinding the source tape back to the beginning, repeating the show as far as "Youngstown". Disc 2 starts with "Brilliant Disguise" (missing out 3 songs) and cuts to the standalone DVD recorder blue screen after "Spirit in the Night" (missing out the final 6 songs). The overall result is that the parts of the show included could have fitted onto a single disc.

version.name: Tacoma 2000

songlist: My Love Will Not Let You Down
Darkness on the Edge of Town

version.description: Patti Scialfa was absent from the band for the second night in a row, but Bruce treated the Seattle/Tacoma audience to a high-energy show. Highlights of the relatively standard set list included "My Hometown" and "Because the Night". This excellent stage shot camcorder video is one of the best of the tour. It is filmed from the balcony on the right side of the arena using a tripod and is rock steady. There are occasional obstructions from the audience, but the view is clear most of the time. The picture quality is good, although there are some signs of generation loss. A good audience tape has been used to dub the audio. The only down side is that the camera zoom isn't very powerful and so there aren't any close-ups. The menus use a split screen with static song titles on the right while a clip from the video plays on the left.

capture.caption: My Love Will Not Let You Down

version.name: Live in Tacoma ALD

songlist: My Love Will Not Let You Down
Darkness on the Edge of Town

version.description: Patti Scialfa was absent from the second Reunion Tour in a row, but Bruce treated the Seattle/Tacoma audience to a high-energy performance. Highlights of the relatively standard set list included "My Hometown" and "Because the Night". "Live in Tacoma ALD" features the same video as previous versions of the show, but this time it is transferred from a low generation source. The difference is immediately obvious, with a much cleaner image and truer colours. The solid black tones are especially noticeable. This excellent stage footage is one of the best of the tour. It is shot from the balcony on the right side of the arena using a tripod and is very steady and well filmed. There are occasional obstructions from the audience, but the view is clear most of the time. As the title suggests, the dubbed audio is taken from what is commonly referred to as the ALD recording of the show (although it is possibly an IEM recording). Unfortunately, it is a very uneven mix. The piano dominates throughout and the vocal is swamped at times. The sax and guitars are also hard to distinguish. Many collectors don't like ALD/IEM recordings because of the lack of crowd noise and this one is no exception. However, it makes an interesting alternative to the sometimes average audience tapes that are usually used to dub DVDs. The set is rounded out with basic menus that borrow the artwork from the CD-R release. "Live in Tacoma ALD" offers a significant upgrade of the picture quality and an unusual alternative to the camcorder audio on the original. It is definitely a worthwhile acquisition.

capture.caption: My Love Will Not Let You Down

version.name: Live in Tacoma Revisited

songlist: My Love Will Not Let You Down
Darkness on the Edge of Town

version.description: Patti Scialfa was absent from the second Reunion Tour in a row, but Bruce treated the Seattle/Tacoma audience to a high-energy performance. Highlights of the relatively standard set list included "My Hometown" and "Because the Night". "Live in Tacoma Revisited" from July4th1985 features the same video as older versions of the show, but this time it is transferred from a lower generation source (possibly the master). The difference is immediately obvious, with a much cleaner image and truer colours. The solid black tones are especially noticeable. This excellent stage footage is one of the best of the tour. It is shot from the balcony on the right side of the arena using a tripod and is very steady and well filmed. There are occasional obstructions from the audience, but the view is clear most of the time. This time, the dubbed audio comes from a reasonable quality audience tape. There will be a section of the collecting community that will prefer this audience recording to ALD/IEM that July4th1985 used to dub his previous release of this show. However, it might have been nice if both audio streams could have been used on the same set. The package is rounded out with basic menus that borrow their design from the original DVD artwork. "Live in Tacoma Revisited" offers a significant upgrade of the picture quality and an alternative choice of audio. Either this release or "Live in Tacoma ALD" are worthwhile additions to any collection, but you probably don't need both.

capture.caption: My Love Will Not Let You Down

version.name: Chicago 99 Second Night

songlist: Light of Day (w/ Boom Boom, start cut)

version.description: The second night in Chicago on the Reunion Tour saw Bruce draw on the "B" set list. "Don't Look Back" opened a show which also included less frequently played songs like "Trapped" and "Point Blank". The clear highlight was a rare "Something in the Night". The DVD opens with some brief footage of a ticket stub. We then get video of the whole show, shot from slightly behind Bruce on the left side of the arena. The picture quality is clear and sharp, but fairly unsteady. The filmer struggles to maintain a clear view when the crowd stands up at the end of the first set and so switches to the screen, but it is not a good angle. The audio is rather distant and hollow, with some drop-outs at the very end of the first disc. Some of the quieter moments in the show (e.g. "Point Blank") are spoiled by a talkative audience member close to the filmer. Watchable stuff, but the more casual collector can skip this one.

version.name: Chicago '95

songlist: Darkness On The Edge Of Town
It's The Little Things That Count
Does This Bus Stop At 82nd St.?
My Best Was Never Good Enough

version.description: Like most of the Joad shows, the image on this DVD is very dark. Picture definition and colour balance are reasonably good. The filmer seems to be using a tripod, but the camera is still unsteady in the vertical plane. There are also some problems with the auto focus at times. What lifts this one above the rest is the good audio. The vocal, guitar and speaking parts are all very clear. The set list includes a rare performance of "The New Timer". This is definitely one of the better GOTJ DVDs.

capture.caption: Darkness On The Edge Of Town

version.name: Napoli '97

songlist: Darkness On The Edge Of Town
It's Hard To Be A Saint In The City

version.description: This GOTJ show in Naples was one of the last of the tour. By this stage, Bruce was including more oldies in the set list and fewer tracks from the album. The subdued stage lights used for the tour means that most of the Joad DVDs are very dark. However, Bruce stands out from the black background better here than on most of the other videos. The footage is shot from a central location and there are few obstructions. The filmer seems to be using a tripod or other means to steady the camera, but the image is still unsteady at times. The picture quality is reasonably clear and the camcorder audio is better than average. The tape cuts out during the spoken intro to "he Line" and resumes half way through the point where Bruce leads the Italian crowd in a rendition of "O Sole Mio", hence missing three songs. The impromptu performance of "Thunder Road" from the theatre balcony after the show is included as an extra. This is one of the better Joad DVDs, but will still only be of interest to fans of the tour.

version.name: Nassau '92
version.description: This terrific video from a spirited HT/LT show is perhaps the best DVD of the tour to surface so far. It is shot from a camcorder on the left side of the arena, almost level with the stage. The image is clear and the colour balance is good. The audio is a little distant and muddy, but still perfectly listenable. What sets this apart from the rest of the bunch is the great camera work from by filmer. He/she does an excellent job of following the action on stage and good use is made of the zoom. There are a few obstructions and shaky sections along the way, but they don't cause too much of a distraction. Detractors from this period in Bruce's career will be forced to admit that this is enjoyable viewing. Steve Van Zandt even shows up for "Glory Days" to please the E Street Band die-hards. Note that a sequence of seven songs in the middle of the show ("Roll Of The Dice" through to "Born In The USA") that appear at the end of Disc 1 are repeated at the start of Disc 2.

version.name: N/A

songlist: Darkness On The Edge Of Town

version.description:
Filmed from a great angle, straight across the stage, the show starts out briefly shaky but gets much steadier as time goes by.  The filmer moves across the stage very well, capturing all members of the band.   Many of the songs are cut, but the video is quite good overall.  There isnt much bass, but the mids and hi's are good.  The camera work makes up for anything lacking in audio, he/she zooms in and out just the right amount   
 Along with many songs missing, some of the tracks that are there are also cut, some for merely seconds at a time.   For the casual viewer, this show may not be of great interest,  but for a 92-93 fan, its one to have.

version.name: N/A

songlist: Darkness On The Edge Of Town
Santa Claus Is Coming To Town

version.description:
The DVD starts out with a short slideshow, mainly pictures from the Born In The U.S.A. era.  
 Shot from the upper right of the arena, the filmer has a great angle for this show.  The crowd around the filmer is very active, many people jumping around and walking in front of him/her.  Therefore, the video on this one does have quite a few obstructions  The main reason for the 5 ranking is the audio.  It has no bass and is very scratchy, which makes it very difficult to sit through.      
 This one is for 92-93 fans only, unless you have an audio that you can dub it with.  Anyone???

version.name: N/A
version.description:
First show on the Tunnel Of Love Tour!  DVD is shot from straight across the stage, but only features the 2nd half of the show.  The camera work is quite shaky at times(appears to be from fans around the filmer) and the audio is nothing to rave about either.
 Cool footage at the early stage of the tour, but I'd say this one is for TOL fans only.

version.name: N/A

songlist: Darkness On The Edge Of Town

version.description:
Camera angle is interesting in this show from Detroit.  It start with the filmer on the right side of the stage, about a quarter the way back.  About halfway through, the camera cuts out, and picks up a few minutes laters on the other side of the stage.  A while later, the filmer ends up where he first started the show.  Not sure the story behind that.  
 As for the video itself, its shot very well.  The filmer has a hard time getting the close right hand side of the stage shots, due to people in the way.  
 At the start of disc 2, it seems that the audio is not the same as disc 1, does not sound as clear.
 Also included in this set are 13 songs from the previous night, 3-28-88.  Its shot from what seems to be almost the exact same area as 3-29-88.
 At the end of each disc, after the last song, there is a long period of just "snow."  Looks like it was just left to record till the VHS tape ran out.  Disc 2 is around a total of 4 hours.
 Otherwise, apart from a few shaky periods, some obstructions and song cuts, its a good TOL show.  A lower generation with dubbed audio(whcih would be very tough to do) would make this one much better.

version.name: N/A

songlist: Darkness On The Edge Of Town

bonus: Short Pro Shot Clips with "Tunnel Of Love" Video

version.description:
This version is pretty much the exact same as version 1, with one exception.  Neither disc has the "snow" at the end of it, and disc 2 has some other footage as well!  Mainly its some short pro shot clips from early days all the way up to the TOL tour.  Also has a "Tunnel Of Love" video with the counter still on the bottom, as seen in the screen shots.  
 Version 2 is the one to have.

version.name: N/A

bonus: MTV Footage From Opening Night In Worcester

version.description:
Excellent Tunnel Of Love show!  Shot from a very very unique angle, straight behind the horns at stage level.  
 The picture quality is very crisp and clear, and the angle alone provides a unique look at what goes on.  Just look at the screen shots for some examples(a very unique look at Bruce grabbing his next guitar up close).
 The only problem with the audio is on the "loud" songs.  You can hear a crackle in it, but its hardly a reason not to have this show. 
 There is also bonus footage at the end of disc 2 featuring: The Alternate Tunnel Of Love promo video and
MTV footage covering the opening show in Worcester.
 This is without a doubt one that should be added to your collection, especially if you were at this show toward the front of the stage.

version.name: 2nd Night in Hartford
version.description: The second night in Hartford is regarded by many as the best show of the Reunion Tour. The surprise opener of "Roulette" (the song's only appearance on the tour) set the stage for an amazing performance. Other notable songs in the setlist include "Brilliant Disguise", "Racing in the Street" and "Spirit in the Night". The clear highlight was a cover of "Honky Tonk Woman", which was worked into "Darlington County". This excellent camcorder footage captures the show extremely well. It is steady and well filmed with some good close-ups. The source tape looks like it is probably a 1st generation VHS copy, resulting in a good picture quality. Unfortunately, the camcorder audio is distant and dull.

version.name: Hot Hartford Nights Volume II
version.description: The second night in Hartford is regarded by many as the best show of the Reunion Tour. The surprise opener of "Roulette" (the song's only appearance on the tour) set the stage for an amazing performance. Other notable songs in the setlist include "Brilliant Disguise", "Racing in the Street" and "Spirit in the Night". The clear highlight was a cover of "Honky Tonk Woman", which was worked into "Darlington County". July4th1985 has used the video from the previously circulated DVD of the show. This excellent camcorder footage captures the show extremely well. It is steady and well filmed with some good close-ups. The source tape looks like it is probably a 1st generation VHS copy, resulting in a good picture quality. The dubbed audio comes from a very good audience recording that has been released on CD as "Hot Hartford Nights Volume 2", hence the title of this DVD release. The sound improvement compared with the original version is considerable. New Menus (borrowed from the CD artwork) have also been added. The great performance, very good video and upgraded sound combine to make this a "must have" DVD.

version.name: On the Floor in Dublin

songlist: Darkness On The Edge Of Town

version.description: "On the Floor in Dublin" features one of the best video recordings from the GOTJ Tour. It was shot by "Dublin Derek" who does a great job of keeping Bruce in the centre of the frame, although a slight "wobble" is noticable at times. The picture quality is also very good, considering the low lighting levels at these shows. The source tape was transferred to DVD by Brucevideos. July4th1985 has replaced the original camcorder audio with an excellent audience recording. The vocal is clear and up-front, even during the quieter spoken segments. New menus have also been added. Many of the GOTJ DVDs are fairly poor, so it is great to finally have one that combines good quality video and audio.

version.name: A Gift From Jakob's Dad

songlist: Only Love Can Break Your Heart (CSNY)
You Don't Miss Your Water (Don Henley)

version.description: The year was 1986 and Bruce Springsteen was cruising at the top of the pop culture consciousness. In his wake was one of the best selling albums of all time and a string of hit singles. Even President Ronald Reagan had cited "Born in the USA" as the embodiment of American values (much to Bruce's annoyance). It had been a year since the triumphant conclusion of a record breaking world-wide tour and so anticipation was high for his return to the stage. However, the new army of fans who had jumped on the BITUSA bandwagon was in for a bit of a shock. Bruce's first live show after the tour (apart from a couple of unannounced Stone Pony guest spots) featured no pounding rock anthems with the all conquering E Street Band. Instead, he opened his set at Neil Young's all-acoustic Bridge Benefit with a stark accapella version of "You Can Look, But You Better Not Touch". What followed was a mixture of stripped down versions of recent hits and lesser know (and in some cases unreleased) songs. His only accompaniment was acoustic guitar and accordion. The results were stunning. A professional film crew was there to capture the events and "Fire" was later used as a promo clip (and can be found on the official Video Anthology). The footage of Bruce's complete performance has been in circulation for many years, but the high generation of the tape meant the quality was disappointing. All that has changed with the release of "A Gift from Jakob's Dad' which uses a newly discovered 1st generation copy as its source. At last, the performance can now be done justice. Not only that, but we also finally get to see all of the other sets that night (Neil Young, Crosby/Stills/Nash & Young, Nils Lofgren, Don Henley, Tom Petty and Robin Williams). The show was spread across two tapes. The first was recorded in LP mode, while the second is in SP mode. It is actually the first tape that is in better quality, but both are showing their age. The cut between the two tapes is readily noticeable because there is an increase in noise on the image, a drop in colour definition and introduction of hiss on the audio. Unfortunately, this transition comes after the first song of Bruce's set. Despite these problems, it must be stressed that this still represents a significant upgrade from the previously circulated version. Ultimix has done a fine job of the authoring the DVD, including the well-designed menus, title sequence and bonus slide show of professional photos from both on and off stage. "A Gift From Jakob's Dad" is an instant classic. This footage can now take its rightful place along side Passaic 78, Largo 78/80 and Toronto '84 as one of the essential items in any self-respecting Springsteen DVD collection. If you haven't got your copy yet, what are you waiting for ?

version.name: You Better Not Touch

songlist: You Can Look (But You Better Not Touch)

version.description: The year was 1986 and Bruce Springsteen was cruising at the top of the pop culture consciousness. In his wake was one of the best selling albums of all time and a string of hit singles. Even President Ronald Reagan had cited "Born in the USA" as the embodiment of American values (much to Bruce's annoyance). It had been a year since the triumphant conclusion of a record breaking world-wide tour and so anticipation was high for his return to the stage. However, the new army of fans who had jumped on the BITUSA bandwagon was in for a bit of a shock. Bruce's first live show after the tour (apart from a couple of unannounced Stone Pony guest spots) featured no pounding rock anthems with the all conquering E Street Band. Instead, he opened his set at Neil Young's all-acoustic Bridge Benefit with a stark accapella version of "You Can Look, But You Better Not Touch". What followed was a mixture of stripped down versions of recent hits and lesser know (and in some cases unreleased) songs. His only accompaniment was acoustic guitar and accordion. The results were stunning. The footage of Bruce's complete performance has been in circulation for many years, but the high generation of the tape meant the quality was disappointing. All that changed with the release of "A Gift from Jakob's Dad" from Ultimix which used a newly discovered 1st generation copy as its source. The sound on "A Gift from Jakob's Dad" is slightly muffled with a faint electronic hum present in the background. DVD Dubbing Guy has therefore kept the greatly improved video of Bruce's set, but replaced the audio with a dub of the Crystal Cat CD "You Better Not Touch". This audience recording is definitely cleaner than the original video feed, but the vocal is a little hollow and distant. Which one of the two is better is largely a matter of personal taste. If you found the interference on the "A Gift from Jakob's Dad" soundtrack distracting, then you will welcome this alternative version. An attractively designed new menu completes a worthwhile effort to further improve Ultimix's excellent release.

version.name: Vote For Change Tour Finale

songlist: Jackson Browne, Bonnie Raitt, KebMo Set
REM Set (w/ Bruce on 'Man on the Moon')
Born to Run (/w Peter Buck, Mike Mills)

version.description: The Vote for Change Tour "Finale" brought many of its artists together for the first time in the President's home city. The crowd was treated to a five-hour-plus show, with Bruce and the E Street Band rocking the proceedings to a close. It was an abridged version of their standard VFC set, including the collaborations with Stipe on "Because the Night", and Fogerty on "Fortunate Son". The documentary footage prior to the show included Bruce rehearsing with Fogerty and handwriting an early setlist that started with "Devils and Dust" (which was sadly not performed). This standalone DVD recording of the Sundance Network digital satellite feed began circulating just two days after the show. It contains the entire 6-hour broadcast squeezed onto a single disc. It is therefore hardly surprising that compression artefact are readily apparent. Despite this, it is surprisingly watchable. The picture is presented in non-anamorphic widescreen. For those that can't wait for the imminent arrival of superior versions, this is an adequate stopgap.

version.name: Vote For Change Washington... 16:9 The Rebroadcast

songlist: Born to Run (/w Peter Buck, Mike Mills)

version.description: The Vote for Change Tour "Finale" brought many of its artists together for the first time in the President's home city. The crowd was treated to a five-hour-plus show, with Bruce and the E Street Band rocking the proceedings to a close. It was an abridged version of their standard VFC set, including the collaborations with Stipe on "Because the Night", and Fogerty on "Fortunate Son". The night's events were broadcast live on the Sundance Channel and with DVD recorders now commonplace, it is not surprising that there are a multitude of versions in circulation. DVD Dubbing Guy has used the Digi-TOx version the show's rebroadcast in an attempt to produce the ultimate edition. The rebroadcast was missing Fogerty's "Deja Vu...", but the sound was much improved from the original screening. The quality is simply stunning. Not only is the image free of the compression artefacts that mar some other versions, it is also presented in glorious anamorphic widescreen. From a sheer technical perspective, this is just about as good it can possibly get. "Vote For Change Washington... 16:9 The Rebroadcast" is undoubtedly the best version of the performance available. If you have a widescreen TV, this is a "must have" upgrade.

version.name: Vote For Change

songlist: Bruce Springsteen & E Street Band Set

version.description: The Vote for Change Tour "Finale" brought many of its artists together for the first time in the President's home city. The crowd was treated to a five-hour-plus show, with Bruce and the E Street Band rocking the proceedings to a close. It was an abridged version of their standard VFC set, including the collaborations with Stipe on "Because the Night", and Fogerty on "Fortunate Son". The night's events were broadcast live on the Sundance Channel and with digital recorders now commonplace, it is not surprising that there are a multitude of versions in circulation. However, there a couple of features that set this version from "Owen35" apart. Namely, the professional standard of the authoring and the wealth of material gathered together on a single dual-layer disc. Bruce's set is taken directly from the digital satellite re-broadcast and so it features the improved mix, when compared to the live showing. Unlike other versions, the Fogerty performance of "Deja  Vu..." that was deleted from the re-broadcast has been edited back in. The video has been zoomed to anamorphic widescreen and there is a choice of either a Dolby Digital or PCM soundtrack. The picture is a little dark and there is some minor blockiness in the backgrounds, but it is otherwise excellent. Also included are the pre-show and pre-Springsteen set documentaries, as well as REM's set. These retain their 4:3 aspect ratio in a 16:9 anamorphic widescreen frame. Picture quality is once again excellent, despite some minor compression artefacts. If that were not enough, the complete "Nighline" edition that featured the VFC tour and the Kerry Rally in Ohio are also included as 'Extras'. The whole thing is held together by an innovative and slick menu structure with animated transitions between sub-menus. "Vote For Change" doesn't necessarily offer the very best quality version of Bruce's performance (that honour probably goes to the "DVD Dubbing Guy" transfer), but it can't be beaten for variety of material or presentational style.

version.name: Summer's Here and the Time is Right

songlist: My Love Will Not Let You Down
Darkness On The Edge Of Town

version.description: "Summer's Here and the Time is Right" brings Night Five of the fifteen night Reunion Tour stand in NJ to DVD for the first time. The highlights of a relatively standard setlist include "Point Blank", "Racing In The Street" and "In Freehold". This single camera footage is shot from a near head-on angle. The filmer concentrates mostly on the stage, but does switch to the screen from time to time. It is fairly unsteady, with occasional obstructions and a few periods with no image at all. Despite these imperfections, it is still very enjoyable stuff. A very good audience recording has been used to dub the audio and this also enhances the enjoyment factor considerably. "My Love Will Not Let You Down" was not captured by the filmer at all and so a slide show of contemporary photographs has been used to accompany the audio for this track. A nice intro sequence (using a "vintage" visual effect) and song selection menus in Bruce's handwriting complete a very nice package. This is another quality production from Ultimix.

version.name: People Have the Power

songlist: Born to Run (w/ Mills and Buck)

version.description: "People Have the Power" was the first Vote For Change offering from the mighty production house of ScrewDevil/CTC (in association with NYC Shows). It is a tremendous multicam mix of the second show of the tour in Cleveland, Ohio (the State which proved to be pivotal in the Election). Although three different cameras are used, the footage from two of these angles was not available for the entire set. A rear view is only seen briefly at the beginning of the performance, while the excellent big screen view does not show up until the fourth song. All shots are extremely steady and unobstructed. The clarity of the video taken from the screen is excellent, while the main stage angle is a little soft and noisy (particularly in the dark tones). The combination of screen shots and stage close-ups give the illusion of pro-shot footage at times. The great video is complimented by superb audio dubbed from an IEM/audience mix which further enhances the professional feel of the production. Also included is Bruce's guest spot with REM. It is mixed from two angles to give a remarkable close-up view. Menus and the usual CTC intro sequence complete the package. This is just about as good as it get when it comes to camcorder DVDs.

version.name: Rockin Ass in Minneapolis

songlist: Born to Run (w/ Mills and Buck)
Rockin' in the Free World (w/ REM, Fogerty, Young)

version.description: "Rockin Ass in Mineapolis" from ScratchMonkey/CTC brings the Twin Cities VFC show to DVD in the form of an outstanding screen shot video. Giant plasma/LCD screens were used instead of the matrix types seen on previous Springsteen tours and the resulting clarity is amazing. There is none of the pixilation or glare from stage lights that normally affects screen shot videos. The contrast is a little low and there is a faint green hue. Nevertheless, the tripod-steady and dead centre image gives the illusion of pro-shot footage. There are even a few wide-angle shots from the arena cameramen to compliment the usual head-and-shoulders views. The dubbed audio comes from a very good audience recording. The performance is one of the best of the tour. Among many highlights, the stand-out has to be the supremely cool duet on "All Along the Watchtower" with Neil Young. Kudos should also go to ScratchMonkey for rescuing "Rockin' in the Free World" from a damaged tape. It should be noted that the first two and last two songs of the set are missing. Bonus clips of Bruce's guest spot with REM are also included. The package is held together with menus featuring a design in keeping with the "ass" theme and the transfer is 16:9 non-anamorphic widescreen. This is another clear winner from ScratchMonkey/CTC and quite possibly the best quality Bruce screen shot video period.

version.name: Rockin Ass in Mineapolis V2.0

songlist: Born to Run (w/ Mills and Buck)
Rockin' in the Free World (w/ REM, Fogerty, Young)

version.description: The original version of "Rockin Ass in Mineapolis" from ScratchMonkey/CTC brought the Twin Cities VFC show to DVD in the form of an outstanding screen shot video. The performance is one of the best of the tour. Among many highlights, the stand-out has to be the supremely cool duet on "All Along the Watchtower" with Neil Young.  Giant plasma/LCD screens were used instead of the matrix types seen on previous Springsteen tours and the resulting clarity is amazing. There is none of the pixilation or glare from stage lights that normally affects screen shot videos. The contrast is a little low and there is a faint green hue. Nevertheless, the tripod-steady and dead centre image gives the illusion of pro-shot footage. There are even a few wide-angle shots to compliment the usual head-and-shoulders views. Kudos should go to ScratchMonkey for rescuing "Rockin' in the Free World" from a damaged tape. It should be noted that the first two and last two songs of the set are missing. Bonus clips of Bruce's guest spot with REM are also included. The footage is probably the best screen shot of any Bruce show, but DVD Dubbing Guy has sought to improve upon the original release. The image has been reformatted to a 16:9 aspect ratio and encoded as anamorphic widescreen, meaning that it is no longer necessary to zoom in on the image on a widescreen TV. In addition, the original dubbed audio has been replaced using the audience recording that was released on CD by Crystal Cat. The improvements in sound are marginal and subject to personal preference. "Rockin Ass in Mineapolis V2.0" is an admirable effort to upgrade what was already an excellent release. The anamorphic widescreen is very nice, but the audio improvement is relatively small.

version.name: He's The Boss... I'm The Employee

songlist: Darkness on the Edge of Town (w/ Vedder)
Deja Vu All Over Again (w/ Fogerty)

bonus: As Long As I [Can Be With You] (w/ Scialfa)

version.description: The final night of Springsteen's VFC tour brought a unique bill to the Meadowlands, with Patti Scialfa and her band opening this homecoming show and Jackson Browne replacing REM. Bruce played in the opening set with Patti, in the second set with Browne and one of the longest headlining sets of the run. Surprise guest Eddie Vedder joined the E Street Band for a powerful trio of "No Surrender", "Darkness on the Edge of Town" and Pearl Jam's "Better Man". The encore opened with three classic CCR songs dueting with John Fogerty. However, the highlight of an emotional show had to be when Browne came out for "Racing in the Street". "He's The Boss... I'm The Employee" (a line spoken by Eddie Vedder during the show) is a terrific two cam mix. Both cameras shoot the stage at essentially the same head-on angle, but the filmers were apparently communicating and so the shots compliment each other nicely. The footage is combined with frequent transition effects, fades and split screens. Picture quality is excellent, although there is some image noise visible during the low light segments. The dubbed audio comes from a very strong audience recording. As well as Bruce's complete set, we also get his guest spots during the other performer's sets as bonus clips. Little Steven's duet with Jackson Browne on "I Am a Patriot" is also thrown in for good measure. The whole thing is authored with an intro sequence and menus. Once again, ScrewDevil has excelled with an essential release.

capture.caption: As Long As I [Can Be With You]

version.name: He's The Boss...I'm The Employee V2.0

songlist: Darkness On The Edge Of Town (with Eddie Vedder)
Deja Vu All Over Again (with John Fogerty)
Racing In The Street (with Jackson Browne)

bonus: As Long As I Can Be With You (with Scialfa)
I Am A Patriot (Little Steven and Jackson Browne)

version.description:
Taken from the exact same video as version 1, this DVD from DVD Dubbing Guy is dubbed with the Crystal Cat's  "Meadowlands Night". The menus and chapters are kept  as they were on the original Screwdevil release.  The only way you can tell the differrence is the V2.0 on the main menu(see screen shot).  The bonus tracks have also been remastered, with the exception of "Running On Empty", as they were not part of the CC release.  
 Though dubbed from the CC release, the original dubbed audio was well remastered itself.  At times, the differences in the audio is hardly distinguishable.  The main standout of the CC version is when there is talking at the mic, its much clearer.  The bass is also slightly less distorted at times.  Either way, this show in one version or another is a must have.

version.name: Philadelphia VFC

songlist: Born to Run (w/ Mills and Buck)

version.description: The Vote For Change Tour launched its opening night in Philadelphia and the highlight of Bruce's rock-driven set was a full band "Lost in the Flood". This stage-shot, single camera footage from "Smokeboyvids/NYC Bitch Committee" captures the performance to good effect. Bruce's entire set is here, together with his guest spot with REM as a bonus clip. It is well filmed and reasonably steady, with minimal obstructions. The picture quality is generally very good, although there is some noise in the dark tones on full zoom and a slight green hue. The audio is also very good, considering it comes from the camcorder. This is clearly not as polished as the multicam/dubbed DVDs that have almost become the norm, but it is very enjoyable nonetheless.

version.name: Vote For Change in Philadelphia

songlist: Born to Run (w/ Mills and Buck)

version.description: The Vote For Change Tour launched its opening night in Philadelphia and the highlight of Bruce's rock-driven set was a full band "Lost in the Flood". This stage-shot, single camera footage from "Smokeboyvid/NYC Bitch Committee" captures the performance to good effect. Bruce's entire set is here, together with his guest spot with REM as a bonus clip. It is well filmed and reasonably steady, with minimal obstructions. The picture quality is generally very good, although there is some noise in the dark tones on full zoom and a slight green hue. The audio is also very good, considering it comes from the camcorder. This is clearly not as polished as the multicam/dubbed DVDs that have almost become the norm, but it is very enjoyable nonetheless. This version with menus and chapters authored by ScrewDevil is identical in content to the standalone version.

version.name: Always Bring a Spare

songlist: Born to Run (w/ Mills and Buck)

version.description: Orlando was the last of the originally announced run of Vote For Change shows and the significance of the venue ("the scene of the crime", as Bruce puts it) was not lost on the artists. Highlights included the tour premier of "Prove It All Night" and a duet with Tracy Chapman on "My Hometown". "Always Bring a Spare" is a very nice 3 cam mix of Bruce's entire set (but not his REM guest spots) filmed by Rabid Dog/NYC Bitch Committee and authored by ScrewDevil. Two of the cameras film the stage from a similar head-on angle, while the third capture the screen. Picture quality is generally very good, although there is a fair amount of noise on the image when full zoom is used. The shots are slightly unsteady and the screen isn't quite centred. Audio is good. This isn't quite as spectacular as the Cleveland or Minnesota VFC DVD, but is still tremendous stuff that shouldn't be missed.

version.name: Scene of the Crime

songlist: Deja Vu All Over Again (w/ Fogerty)
Man on the Moon (REM w/ Springsteen)

version.description: The importance of Florida in the forthcoming Election was not lost on the artists in what was originally scheduled as the final show on the Vote For Change Tour. Bruce declared that he was "glad to be in the Sunshine State... or as I call it, the Scene of the Crime". Thus, the inspiration is drawn for the title of this alternative view of the Orlando VFC show from Rabid Dog/ScrewDevil Productions. Disc 1 opens with a shot of the stage from the back of the arena. The camerawork is very uncertain, but a different video source kicks in during the second song. This view quickly settles on the giant screen. Once locked on, the screen is held very steady and fills the frame entirely. This view is used for the vast majority of Bruce's set, with only a brief cut to the stage during John Fogerty's spot. This image quality is clean and sharp, although it is a little overexposed and colour shifted towards red. The dubbed audio is also very good, representing a noticeable improvement over the cam audio used on "Always Bring a Spare". Disc 2 contains the entire sets from both Tracey Chapman and REM, the highlight being Bruce's guest appearance on the latter's final two songs. Again, both sets are shot primarily from the screen (with the exception of "Man on the Moon"). The audio on the second disc has not been dubbed and is consequently a little distant. "Scene of the Crime" is an excellent example of how to produce a screen shot DVD. The steady full frame image and great dubbed audio make it enjoyable viewing. Don't try to choose between this and "Always Bring a Spare", just go ahead and get them both.

version.name: The Late Show

songlist: Top of the Pops ("Lucky Town", Glasgow '93)

version.description: "The Late Show" was a BBC TV arts series that ran in the 1990's (as opposed to Letterman's US chat show). The edition dedicated to Bruce that is presented here was broadcast in the UK in June 1992, just after the start of the HT/LT Tour's European leg. The show opens with a clip of "Local Hero" from the tour opener in Stockholm. This is followed by a recap of Bruce's career up to that point, told through a series of comments by UK music critics and clips from the usual stock footage (Phoenix '78, No Nukes, LA '85, etc). The remaining two-thirds of the 40 minute running time contain an interview with journalist, presenter and long time fan David Hepworth in a LA rehearsal studio. Bruce talks about life, love, music and riots. This is interspersed with clips from contemporary promos, the SNL appearance and more from the Stockholm show. The real gem though, is a run-through of "With Every Wish" in the rehearsal studio (the audio on this clip is unfortunately from a boom mike rather than the soundboard). Also included on the DVD are two MTV News segments (one of which uses footage from the '93 Red Bank Rehearsals) and the live performance of "Lucky Town" from Glasgow '93 that was shown on the following night's "Top of the Pops" . The DVD has been produced by "robertbobo" from master VHS recordings of the original broadcasts. Audio and video quality is excellent, with negligible grain visible. The menu is also noteworthy for its attractive design. "The Late Show" is a nice companion to the other tour-related BBC documentaries (e.g. the "OGWT Special"). An excellent debut from "robertbobo".

version.name: Toronto 85

songlist: Twist And Shout - Do You Love Me

version.description: This camcorder video captures Bruce's performance at the CNE Stadium in Toronto during the final stages of the BITUSA Tour. The footage is quite distant (with no zoom) and unsteady. Coupled with the low resolution of the 80's era camcorder, it is hard to discern much detail. Nevertheless, the 1st generation source tape gives a very clean image. The remastered audio makes the most of the limitations of the cam source. The usual high production values that we have come to expect from brucevideos are all here. The clean picture and reasonable audio makes this one of the better camcorder-sourced DVDs of the Tour. The fact that it is a complete show (rare for BITUSA videos) is also a bonus. However, it doesn't compare well to more modern video shoots.

version.name: Sudden Insight

songlist: Darkness On The Edge Of Town
Pilgrim In The Temple Of Love
There Will Never Be Another One For Me But You

version.description: SDonkey brings the Cincinnati show from the end of the US leg of the GOTJ Tour to DVD for the first time. This camcorder footage is reasonably steady, with some good close-up views. The picture is slightly overexposed, but at least this means that Bruce is not hidden in shadows like most of the other GOTJ videos. The picture quality suffers from a fair bit of noise in the black background and signs of occasional tape warp. However, SDonkey took great care to locate the best available source. It should be noted that the last two songs of the night were not filmed. The audio is good, despite originating from the cam. In fact, it is better than the audience tape that circulated on CD under the title of "Cincinnati 96". The discs are nicely authored with original menu designs and a suitably stark title sequence. Prior to loading the Disc 1 menu, we also get clever computer generated promos for SDonkey Productions and a certain Bruce DVD web site. A brief photomontage featuring shots of the venue is also thrown in for good measure. This is by no means the best of the GOTJ DVDs, but it is as good as we are likely to see for this particular show. GOTJ enthusiasts will be pleased to be able to add this one to their collection.

capture.caption: Pilgrim In The Temple Of Love

version.name: A Night in Paris... Vol 1

songlist: My Love Will Not Let You Down
You Can Look (But You Better Not Touch)

version.description: Like most first nights of multi-night stands, Night 1 of the two Reunion Tour shows in Paris saw a standard set-list. The main highlights were "Backstreets", "This Hard Land" and Elliot Murphy's guest spot on "Hungry Heart". This reasonably good camcorder footage was filmed from the left side of the arena. It switches periodically between the stage and the screen, although there are frequent obstructions in both cases. It is fairly unsteady and the filmer often struggles to get a clear shot. In between the problem sections, there are some very nice close-up views. The image is clean and free from interference, but the focus is a bit soft and there is a colour shift towards the red. Remastering brings the best out of the camcorder soundtrack. The now-familiar brucevideos animated menus are all here. "A Night in Paris... Vol 1" is by no means one of the best 99/00 DVDs, but it is still an enjoyable watch.

version.name: Love Rushed Inside
version.description: "Love Rushed Inside" from brucevideos Productions features the second of the two Dublin shows during the HT/LT Tour. This camcorder footage is shot from the left side of the arena. The DVD transfer is direct from the VHS-C master tape, resulting in a clear and sharp picture. The viewing angle is mainly fixed, with minimal panning and no use of the zoom. However, Bruce remains centred in the frame most of the time. Some of the songs are partially cut (including the rarely performed "Satan's Jewelled Crown") and the second half of the show is missing entirely. Audio for all of Disc 1 and the first song on Disc 2 is dubbed from an excellent audience recording. The remainder of Disc 2 (four songs) is dubbed using the superb soundboard recording that saw the light of day on the "Let's Play That Sun into the Ground" CD. So far, so good, right ? Well, now for the bad news. The video is incredibly shakey. There is a continuous oscillation of the camera that makes viewing very hard work. Motion sickness sufferers are advised to pop a Dramamine pill before attempting to watch. As usual, the trademark brucevideos animated menus are used. A simple title sequence is accompanied by the third verse from "Leap of Faith", thus revealing the inspiration for the DVD title (and disappointing those who thought they had traded for a porn flick). There is also something of a hidden "Easter Egg" on Discs 1, which contains an alternative 4.1 surround sound mix (accessible via the "Audio" button on your remote). Any DVD that is dubbed with excellent audio is always going to be welcome. With a steadier camera and more overlap between the video and the soundboard, this would have been one of the best DVDs from the tour. As it is, most viewers will find it hard to watch more than a couple of songs in one sitting (although shaking your head from side to side in sync with the camera may help). Finally, a word of caution. If you decide to trade for this DVD, take care to ensure you get the brucevideos version and not the undubbed version that is also in circulation. Without the excellent audio, it has few redeeming features and should be avoided.

version.name: Tacoma Rising

songlist: Darkness on the Edge of Town

version.description: Tacoma was just the eighth show of the Rising Tour and so the core set list was still bedding in. The Washington crowd were the first to hear the new rock reworking of "Dancing in the Dark" and the tour debut of "Ramrod". This single disc DVD contains a rock steady view of the giant screen, filling about two thirds of the frame. Image quality is very good, but there is a pronounced colour shift towards blue. A damaged segment of the screen results in a small white rectangle flickering on and off during the first few songs, but this is fairly unobtrusive. The audio is dubbed from an excellent IEM/audience mix that was uncirculated previous to this release. The audio/video synchronization is spot-on at the beginning of the show, but it drifts apart as things progress. The delay starts to become noticeable during "You're Missing", but resets after a cut which eliminates "Badlands" entirely. Unfortunately, the drift between audio and video builds up again significantly towards the end of the show. Circulation of this DVD was originally confined to "ubertrader" circles, but the version reviewed here is now widely available after being posted to usenet. Sadly, this is a standalone copy of the original authored disc. It has an auto-generated blue menu, with a non-functioning recorded image of the authored menu. The steady image and great sound makes this enjoyable viewing, at least during those tracks where the audio is in sync. Hopefully, the master version will eventually become available.

version.name: The Story of Bruce Springsteen
version.description: "The Story of Bruce Springsteen" is a 1986 documentary that was produced and broadcast by Dutch TV. It consists of a straightforward retelling of the Springsteen tale from his early days in New Jersey, through to the dizzy heights of the BITUSA world tour. The footage of Bruce himself will be familiar to most, drawing heavily on a couple of backstage interviews and the usual stock live performance footage (e.g. Phoenix '78, No Nukes). Most of the BITUSA promo videos are also included in part. There is however, a rare "blink and you'll miss it" clip that appears to show Bruce on stage in Rotterdam in 1985. Perhaps more interesting is the Dutch film crew's shots of Freehold and Asbury Park locales, together with a couple of interviews with pre-fame bandmates. There is even a somewhat bizarre segment where the infamous Ducky "Wanna Buy a Duck" Slattery sings "Show Me the Way to Go Home" while standing in a parking lot. There are burned-in Dutch subtitles during the interviews. The narration voice-over is also in Dutch, but new DVD player generated English subtitles have been created for this production (although some of these seem to have been truncated). The transfer and authoring represents the debut effort from "Racing in the Street Productions". Picture quality from the master VHS recording of the broadcast is very good, with only a little distortion on the audio. (Note also, there is a short audio drop-out around the 8 minute mark). The intro sequence, menu designs and chaptering are all very impressive. "The Story of Bruce Springsteen" is an interesting programme and a great first release from "Racing in the Street Productions". Hopefully, there is more where this one came from.

version.name: The Rarities Collection

songlist: Rolling Stone State of the Union Special ('98)
Pat King Benefit, Count Basie Theatre (1/31/98)
St. Rose of Lima Church, Freehold (11/8/96)
Rolling Stone State of the Union Special ('98)
Human Touch/Lucky Town CDs TV Commercial
Human Touch/Lucky Town CDs TV Commercial
Rolling Stone State of the Union Special ('98)
TV News Clip, Bruce at Airport ('96)

version.description: "The Rarities Collection" is a compilation of video clips, drawn primarily from TV broadcasts in the 90's. Most of the material is far from "rare", consisting of the usual award, chat and tribute show appearances that are well-known to most Springsteen DVD collectors. Thankfully though, these familiar clips are in generally excellent quality. There are actually quite a few gems here, although they are spread a bit thinly across the four discs. Perhaps the best of these is Bruce's five-song guest spot with Clarence at Tradewinds in '93. The picture quality is very good indeed, although it is unsurprisingly shaky and the audio is somewhat muffled. Also interesting are the three performances from the Tokyo GOTJ show in 1997. The rest of the truly rare clips are generally only a minute or so long each. These include various candid run-ins with TV camera crews, on stage at the Bottom Line in '92 and a Meadowlands soundcheck in '93. Also thrown in for good measure are three solo performances from E Street Band members on Letterman. The clips are in no particular order and some of them are strangely duplicated on multiple discs (albeit from different source tapes). There is only a standalone blue menu for navigation. All told, this an interesting and enjoyable collection with just enough rare footage to make it a worthwhile addition to any collection.

version.name: Kerry Rally Webcast
version.description: Bruce's first stop on the Kerry campaign trail was in Madison, Wisconsin. The somewhat rusty acoustic performance was broadcast live via the internet. Part of that webcast appears here in DVD format. Prior to the menu appearing, a clip that originally ran on the moveon.org website plays in full. It includes Bruce's "Public Service Announcement" and a very brief excerpt of "People Have the Power" from the Cleveland VFC show. The menu then loads and features a looping clip from the webcast dubbed with an acoustic "Star Spangled Banner". The webcast footage itself suffers from the low resolution, low frame rate and compression artefacts that you would expect from a video stream intended to play in a small window on a PC. Less excusable is the static and distortion on the audio that has been introduced somewhere in the capture, conversion or transfer process. Only Bruce's speech, "No Surrender" and Kerry's speech are included. The first song, "The Promised Land", is missing. It will only be the most ardent collectors who will be interested in this DVD, since the same footage taken from a TV broadcast (and hence in much better quality) is also in circulation. One to give a miss.

version.name: Flood Aid 2004

songlist: If I Should Fall Behind (solo acoustic)
Land of Hope and Dreams (solo acoustic)
Everything's Going to Work Out Right
Santa Claus is Coming to Town

version.description: After Hurricane Ivan had swept through Western Pennsylvania in September 2004, local rocker Joe Grushecky decided to stage a benefit show for the victims of the devastation. "Flood Aid 2004" took place 3 months later in the opulent surroundings of Heinz Hall, home of the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra. There were a total of eight acts on the bill, headlined by Bruce and Grushecky with his House Rockers. Bruce's first performance of the night came during the set of fellow Jersey musicians Exit 105. He reprised his cover of Dylan's "All Along the Watchtower" from the VFC tour. No Neil Young this time, but it was still a terrific performance. Bruce strolled onto the stage later in the evening to perform a 3 song solo set consisting of "If I Should Fall Behind", "Land of Hope and Dreams" (in the same acoustic arrangement as its debut at the Clearwater Festival in 2001) and "For You" (dedicated to "all the old fans"). Bruce then welcomed Grushecky and his band on stage to join him for a set that drew on both their back catalogues, together with two songs that they had penned together. Highlights from a Bruce perspective were the Chuck Berry-esque "From Small Things", a rockabilly "Johnny 99" and a stripped down "Factory". The only nod to the Yuletide season came at the end of the show when all the evening's performers took the stage for "Santa Clause is Coming to Town". A unique night like this one deserved a special treatment on DVD and ScrewDevil comes through with a magnificent presentation. This remarkable camcorder footage from "NYC Shows" is shot from head-on in front of the stage. The image is crystal clear, very steady and offers some great close-ups. A second camera source crops up towards the end of the solo set with a slightly softer focus and some minor noise, but when it reappears later it is as sharp as the primary source. The colours are rich, natural and well-balanced. Although both cameras are at a virtually identical angle, they compliment each other well by allowing switches between tight-in and wide angle views. The shots are unobstructed throughout and it is mind-boggling to imagine how this was achieved in such a small venue without being challenged. The audio is dubbed from an excellent audience recording that benefits from the great acoustics of the theatre setting. The sound is full and clear, although the lead vocals appear slightly back in the mix at times. Audio/video synchronisation is spot on. The high production values we have come to expect from ScrewDevils are present and correct, even though this title was in circulation only a couple of weeks after the show. There is a nice into-sequence with a photomontage showing the flooding, together which text describing the background to the benefit. Menu deigns are simple, but effective and give access to the Exit 105 spot as a Bonus on Disc 2. "Flood Aid 2004" raised the bar on what could be achieved with a fan-made DVD. The image clarity and camera-work are as close to pro-shot quality as you could hope to get from camcorders. This one needs to be included in any "best Bruce DVD ever" discussion.

version.name: Visions of the Ghost of New York

songlist: The Ghost Of Tom Joad (start cut)
Darkness On The Edge Of Town
It's The Little Things That Count
Does This Bus Stop at 82nd St.?

version.description: "Visions of the Ghost of New York" features Bruce's second of three shows at the Beacon Theatre in the eponymous city at the start of the GOTJ Tour. It is a Cheesesteak DVD Production in association with ScrewDevil Productions and Rockaway Rob of a NYC Bitch Film. The opening title sequence deserves a special mention all of its own. It is a hugely effective montage of morphing sepia-toned photographs overlaid with a flickering silent film effect. It sets just the right mood for the themes of the performance. The video kicks in shortly after the start of the first song. It is shot from high on the right side of the theatre. The filmer struggles to find a clear view and it is not until three songs in that the camera settles on Bruce. The image remains extremely steady for the majority of the show, but there are a few spots where the screen goes black. A few bodies briefly cross the field of view from time to time. The DVD transfer, direct from the master tape, has produced great results. It will be no surprise to those who already have a few GOTJ DVDs in their collection that the image is very dark. This is an unavoidable consequence of the subdued stage lighting. There is some noise visible in the black backgrounds, but the picture quality is significantly better than most of the other DVDs from the era. Definition is very good, with some nice colour balance during the better lit parts. The last song of the night ("My Best Was Never Good Enough") was missing from the source tape. The audio is dubbed using the "Ghosts of New York" CDR as the source, hence the DVD title. It is a strong sound, with no problem making out the spoken intros. The steady camera work, clear audio and high production values all go together to put "Visions of the Ghost of New York" among the very best of the GOTJ DVDs that are currently circulating.

dvdLocation.venue: No Surrender - Bruce Campaigns for Kerry

version.name: No Surrender - Bruce Campaigns for Kerry
version.description: "No Surrender: Bruce Campaigns for Kerry" is a comprehensive compilation of TV news footage from Bruce's appearances at the Kerry rallies in the days leading up to the November 2004 Presidential election. All four appearances followed a similar format, with a heartfelt speech on American political values sandwiched between acoustic performances of "The Promised Land" and "No Surrender". First up is the MSNBC coverage of the first rally in Madison, Wisconsin. The live broadcast of "The Promised Land" and Bruce's speech is included, together with two edited reports shown later in the day (including glimpses of "No Surrender"). This multicam video has been captured from a digital transmission for near perfect quality. Further coverage of the Madison rally in the form of raw TV camera footage is also included. This consists of a number of unedited shots from various camera angles. As well as clips from the two songs, we also get extensive shots of the crowd (one cameraman seems particularly fond of a young blonde in the front row) and video of Bruce visiting some student housing nearby. There is also a brief interview with Bruce as he boards his SUV after the show. Many of these clips are only a few seconds each and there is some repetition of the same scene from different angles, so the results are quite uneven. The bit rate is also very low, causing the image to pixilate at times. The sound comes from the camera mikes, rather than the soundboard and is hence a little muffled. Nevertheless, it makes for interesting viewing. The Columbus, Ohio rally is next, in the form of a single unedited camera angle. Again, the bit rate is a little low, leading to some minor pixilation. As well as Bruce's spot, we also see more of Kerry's speech. The Miami rally is also shown from a single unedited camera, but this time the quality is superb. The best of the bunch is probably the CSPAN coverage of the Cleveland rally on the eve of the election. Following Senator John Glenn's introduction, Bruce adds a third song ("Thunder Road") and gives a more lengthy and impassioned speech. Again, picture quality is near perfect. This excellent compilation stands as a testament to Bruce's strong beliefs regarding the state of the US in 2004. Some fans may not agree with his views, but everyone should make the effort to understand them in order to put his body of work as a whole in context. The relevance of material here has obviously dated badly due to the outcome of the election. Bruce's introduction of Kerry as "the next President of the United States of America", for instance, now rings hollow. However, this DVD plays an important role in telling the Bruce Springsteen story and so should be included in every collection.

version.name: St Paul '80
version.description: There is very little video available from "The River" era, so this cine film from the ninth show of the tour is interesting viewing. Excerpts from six non-sequential songs are included. They are shot from the left side of the stage at an angle and distance reminiscent of the Montreal film from the following year. Unfortunately, the quality is significantly worse than Montreal, due largely to the high generation of the VHS source tape (apparently videoed from a projection onto a wall). The picture definition is poor and there is a large amount of colour bleeding. The audio, although muffled, has held up much better. Despite the poor quality, it is still enjoyable to be able to see early "River" performances. This version has now been superceded by a new transfer from the master reel.

version.name: St Paul '80
version.description: This long-lost "River" footage surfaced recently as a high generation copy of a VHS video that had been shot from a projection of the Super 8 cine film onto a wall. The quality of that version was poor, but its release was successful in prompting the filmer to dig out the original reel. We now have a new transfer using the master as the source. The improvement is astounding. Gone is the colour bleeding that marred the first release. The image is now clean and sharp with more balanced and natural colours. We are still talking about film shot with primitive technology compared to today's standards, but this is as good as anyone could reasonably hope to expect. The steady footage is shot from the left side of the arena and consists of a series of incomplete clip from throughout the show. The audio is nice and clear. The rarity value, coupled with the surprisingly good quality, make this a definite "must have" for any serious Springsteen collector.

version.name: Red Bank Rehearsals
version.description: In March 1993, MTV took their cameras to the Count Basie Theatre in Red Bank, New Jersey to capture some video that could be used in news bulletins announcing the HT/LT European Tour. The "Red Bank Rehearsals" DVD uses an original SVHS promo tape as the source of the transfer. The footage is divided into two parts. The first is a lengthy interview where Bruce talks about his new musical direction and touring without the E Street Band. Picture quality is excellent, but only the most dedicated fans will manage to sit through all 40 minutes. The second part is far more interesting. It consists of "rehearsals" (most likely staged especially for the cameras) for the benefit show later that night. Five songs are worked on, including the rarely performed "Warm and Tender Love" and "Soul Driver". The picture quality is clean and sharp, but the image is a little dark and the colour balance is shifted towards blue. "Red Bank Rehearsals" was one of the first releases from brucevideos Productions. The great quality of the pro-shot rehearsal footage makes it a "must have".

version.name: Wembley '88

songlist: Ain't Got You - She's The One

version.description: The Tunnel of Love Express rolled into Wembley in the summer of 1988 for the sole show of the tour in the English capital. The highlight of an otherwise standard set list was the addition of "Love Me Tender" in the encores. This standalone DVD transfer by "Mr Carlos" uses a low generation copy of a VHS tape from "Loadsabottle Productions". It is shot from the left side of the stadium stands for a mostly clear view of the stage. It is well filmed, but a little shaky. The image is clean and the definition is good, considering the age of the tape. The image is slightly overexposed and there is a pronounced colour shift towards blue. The picture is virtually two-tone at the start of the show, but this improves when it gets dark and the stage light come up at around the mid-way point. The audio is nice and clear. The mostly unobstructed view and the clean image make this one of the better TOL camcorder-sourced DVDs.

version.name: Wembley '88

songlist: Ain't Got You - She's The One

version.description: The Tunnel of Love Express rolled into Wembley in the summer of 1988 for the sole show of the tour in the English capital. The highlight of an otherwise standard set list was the addition of "Love Me Tender" in the encores. This authored DVD by "Mr Carlos" uses his original standalone transfer of the "Loadsabottle" low generation VHS tape as its source. It is shot from the left side of the stadium stands for a mostly clear view of the stage. It is well filmed, but a little shaky. The image is slightly overexposed and there is a pronounced colour shift towards blue. The picture is virtually two-tone at the start of the show, but this improves when it gets dark and the stage light come up at around the mid-way point. The audio is nice and clear. A simple song selection menu has been added to each disc, using the same scan of CC's "Summer Night" CD cover as the background image. Unfortunately, a slight degradation of the picture quality has also been introduced somewhere in the authoring process. There is a noticeable loss of definition, resulting in a "softer" image. The mostly unobstructed view and the clean image make this one of the better TOL camcorder-sourced DVDs. However, the original standalone transfer will be preferable to most collectors instead of this version because of the slightly sharper picture quality.

version.name: Chicago '81

songlist: You Can Look, But You Better Not Touch

version.description: There is no doubt that this DVD contains a classic show from late in the "River" tour (there were only four further dates). Highlights of the set list include "Jole Blon" and "Johnny, Bye, Bye". Unfortunately, this record of the performance is in poor quality. The footage is shot from the right side of the stage and is a little unsteady with the occasional obstruction. The real killer though, is the generation loss. The picture definition has been heavily degraded and the colours have been washed out. In fact, the image is virtually black & white when the stage lights are down. The audio has survived a little better, but it is still distant and muffled. There is around 90 minutes of film here, with both the beginning and end of the show missing. Inexplicably, there is also a few minutes of the unrelated Munich hotel appearance from '93 tacked onto the end. The rare chance to see performances of "Jole Blon" and "Johnny, Bye, Bye" will be reason enough for some dedicated collectors to add this one to their library. Everyone else can safely pass.

version.name: Chicago '81

songlist: You Can Look, But You Better Not Touch

version.description: The "brucevideos" version of this cine film from a classic show at the end of the "River" tour is sourced from a lower generation tape than the previously circulated DVD. It is shot from high on the right side of the arena and is fairly unsteady with frequent obstructions. Although there is a noticeable improvement in picture definition, this is still low quality stuff. The view is distant, the contrast is low and the colours verge on monochrome at times. Remastering has improved the audio, but it is still quite indistinct. Total running time is around 90 minutes. The DVD also contains eight minutes of bonus footage from the "Darkness" show in St Paul. Again, the view is distant and the picture definition is low. However, the image is much cleaner than the main feature. Hard-core fans will be thrilled at the chance to add this rare film of performances such as "Jole Blon" and "Johnny, Bye, Bye" to their collection. Nevertheless, despite the welcome improvements, this is still hard going to watch.

version.name: Paris Amnesty '88
version.description: Paris was the second stop on the Human Rights Now! Tour and the only city that saw two shows. This DVD contains Bruce's entire set from the first night. The filmer starts by shooting the stage, but soon realises that it was going to be very difficult to maintain a clear shot. Hence the view switches to the giant screen. The filmer returns to the stage a couple of times, but the majority of the remainder is shot from the screen. It is a little unsteady, but the filmer does a reasonable job of keeping the screen in the centre of the frame and mostly avoiding the heads and arms of the crowd. The source of this transfer is obviously a high generation copy of the master tape and so there is significant degradation of the image quality. This results in dark and murky visuals. As usual, the audio has survived multiple copying better and remains fairly strong. Overall, this is a high generation source of an average screen shot video. Nevertheless, it is watchable enough. This shouldn't be high on your priority list, but it is worth getting hold of, if you get the chance.

version.name: Paris Amnesty
version.description: Paris was the second stop on the Human Rights Now! Tour and the only city that saw two shows. This DVD contains Bruce's entire set from the first night. The filmer starts by shooting the stage, but soon realises that it was going to be very difficult to maintain a clear shot from the floor of the stadium. Hence, the view switches to the giant screen. The filmer returns to the stage a couple of times, but the majority of the remainder is shot from the screen. It is a little unsteady, but the filmer does a reasonable job of keeping the screen in the centre of the frame and mostly avoiding the heads and arms of the crowd. This new DVD transfer by "Brucevideos" is taken from a 1st generation tape and is consequently a big improvement on the previously circulated version. The image is now much cleaner, but still quite dark and grainy. The audio is from the camcorder, but remastering has brought out the best in it. There are chapter stops for each song, but no menus. As long as your expectations are not too high, this is an enjoyable enough DVD.

version.name: Nick's Fat City

songlist: What Did You Do In The War?

version.description: Bruce performed six club shows with Joe Grushecky and The Houserockers in October 1995, presumably in preparation for returning to live performances before the Joad tour. The video on this DVD comes from the first of two nights at Nick's Fat City in Pittsburgh. The set list is drawn mostly from Grushecky's repertoire, but there a couple of Bruce's songs and a few rock/soul classics thrown in for good measure. The footage is shot from a high position on the left side of the club. The eagle's eye view avoids the crowd obstructions that mar most club videos, but the angle is a bit unfortunate for Joe and his developing bald spot.
