The filmer holds a reasonably steady shot throughout and the video quality is fairly clear, despite some signs of generation loss. The colour balance has shifted, giving the image a reddish/brown tint. Some black lines of interference creep into the image at around the half-way point and slowly get worse for the remainder of the running time. The high vantage point also appears to affect the quality of camcorder audio, resulting in a hollow and distant sound. The reasonably good video quality and unobstructed view make this one of the better club appearance videos, but it is a shame about the poor audio.

capture.caption: What Did You Do In The War?

version.name: Storytellers
version.description: VH1's "Storytellers" is an occasion series that allows songwriters to perform their music and tell the stories behind the songs. Bruce used the opportunity to appear on the show to promote the release of "Devils and Dust". Bruce's performance in the intimate surroundings of Red Bank's Two River Theatre was by all accounts a very special evening. He was in turn charming, funny and interesting as he performed solo versions of 8 songs and then proceeded to break them down line by line. His explanations provided some fascinating insight, but were also as poetic and obtuse as the lyrics themselves at times. The show was cut down to just 43 minutes for its premier broadcast just 3 days before the album hit the shelves. The editing is frustrating, with the post-song descriptions overlaid and interspersed with the songs themselves. Some songs have verses cut and two weren't used at all. NeonKaiser's transfer to DVD was in circulation via the internet just a few hours after the show had aired. Understandably, there has been minimal authoring. Despite the running time, the quality has not been maximised by using XP mode. Instead, half the capacity of the disc is left unused. Picture and sound quality are both generally excellent, but some minor noise in the image and low contrast are noticeable. This version of the broadcast is an admirable effort to make it available quickly, but better presentations of the material will surely follow.

version.name: Stories From an Only Son
version.description:
VH1's "Storytellers" is an occasion series that allows songwriters to perform their music and tell the stories behind the songs. Bruce used the opportunity to appear on the show to promote the release of his new album, "Devils and Dust".
It was by all accounts a very special evening. Bruce was charming, funny and interesting as he performed solo versions of 8 songs and then proceeded to deconstruct them line by line. His explanations provided some fascinating insight, but were also as poetic and ambiguous as the lyrics themselves at times. The show was cut down to just 43 minutes for its premier broadcast and subsequently extended to 53 minutes with the restoration of "Waitin' on a Sunny Day". Unfortunately, the editing is frustrating, with the post-song descriptions overlaid and interspersed with the songs themselves. Predictably for a TV broadcast, multiple versions are now in circulation. However, Digi-TOx and DVD Dubbing Guy have joined forces to produce the ultimate version of the show. "Stories from an Only Son" is a two-disc set with identical video content on both discs. It is an excellent digital capture of the extended cut with virtually no perceptible compression artefacts. It has been cropped to a 16:9 aspect ratio (eliminating only the black bars seen on other versions) and encoded in anamorphic widescreen. The results are truly superb. The only difference between the two discs is the audio tracks. Disc 1 contains an uncompressed PCM stereo stream, while Disc 2 has a DTS surround-sound mix. Both sound excellent if you have the right equipment to gain the full benefit. "Stories from an Only Son" is a "must have" upgrade for widescreen TV owners. A Home Cinema sound system will further enhance the experience. However, you might want to stick with your earlier versions if you only have a standard TV set.

version.name: Storytellers Uncut

songlist: Jesus Was an Only Son (two takes)

version.description: VH1's "Storytellers" is an occasional TV series that allows songwriters to perform their music and tell the stories behind the songs. Bruce used the opportunity to appear on the show to promote the release of his new album, "Devils and Dust". It was a very special evening in front of an invited audience of just 300 that had been shoe-horned into the tiny Red Bank theatre. Bruce was charming, funny and poignant as he performed solo versions of 8 songs and then proceeded to deconstruct them line by line. His candid stories and explanations provided some fascinating insight, but were also as poetic and ambiguous as the lyrics themselves at times. The setlist included the world premiers of two songs from the new album. Other highlights included a duet with Patti on "Brilliant Disguise" and a Smokey Robinson imitation on "Waitin' on a Sunny Day". The biggest standout though, was a devastatingly beautiful acoustic arrangement of "The Rising" that brought a standing ovation both times it was performed. The 2 hour show was cut down to just 43 minutes for its premier broadcast and subsequently extended to 53 minutes with the restoration of "Waitin' on a Sunny Day". Unfortunately, the editing of these versions is frustrating, with the post-song descriptions overlaid and interspersed with the songs themselves. Fortunately, we now get to see the entire performance in its unedited glory. It's all here, including the two previously unseen songs ("Nebraska" and "Thunder Road") and the alternate takes (the unused first take of "The Rising" alone is essential viewing). The only thing missing is the Q & A session with the audience that followed the main show. The source of this DVD set appears to be a first generation digital copy. It is hard to find anything to fault with the picture and sound, which are virtually broadcast quality. The image is non-anamorphic widescreen and mercifully free of any logos or other on-screen graphics. The video does drop out for around 10 seconds between takes of "The Rising", but it resumes where it left off, so nothing is missed. The source tape has been transferred to DVD using a standalone recorder in XP Mode across three discs. This means that the third disc runs for just 17 minutes, but it is justified to retain maximum quality. Disc 2 and 3 appear to have errors which mean they fail to load in many home DVD players, but this can usually be overcome by pressing "Stop" and then "Play". "Storytellers Uncut" is an exceptionally good presentation of one of the most important and fascinating performances of Bruce's career. It's simply a "must have".

version.name: Storytellers Uncut
version.description: VH1's "Storytellers" is an occasional TV series that allows songwriters to perform their music and tell the stories behind the songs. Bruce used the opportunity to appear on the show to promote the release of his new album, "Devils and Dust". The setlist included the world premiers of two songs from the new album. Other highlights included a duet with Patti on "Brilliant Disguise" and a Smokey Robinson imitation on "Waitin' on a Sunny Day". The biggest standout though, was a devastatingly beautiful acoustic arrangement of "The Rising" that brought a standing ovation both times it was performed. It's all here, including the two previously unseen songs ("Nebraska" and "Thunder Road") and the alternate takes (the unused first take of "The Rising" alone is essential viewing). The only thing missing is the Q & A session with the audience that followed the main show. The source of this DVD set appears to be a first generation digital copy. It is hard to find anything to fault with the picture and sound, which are virtually broadcast quality. The image is non-anamorphic widescreen and mercifully free of any logos or other on-screen graphics. The video does drop out for around 10 seconds between takes of "The Rising", but it resumes where it left off, so nothing is missed. "Hodgo" has added simple song selection menus to the original standalone transfer by using artwork borrowed from GChord. The video remains untouched and so the superb quality is retained. Disc 3 (only 17 minutes on the original release) has been filled out by lifting material from the "Devils & Dust TV Appearances" DVD. Given that the original version fails to load properly on many players, this authored version is particularly welcome.

version.name: Patti Scialfa in Concert

songlist: As Long As I (Can Be With You) (Bruce on guitar)

version.description: As part of the promotional effort for her second album "23rd Street Lullaby", Patti Scialfa shot a pay-per-view special for satellite broadcaster DirecTV. It contained a compilation of performances from two shows at "The Hit Factory" studios in front of an invited audience. Interwoven with the songs are interviews with Patti and footage from back-stage rehearsals. The band put together especially for the tapings included E Streeters Nils Lofgren and Suzie Tyrell. And yes, there is Bruce content too. Ms Scialfa's other half joins the band on guitar for two songs, but does not contribute any vocals. The image quality on this DVD standalone transfer is slightly soft, indicating the source was a VHS tape of the broadcast rather than a digital recording. Nevertheless, picture and sound are both very good. There are some pleasant performances here, but Bruce's limited participation means that you will need to be appreciative of Patti's music to want this one in your collection.

capture.caption: As Long As I (Can Be With You)

version.name: Patti on TV
version.description: "Patti on TV" is a compilation of the chat show appearances that Patti made during June 2004 to plug her second CD "23rd Street Lullaby". Most of the clips follow the same format, namely some fairly vacuous chat about juggling the duties of motherhood and rock stardom, followed by a performance of one or more songs from the album (predominantly the title track). There is just enough Bruce content to warrant inclusion in the DVD Index. Ms Scialfa's other half is seen looking on proudly from the wings during the "Today" spot. However, his main contribution is an interview for the "CBS Sunday Morning" profile on the happy couple. There is minimal added production value to be found in this standalone transfer, but picture and sound quality are generally excellent throughout. This is essential stuff for Patti fans, while the more casual Bruce DVD collector will find just enough of interest in the "CBS Sunday Morning" segment to make it worthwhile seeking this one out.

version.name: Devils & Dust TV Appearances
version.description: Stan Goldstein has gathered together all of Bruce's TV appearances during the week of the "Devils & Dust" album release in April 2005 for this single disc compilation. First up is the VH1 Classic extended version of "Storytellers". This is identical to the original version, except for the Smokey Robinson style performance of "Waitin' on a Sunny Day" that has been tagged onto the end. Next is a profile that aired on NBC's "Dateline". Bruce is seen chatting inside Asbury Park's Paramount Theatre and strolling on the boardwalk outside with interviewer Matt Lauer. More of the same interview is used for the two "Today Show" segments (from consecutive mornings), which also includes exclusive performances of "Devils & Dust" and "All I'm Thinking About". Also included are two brief clips of an interview that VH1 conducted at the time of the "Storytellers" filming. Closing out the DVD is the stylish promo video for the "Devils & Dust" single that was shot in an empty Paramount Theatre. The recordings have been transferred to DVD using a standalone recorder, so there is little in the way of menu functionality. Nevertheless, picture and sound are generally excellent (apart from some very minor compression artefacts in the dark backgrounds). This material will probably be given a better presentation at a later date, but this compilation represents at welcome opportunity to see these TV appearances in excellent quality soon after they debuted.

version.name: Soothing the Desert Heat

songlist: My Best Was Never Good Enough

version.description: The Devils & Dust show in Glendale (near Phoenix) was just the third of the tour and the first to be held in the half-arena configuration. The attentive crowd were rewarded with the world premiere of "All I'm Thinkin' About" (the last song from the new album to be played live) and an ultra-rare "Book of Dreams" (not performed since 1992's "Plugged"). Other highlights for fans of classic Springsteen material included "For You", "Highway Patrolman" and "Racing in the Streets". Part-time Arizona resident Nils Lofgren made a surprise guest appearance for "This Hard Land". This excellent camcorder footage was filmed from the left and towards the back of the arena. The angle gives a side view of Bruce while he is centre-stage, but a great head-on shot while he is seated at the piano. It is generally very steady and offers some great close-ups. Picture quality is very good, but there is quite a bit of digital noise visible in the dark tones. The DVDs have been created by direct transfer of the master tape using a standalone recorder. Hence, there are no authored menus, song chapters or dubbing. Although the audio comes from the camcorder, it is remarkably clear and strong. There is some echo on the vocal, but this is probably unavoidable due to the acoustics of the venue. Despite the lack of added production value, this is an extremely enjoyable set.

version.name: I've Been Out in the Desert

songlist: My Best Was Never Good Enough

version.description: The Devils & Dust show in Glendale (near Phoenix) was just the third of the tour and the first to be held in the half-arena configuration. The attentive crowd were rewarded with the world premiere of "All I'm Thinkin' About" (the last song from the new album to be played live) and an ultra-rare "Book of Dreams" (not performed since 1992's "Plugged"). Other highlights for fans of classic Springsteen material included "For You", "Highway Patrolman" and "Racing in the Streets". Part-time Arizona resident Nils Lofgren made a surprise guest appearance for "This Hard Land". ScrewDevil has used the previously circulated video of the show from SmokeyBoyVids as the source for "I've Been Out in the Desert". This excellent camcorder footage was filmed from the left and towards the back of the arena. The angle gives a side view of Bruce while he is centre-stage, but a great head-on shot while he is seated at the piano. It is reasonably steady and offers some great close-ups. Picture quality is very good, but there is quite a bit of digital noise visible in the dark tones. The camcorder audio has been replaced by a good audience tape. It gives a fuller sound with less extraneous noise, but the vocal isn't as prominent as the original. The degree of improvement is largely subjective. The set features attractively designed menus and an effective title sequence that uses a photomontage of desert landscapes accompanied by the song that inspired the DVD's title - "Further On (Up the Road)". The added production value and alternative audio makes "I've Been Out in the Desert" another winner from ScrewDevil Productions.

version.name: Living in the Light

songlist: My Best Was Never Good Enough

version.description: The "Devils & Dust" tour's official opening took place at the Fox Theatre in Detroit on the eve of the album's release. It soon became apparent that this was no "Tom Joad II". There was a wider variety of musical styles, ranging from the bizarre use of the harmonica on "Reason to Believe" to a number of piano spots between the acoustic guitar numbers. Bruce debuted 10 of the 12 cuts from the new album, mixed with classic oldies like "For You" and "Racing in the Streets". "The Rising" album was also well represented with four songs. Other highlights included "Part Man, Part Monkey" as a commentary on Bush's fundamentalist views and a return to the original solo piano arrangement of "Real World". The show gets the full-blown ScrewDevil treatment on "Living in the Light", using footage from NYC Shows and Fig. The beautifully designed menus give way to an apt title sequence in the style of an old B&W western. The main source in the 3 cam mix is a head-on shot from waist height. The camera slowly bobs up and down throughout, but Bruce is kept in the centre of the view. This is blended with a great screen shot that is very steady and fills the frame. There is also an alternate stage angle. Picture quality is generally very good and thankfully far superior to the videos from the last solo tour. However, there is quite a lot of digital noise present in the image, particularly in the dark backgrounds. The dubbed audio gives a clear and full sound and is perfectly synchronised. "Living in the Light" doesn't fail to live up to the high standards we have come to expect from a ScrewDevil production. Go get your copy now.

version.name: Attack of the Relatives
version.description: Bruce's first Devils & Dust show proper in his home state of New Jersey was the 13th of the tour and it proved to be unlucky for some. A bank of speakers blew out after around 25 minutes and one section of the crowd was left without sound. Disgruntled fans started shouting out "We can't hear you!", but Bruce thought he was being heckled and gave them his best "STFU". As the chanting continued, Bruce offered to show them the door. The problem was eventually fixed and Bruce was told the reason for the ruckus. His mood softened and he joked that it was members of his family that had caused the disturbance. He said the show should be called "Attack of the Relatives". Hence, the title of this DVD release was instantly coined. The tour debut of "The Wish" was the highlight of a set list with few surprises. Other notable performances were "Paradise" and the new spaghetti western arrangement of "I'm On Fire". This excellent set from LAM Video and Cheesesteak Productions features an impressive two cam mix. One camera is high on the left side of the arena, while the other is in a rear-centre location. The picture quality from the side view (which becomes head-on when Bruce is at the piano) suffers from quite a bit of digital noise and a faint band that rolls horizontally across the screen. The central view is much better, with excellent definition and rich colours. Steadiness is good for hand-held filming and both angles provide some very nice close-ups shots. There are a couple of brief spots (mostly between songs) where there is no video at all, but these are covered by either freeze-frame or slide-show stills. The perfectly synchronised dubbed audio is taken from the "JB" audience tape. The vocal has quite a bit of echo and you might need to turn up the volume to follow some of the spoken intros, but this is probably an unavoidable consequence of recording in an arena. "Attack of the Relatives" is a quality production and a nice record of a memorable night.

version.name: The LA Touch

songlist: Waitin' on a Sunny Day (w/ Nils Lofgren)

version.description: The second night of a spectacular two-night stand in L.A. saw "Devils & Dust" bumped down to the third spot to make way for the tour debut of "My Beautiful Reward" at the top of the show. Many more tour debuts followed, including "Empty Sky", "The Line" and a new solo piano arrangement of "The River". "All The Way Home" was the last song from the new album to be played on the tour and "If I Should Fall Behind" was played on guitar instead of piano like the previous evening. Nils Lofgren showed up for the second time on the tour, this time to help out on an extended version of "Waitin' on a Sunny Day". The requisite gathering of Hollywood celebs in attendance seemed to approve of a tremendous show. "The LA Touch" contains a reasonably good screen-shot video of the performance. It starts during the final notes of the show opener and it is not until the third song that the filmer is able to zoom in on the screen. Once he does, he manages to hold the shot fairly steady and fill the majority of the frame. The screens at the "Devils & Dust" shows were not the big high-definition displays seen at recent arena and stadium appearances. Consequently, the image quality is not as good as the best screen shot videos from previous tours. The DVD uses the original cam audio, which is fairly distant but acceptably clear. Unfortunately, it is only present in one channel of the stereo soundtrack. The master tape has strangely been transferred as three separate titles on the first disc and two on the second, so the show returns to the main menu at the end of each section. The problems with the audio and claustrophobia of a screen shot which exclusively focuses on Bruce's face or hands means that "The LA Touch" will be of limited appeal.

version.name: 8MM

songlist: It's Hard To Be A Saint In The City
It's Hard To Be A Saint In The City
Met Sports Ctr, Bloomington, Minn 10th June1978

version.description:
General consensus is those lucky enough to catch Bruce between 1975 and 1981 caught a performer at the peak of his powers. This compilation of clips, some in circulation for the first time, supports this consensus and compliments the official release of the first show at Hammersmith Odeon in 1975 and bootlegs of shows in Landover during 1978 and 1980. Of particular note is the footage from 1976 and 1977, documenting a period very underrepresented in terms of video.
  As the artwork notes, 8mm is a cartridge based motion picture film format that allows approximately 3 minutes 20 seconds of continuous filming. As a result, the vast majority of songs included on these DVDs are incomplete and many are only brief snippets. This leads to a compilation that is like a curate’s egg: something which is part good, part bad; a mixed bag. Some of the 8mm footage was silent and although efforts were made to dub the footage, the audio does not always match the video throughout the compilation, particularly on the first DVD. The audio has been used, it would seem, to indicate what song is most likely being played. Unfortunately, this leads to a very unsatisfying experience, although this is balanced by the outstanding work in other areas, particularly the excellent footage from New Year’s Eve in December 1980 which is dubbed in the traditional sense.
  This is an interesting compilation and a good historical document for hardcore fans. That said, it is unlikely to get too many repeat viewings because of the issues highlighted above and won’t make it on to many “must-have lists”.

version.name: Bologna 05
version.description:
The first night of a three show "Devils & Dust" jaunt through Italy saw Bruce returning once again to the "Nebraska" album for the tour premier of "My Father's House". The other notable variation in the running order was at triple shot at the piano, with "Paradise" into "Real World" into "My Hometown". This excellent camcorder footage is shot from high on the left of the theatre. The side angle turns into a great head-on view when Bruce is seated for the piano numbers. The pans as Bruce moves position between songs are a little jagged, but otherwise the vast majority of the video is perfectly steady. However, the filmer is forced to switch from the tripod to handheld when the crowd stands for the encores. The picture is bright and sharp and although there is some digital noise evident, it is less prominent than most of the other videos from the tour. There aren't many close-up shots because the filmer avoids full zoom to minimise pixilation, but this is extremely good stuff. The camcorder sound is slightly distant, but still very clear. There is quite a bit of echo on the vocal, but this is common to most recordings from the tour. Picky viewers might notice a slight audio delay, but this doesn't really cause a distraction. Not only is this one of the best D & D audience shot videos of the tour, it stands proudly as one of the best of any tour.

(Note: The audio is encode as MPEG1, which may cause problems with some standalone players, particularly the JVC brand)

version.name: With the Devil Snappin' at My Heels

songlist: Land of Hope and Dreams (start cut)

version.description: The first night of a three show "Devils & Dust" jaunt through Italy saw Bruce returning once again to the "Nebraska" album for the tour premier of "My Father's House". The other notable variation in the running order was at triple shot at the piano, with "Paradise" into â€˜Real World" into "My Hometown". "With the Devil Snappin' at My Heels" from SDonkey Productions features a new video of the show from "Bazzy". The handheld footage is shot from the back of the theatre and so the view is quite distant. There is constant camera movement and jitter, which makes viewing hard going at times. The image is clean, but it lacks definition and there is some occasional loss of focus. There are some brief cuts between some songs and the encores start shortly after the beginning of "Land of Hope and Dreams", thus missing "Ramrod". SDonkey has done a very good job authoring the set, with a clever animated title sequence and nicely designed menus. However, the real attraction is the excellent dubbed audio, which gives a clear and full sound. "With the Devil Snappin' at My Heels" can't come close to matching the excellent "Luke" video of the show (probably the best of the tour), but great production and dubbed audio make this an interesting alternative.

version.name: Bologna 05
version.description: The first night of a three show "Devils & Dust" jaunt through Italy saw Bruce reaching back once again to the "Nebraska" album for the tour premier of "My Father's House". The other notable variation in the set was at triple shot at the piano, with "Paradise" into "Real World" into "My Hometown". 'DVD Dubbing Guy' has used the excellent video from the 'Luke' version for his upgrade of the show. It is shot from high on the left of the theatre, but the side angle turns into a great head-on view for the piano numbers. The pans as Bruce moves position between songs are a little jagged, but otherwise the vast majority of the video is perfectly steady. However, the filmer is forced to switch from the tripod to handheld when the crowd stands for the encores. The picture is very sharp, but there is quite a bit of digital noise evident in the dark tones. There aren't many close-up shots because the filmer avoids full zoom to minimise pixilation, but this is extremely good stuff. The original camcorder audio has been replaced with the 'Kokomo' audience tape, resulting in a significant improvement in the sound quality. The simple 'Luke' menus have been reused, with the addition of text to identify it as the "DVD Dubbing Guy" version. "Bologna 05" is probably the best video footage from the "Devils & Dust" tour, so a new version with improved sound is very welcome.

version.name: Brussels 05

songlist: My Best Was Never Good Enough

version.description: The first "Devils & Dust" show in Continental Europe saw "Part Man, Part Monkey" dropped from the line up for the first time. The Gretsch guitar was used instead for the tour premier of "State Trooper", bringing the total of "Nebraska" songs to three. Piano versions of "Tougher Than the Rest", "Real World" and "Racing in the Street" meant that the respectful Brussels crowd were treated to a good set. This handheld camcorder footage is shot from a central position at the back of the theatre, giving a somewhat distant view. Unfortunately, the camerawork is very poor. It is extremely shaky, with Bruce frequently shooting out of the frame altogether. There are constant switches between stage and screen and the zoom is used excessively. The image is clean, but definition is low and the colours seem washed out. All in all, the video is near unwatchable. To make matters worse, authoring errors make disc navigation impossible on most standalone players. Disc 2 is particularly bad, with second half of the show split among four disc Titles in the wrong order. The only redeeming feature is the audio, which is good for a camcorder. The shaky video and broken menus mean that only collectors who must have every available DVD from the tour will want this one.

version.name: Live in Brussels
version.description: The first "Devils & Dust" show in Continental Europe saw "Part Man, Part Monkey" dropped from the line up for the first time. The Gretsch guitar was used instead for the tour premier of "State Trooper", bringing the total of "Nebraska" songs to three. Piano versions of "Tougher Than the Rest", "Real World" and "Racing in the Street" meant that the respectful Brussels crowd were treated to a good set. "Live in Brussels" from 'It's Boss Time' features a new video of the show containing just six songs at the keyboard and "Ramrod", giving a running time of 42 minutes. It is shot with a reasonably steady handheld camcorder from the far left corner of the theatre, resulting in a fairly distant view. The filmer constantly switches from stage to screen, but the screen only occupies around half the frame. The picture quality is very clean, but the focus is forever drifting and so the image is often blurred. The audio is average for a camcorder source. The DVD begins with a very brief title sequence, but there are no menus or even chapter stops. Unusually, the disc had been authored in 16:9 anamorphic widescreen. The widescreen aspect ratio is a curiosity, but there is otherwise very little here to recommend.

version.name: Milan 05
version.description: The last night of the three show mini-tour of Italy fell on the eve of Bruce's 14th wedding anniversary to Patti. Romance was definitely in the air, with three consecutive tales of separated lovers ("Tougher Than the Rest", the tour premier of "Open All Night" and "All the Way Home"). "Brilliant Disguise" and "Lucky Town" both stayed from the night before, but the best spot in an excellent setlist was the piano combo of "Wreck on the Highway" leading into the tour premier of "Lost in the Flood". This excellent camcorder footage is shot from high on the right of the theatre. This gives a side view of Bruce while he is centre stage, but a back view while he is seated at the piano. The camera appears to be mounted on a tripod, but frequent angle adjustment makes the view quite shaky at times. The filmer also tends to be overenthusiastic with the zoom, but the shot is rock steady on the occasions when the camera is left alone. Image quality is mostly very sharp, except for some pixilation on the extreme close-ups. The colours are rich and the dark backgrounds are pleasingly solid. Inexplicably, there are short cuts between most songs and this can become mildly irritating. Audio from the camcorder is very clear, although a little heavy on the echo. The discs are authored with simple yet attractive menu designs. It should be noted that both discs have a minor error which means that one song on each can't be selected. The excellent picture quality makes Milan '05 one of the best videos from the first European leg of the Devils & Dust tour. It is just a shame the camera angle wasn't held steadier more often. (Note: The audio is encode as MPEG1, which may cause problems with some standalone players, particularly the JVC brand).

version.name: Wreck in Milan
version.description: The last night of the three show mini-tour of Italy fell on the eve of Bruce's 14th wedding anniversary to Patti. Romance was definitely in the air, with three consecutive tales of separated lovers ("Tougher Than the Rest", the tour premier of "Open All Night" and "All the Way Home"). "Brilliant Disguise" and "Lucky Town" both stayed from the night before, but the best spot in an excellent setlist was the piano combo of "Wreck on the Highway" leading into the tour premier of "Lost in the Flood". "Wreck in Milan" from 'Tony Killerjoe' is taken from an entirely different source than the first DVD of this show from 'Luke'. This one is shot with a handheld camera from relatively low on the left side of the theatre. The filmer does an admirable job of keeping a reasonably steady and centred view, but there is constant camera movement throughout. The image is a little overexposed, but otherwise sharp and mercifully free of pixilation or noise. The audio is very good, given that it comes from the camcorder. So far, so good. However, there seems to be a problem with the aspect ratio. The video has been transferred at a resolution of PAL 704x576 rather than the more common PAL 720x576 and it appears that it may even have been shot in widescreen mode. Whatever the cause, the result is a slightly squashed Bruce when viewed on a native 4:3 display (e.g. a standard TV set). Things look more natural if stretched on a 16:9 display. The authored menus also add to the wackiness, with separate sub-menus for each track instead of a single song selection sub-menu. "Wreck in Milan" is a reasonable alternative to the original release, but if you only want one version of the show, then stick to the 'Luke' version.

version.name: Berlin 05
version.description: After being rescheduled, Berlin became the final stop on the first European leg of the Devils and Dust tour. The setlist featured nine songs not played the night before in Hamburg, including tour premieres of "Sinaloa Cowboys" and "Hungry Heart" (which featured the obligatory German guest appearance by Wolfgang Niedecken). "Adam Raised a Cain" was reprised from Stockholm as the opener and "Spare Parts" was retained after its tour debut the previous evening. This DVD from "Sunny Day" is certainly one of the stranger presentations of any show from the tour. It is authored as 9 separate Titles, each of which returns the viewer to the animated main menu upon completion. The first of these is named "Speech" and consists of several fragments of spoken introductions followed by the first line or two of the proceeding song from throughout the show. The remainder of the Titles are individual songs which are (mostly) complete. The handheld footage is shot from a central location at the back of the theatre. The filmer frequently switches his view from stage to screen (or both at the same time in some cases). Bruce only fills around a half of the frame or less during the screen views and the stage views are mostly very distant. The angle also tends to wander around quite a bit. The picture quality is generally good, but the auto focus occasionally struggles and some shots are overexposed. The camcorder audio is reasonable, but quite hollow and echo laden. This might serve as a nice memento for members of the audience, but casual collectors can safely ignore.

version.name: The Final Show
version.description: After being rescheduled, Berlin became the final stop on the European leg of the Devils and Dust tour. The setlist featured nine songs not played the night before in Hamburg, including tour premieres of "Sinaloa Cowboys" and "Hungry Heart" (which featured the obligatory German guest appearance by Wolfgang Niedecken). "Adam Raised a Cain" was reprised from Stockholm as the opener and "Spare Parts" was retained after its tour debut the previous evening. The first DVD from the show to circulate was an incomplete collection of fragmented clips, so it is nice to finally get the complete performance. This footage (a completely different source than the first) is shot from a tripod on the left side of the arena. There are some lengthy periods of perfectly steady close-up views. Unfortunately, the shot gets extremely shaky whenever the filmer makes an adjustment and it can take quite a while to re-establish a stable angle. The picture quality is generally very good, but a combination of full zoom and compression due to squeezing the whole show on a single disc leads to quite a bit of grain. The cam audio is reasonably clear, but sounds fairly hollow. "The Final Show" is a mixed bag of some great rock-steady close-ups interleaved with near-unwatchable shaky spells. Copious use of the fast forward button to pick out the best bits makes this an enjoyable watch.

version.name: 1995 Molly Meldrum Interview
version.description: This astounding interview was conducted in Los Angeles by renowned Australian rock journalist Ian 'Molly' Meldrum as part of the promotional push for the "Greatest Hits" album in 1995. It is extraordinary on a number of levels, making it undoubtedly one of the most fascinating interviews of Bruce's career ever committed to film. Bruce and his management keep tight control of his contact with the media. Questions must be submitted beforehand and follow-ups are generally not allowed. However, Molly Meldrum had other ideas. He was granted just 15 minutes, but was determined to get a much longer interview that he could use for a worldwide syndicated TV special. He was impeccably polite, but refused to relent on his persistent line of questioning. The interview starts in conventional fashion, but Meldrum quickly throws in a question that isn't on the approved list. Bruce seems intrigue, but his minders (who are just off-camera) are less amused. The tension grows and Bruce starts to cast glances to someone else in the room. The questions are unique and insightful, drawing on the in-depth knowledge of someone who is obviously a dedicated fan. Examples include questions on an unreleased album recorded in 1986 and the verse about Bruce's father that was deleted from "Glory Days". Bruce seems to be caught off-guard at times, but he remains in good spirits throughout. It was admirable that Bruce let the interview continue, despite the fact that he was clearly being signalled to end it. This is probably because Meldrum was smart enough to avoid questions of a personal nature and the issue of bootlegs is cleverly circumvented when it comes up. After a gruelling 90 minutes, the interview is finally called to a halt. Springsteen's management (who are never seen on camera) were apparently furious at what unfolded and they refused to allow Meldrum to use more than the originally allocated 15 minutes, so the TV Special never came to fruition. However, we can now finally get to see the marathon session in its unedited entirety. The DVD is a simple presentation of what is probably a 2nd generation VHS copy. The entire running time consists of a single head-and-shoulders fixed angle shot. Picture quality is generally very good, but there are occasional flickers of interference and the colour has shifted towards red. The audio is perfectly adequate, but there is minor hiss and distortion throughout. If any interview could be described as essential, then "1995 Molly Meldrum Interview" is it. (Thanks go to "Earthslayer" for the background information used in this review)

version.name: Rome 05
version.description: Rome was the first "Devils & Dust" show in over a month not to have "My Beautiful Reward" as the opener. Instead, Bruce entered the stage to the haunting strains of Ennio Morricone's "Once Upon a Time in the West" theme and then dedicated the new spaghetti western arrangement of "I'm on Fire" to the home town composer. "Brilliant Disguise" and "Lucky Town" made their tour premieres and long-time fans were treated to piano versions of "Incident on 57th Street" and "Racing in the Street". The camcorder footage featured on this DVD was shot from a tripod high on the left side of the theatre. This gives a side view when Bruce is on guitar, but a head-on view when he takes a seat at the piano. It is extremely steady when the filmer holds a fixed angle, but the pans are very shaky. Picture quality is very good, but the view is a little more distant than the best videos of the tour and there is quite a bit of digital noise in the dark backgrounds. The camcorder audio is disappointingly hollow and heavily laden with echo. As a very nice bonus, the set also features a short special that aired on Italian TV. Interspersed among the promo clips and original interview (with overdubbed Italian translation) are some brief clips of pro-shot footage from the Bologna and Milan "Devils & Dust" shows. The pro-shot clips are a pleasant surprise, but the very good footage in the main feature is let down by the audio.

version.name: Once Upon a Time in Rome
version.description: Rome was the first "Devils & Dust" show in over a month not to have "My Beautiful Reward" as the opener. Instead, Bruce entered the stage to the haunting strains of Ennio Morricone's "Once Upon a Time in the West" theme and then dedicated the new spaghetti western arrangement of "I'm on Fire" to the home town composer. "Brilliant Disguise" and "Lucky Town" made their tour premieres and long-time fans were treated to piano versions of "Incident on 57th Street" and "Racing in the Street". "Once Upon a Time in Rome" from 'SleekBlack' uses the same video source that has previously circulated. It was shot from a tripod high on the left side of the theatre. This gives a side view when Bruce is on guitar, but a head-on view when he takes a seat at the piano. It is extremely steady when the filmer holds a fixed angle, but the pans are very shaky. Picture quality is good, but the view is a little more distant than the best videos of the tour and there is quite a bit of digital noise in the dark backgrounds. The original camcorder audio was very disappointing, so the dubbed source lifted from the 'Godfather Records' release used here is a big improvement. There are some problems with the synchronisation in places, but the distant view means that you have to look hard to notice them. "Racing in the Street" now continues with audio only at the point where the video cuts. The discs include song selection menus with a somewhat unimaginative layout. "Once Upon a Time in Rome" is a reasonable attempt to upgrade the original release, but the basic disc design and variable synch is a little disappointing.

version.name: Hamburg 05
version.description: The Hamburg "Devils & Dust" show turned out to be the penultimate night of the European tour after being rescheduled from earlier in the month. Bruce rewarded the home town crowd for their patience with tour premiers of "Janey, Don't Loose Heart" (on electric piano), "Spare Parts" and "Growin Up". Other rarities included "Highway 29" and "Highway Patrolman". The pump-organ "Downbound Train" stayed from its debut during the previous show as the opener. Only some of those performances are included on this single DVD of select songs from the show. Luckily, the supreme "Janey..." is among the songs captured when the filmer chose to turn on his camera. The tracks are mostly complete, but some are faded out a little early. The footage is shot from the left of the theatre, which gives a side view for the guitar numbers and a head-on view of Bruce at the piano. The picture quality is mercifully free of the digital noise that mars most of the videos from the tour, but there is some pixilation when the filmer uses maximum zoom. It is reasonably steady and carefully filmed, with a good colour balance. The audio is very good for a camcorder source. Unusually for camcorder video, the transfer is anamorphic widescreen. The disc has been authored with interesting menu designs and despite being incomplete, it is a very nice presentation of the show.

version.name: Hamburg, Don't You Lose You Heart
version.description: The Hamburg "Devils & Dust" show turned out to be the penultimate night of the European tour after being rescheduled from earlier in the month. Bruce rewarded the home town crowd for their patience with tour premiers of "Janey, Don't Loose Heart" (on electric piano), "Spare Parts" and "Growin' Up". Other rarities included "Highway 29" and "Highway Patrolman". The pump-organ "Downbound Train" stayed from its debut during the previous show as the opener. "Hamburg, Don't You Lose You Heart" from Digitox/DVD Dubbing Guy uses the same incomplete video that has previously circulated. The songs that are included are mostly complete, but some are faded out a little early. The footage is shot from the left of the theatre, which gives a side view for the guitar numbers and a head-on view of Bruce at the piano. The picture quality is mercifully free of the digital noise that mars most of the videos from the tour, but there is some pixilation when the filmer uses maximum zoom. It is reasonably steady and carefully filmed, with a good colour balance. The original camcorder audio has been dubbed with the excellent audience tape from 'SW'. The DVD has been skilfully authored in anamorphic widescreen with an attractive menu system. There are also a couple of very nice Bonus Features. A German TV news segment featuring some brief pro shot clips has been included, as well as the audio for the songs that were not filmed. Overall, a very good upgrade.

version.name: Frankfurt 05
version.description: Frankfurt saw "Into the Fire" stay as the show opener from the first German "Devils & Dust" show in Munich. The electric "Open All Night" returned to the set and "The Ghost of Tom Joad" got its first European outing of the tour. The other main highlight was a rare triple shot at the piano with "For You", "Two Faces" and "The River". Unfortunately, none of those performances make an appearance on this DVD. Instead, we get nine songs (all cut) from the last part of the main set and the encores. The filmer moves position between some of the songs, so we get to see Bruce from several different angles. All of the shots are from the same high level at the back of the theatre and are fairly unsteady. Obstructions from the audience and stage rigging are a constant problem. The picture quality is reasonable, but it lacks the crisp definition that we have seen on other videos from the tour. It is overexposed at times and there are some strange green/brown tints. Most annoyingly, there is a small white spot that dances around the centre of the frame for the first few songs. The spot looks like a firefly and you might find yourself wishing that Bruce would just turn around and swat the damn thing. The DVD is saved by the dubbed audio. The strong and full sound makes it worthwhile persevering with the full 45 minute run time. The disc is authored with a very simple main menu, but no song selection menu. This one falls firmly into the "nice souvenir for those that were there" category.

version.name: 'Till I Die... Ghent '93
version.description: When Bruce arrived at the Flanders Expo arena in Ghent for the first of his two "Human Touch/Lucky Town" shows, he found himself being filmed by a local TV news crew. A compilation of the resulting footage has now surfaced on "Till I Die... Ghent 93" from "JoJo". The footage is divided into three sections. The first (and most interesting) sees Bruce soundchecking "Lucky Town" and "I Ain't Got No Home" in the empty arena. This is followed by a backstage interview and finally clips from three consecutive songs from the show. All three sections run for around 10 minutes each. The stage video is a series of relatively short snippets rather than complete performances. The source appears to be a second or third generation VHS copy of the master. Picture quality is very good, with only a small amount of generation loss visible. There are some slight pauses and stutters throughout, but this doesn't detract too much from this extremely enjoyable video. The sound comes from a boom mike rather than the soundboard, but is nevertheless very clear. The animated menu gives access to some novel bonus material. This consists of the news broadcasts that made use of the same raw video and a slide show of local newspaper and magazine clippings. These clippings are also available on the disc as high res .pdf files. "Till I Die... Ghent 93" is an excellently produced DVD of some great pro shot footage. A "must have" for fans of the period.

version.name: Summer of '88

songlist: Rock & Roll Hall of Fame Report

version.description: "Summer of 88" from Stan Goldstein is a compilation of primarily TV news coverage during the period January to September 1988 (if only summer really was nine months long). The contents are as follow: - A segment from the ITV's (not BBC, as listed on the menu) "TV-am", covering the Wembley Stadium show on 25 June. It includes several live clips. - A segment from the UK Channel 4 (again not BBC, as listed on the menu) magazine show "Wired".  It features footage of Asbury Park and interviews with locals who have tenuous connections to Bruce. Clips from the Birmingham show on 21 June are also included. - The SOS Racism Rally in Paris on 18 June. - A Dutch TV news segment featuring clips from the Rotterdam show on 29 June. . - A segment from the Italian TV show "Notte Rock", featuring footage from the Turin show on 11 June. . - A complete "Be True" from the Mountain View show on 2 May. . - "Can't Help Fallin' in Love" from the Berlin broadcast on 19 July. . - The camcorder footage of Bruce busking on the streets of Copenhagen, 23 July. . - TV commercials for the "Video Anthology", "Tunnel of Love" and the radio broadcast of the Stockholm show. . - A BBC TV news report on the Amnesty Tour, including Bruce's appearance at a press conference on 1 September. . - Coverage of the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame ceremony on 20 January, including a lengthy clip of Bruce's speech inducting Bob Dylan. Picture quality ranges from excellent (Mountainview, SOS Racism) to poor (Dutch and Italian TV broadcasts). Much of the material will be familiar to veteran collectors and some of it has previously circulated in better quality (e.g. Turin, Berlin). There are some real gems here though, including the great quality Mountainview clip and the snippets from the UK shows. The chapter selection menus are strangely split in two halves and the captions are somewhat ambiguous (or as noted, wrong). Nevertheless, "Summer of 88" does a nice job of capturing a varied and exciting year in Bruce's career. It is interesting and enjoyable viewing.

version.name: Soundcheck
version.description: "Soundcheck" is a somewhat bizarre compilation of previously circulated clips from the late '70s and early '80s. It kicks off with the well-known closed-circuit soundcheck footage from Passaic '78. The black and white image is dark and grainy, making it quite hard to distinguish Bruce from the general murk. However, the rarity value and good sound makes it worth a viewing or two. Conversely, the clip from Bruce's guest spot with Southside Johnny on New Year's Eve 1979 is not worth even a few seconds of your time. This has been available for some time in excellent quality, but the version here is abysmal. Generation loss has rendered it unwatchable. The pro-shot footage shot from Buffalo '84 is much better (but that is not hard). It is a single camera view of "Cadillac Ranch", "Pink Cadillac" and "Born to Run" from the right side of the arena. Generation loss is again evident and there is a large counter across the screen, but it is still enjoyable stuff. Next is part of the "Old Grey Whistle Test" special from 1985, including a segment of the interview, a live clip of "Cover Me" and the "Dancing in the Dark" promo. Quality is similar to the other (complete) versions in circulation. The disc finishes with some random TV clips of other artists (Dylan on Letterman, an early Johnny Cash appearance and some unidentified children on an ancient '50s variety show). You also get 20 minutes of blank screen for good measure. There is no authoring, just a basic standalone transfer of a VHS tape. If you don't already have the Passaic soundcheck or Buffalo '84 footage, then this is as good a way as any to pick them up. Otherwise, give this one a miss.

version.name: Bridgeport 05
version.description: By the time the "Devils & Dust" Tour rolled into Bridgeport, a generous scattering of rare performances and tour premiers had almost become the norm. The packed arena was treated to the longest set yet, with a total of 27 songs. There were seven songs at the keyboard, including the first tour outings for "All That Heaven Will Allow" and "Nothing Man". Other highlights included "Highway 29", "Lost in the Flood" and "Spare Parts". Among the Connecticut crowd were fellow songwriters Jesse Malin (to whom Bruce dedicated "The Promise") and Suicide's Alan Vega (who wrote the standard show closer, "Dream Baby Dream"). There was also an amusing repetition of the infamous incident in New Jersey on the first leg of the tour when Bruce admonished the crowd for yelling and later apologised when he was told there was a PA fault. However, he couldn't resist adding "If it wasn't that, go fuck yourself". This LAM Video/Silver Stallion Production features a video shot from the right side of the arena. Picture quality is very good, although use of full zoom which gives some very nice close-up views does result in a fair amount of grain. Thankfully though, the dark backgrounds are free from the noise that mars many of the other videos from the tour. The filmer manages to hold a steady shot during most of the performance, but things get a bit shaky when Bruce moves stage position between songs. It takes a while to re-establish a stable view, but the worst of these transitions are replaced with stills montages while the sound continues uninterrupted. This is very effective at smoothing out the rough spots, but the predominance of early era images strikes as anachronistic. Some of the piano songs are filmed from the arena screen, with good quality results. The audio comes from a very clear audience recording. The dubbing is spot on most of the time, but a glitch just before the last track on Disc 1 throws out the synchronisation for all of "Racing in the Street". The authored menus use background video clips to good effect. The close-up views, mostly steady camera work and strong dubbed audio makes "Bridgeport 05" one of the better DVDs from the "Devils and Dust" tour. It is a good representation of the stand-out third leg and well worth adding to your collection.

version.name: Sit Back, Relax and Shut The Fuck Up !
version.summary: Compilation of clips from both nights
version.description: The colourfully titled "Sit Back, Relax and Shut The Fuck Up !" is a compilation of songs from the two Royal Albert Hall shows at the start of the European leg of the "Devils & Dust" tour. There are four songs from each night, both filmed with the same handheld camera from a very similar location on the right side of the theatre. The two nights appear on the disc in reverse order, but this puts the songs in the sequence that they appeared in the shows. The view is fairly unsteady and there are occasional obstructions. The image quality is a little soft and the camcorder audio is about average for the source. It is all held to gather with some very basic menus. Total running time is just 34 minutes, but this does include the memorable moment when Bruce found himself in the arms of attractive twin blondes during Ramrod. In lieu of either complete show emerging in trading circles, "Sit Back, Relax and Shut The Fuck Up !" offers those that were there a reasonable memento of the occasion. For others, it is unlikely to get many repeat plays after the initial viewing.

version.name: Rotterdam Ahoy
version.description: The Netherlands' only "Devils & Dust" show fell on Father's Day and so it was no surprise that Bruce opened with "Adam Raised a Cain" and later followed up with "My Father's House". A piano triple shot of "For You", "Two Faces" and "The River" was complimented later by another trip to the keyboards for "Countin' on a Miracle" leading into "Racing in the Street". A six number encore stretched the set out to a total of 26 songs. This single disc DVD uses a video shot from the left side of the arena. The camera appears to be on a tripod, but there is still quite a bit of movement and occasional obstructions. Picture quality is generally good, with quite a bit of detail visible and pleasingly solid dark tones. The sound is also good for a camcorder source. The big problem is that the camera is mounted at an angle until well into the main set and again at the end, giving the appearance that Bruce is standing on a slope. You might find yourself fearing that he could topple backwards at any time. "Rotterdam Ahoy" is a reasonably good example of a DVD from the tour, as long as you are prepared to watch two thirds of it with your head tilted to one side.

version.name: 'Neath The Arms Of Cassiopeia
version.description: Dusseldorf was the third of three consecutive German shows on the European leg of the "Devils & Dust" tour and Bruce obviously thought it was time for a serious set list shake up. There was a total of twelve changes from the previous night in Frankfurt, including tour premiers of "Highway 29" (for the first time since the "Ghost of Tom Joad" tour) and both "I Wish I Were Blind" and "Mary's Place" on piano. Also on piano were "Incident on 57th Street", "Tougher Than the Rest" and the always welcome "Racing in the Street". That only left room for seven songs from "Devils & Dust", with no "Leah" for the first time. "'Neath The Arms Of Cassiopeia" from "brucevideos" uses handheld camcorder footage shot from the left side of the theatre, giving a nice head-on view when Bruce is at the keyboards. It is reasonably steady for a handheld, but the camera is tilted slightly to one side at times. There are a couple of brief cuts for tape swaps and things get a lot shakier towards the end of the encores. The picture quality is very clean, but the definition is a little soft and the view a little distant. The dubbed audio comes from a good audience tape from 'Vortex'. The DVD comes complete with a basic song selection menu. "'Neath The Arms Of Cassiopeia" is certainly one of the better DVDs from the tour, but not quite up there with the very best.

version.name: Frankfurt - Dusseldorf 05

songlist: Land of Hope and Dreams (Frankfurt, 15 Jun 05)

version.description: Dusseldorf was the third of three consecutive German shows on the European leg of the "Devils & Dust" tour and Bruce obviously thought it was time for a serious set list shake up. There was a total of twelve changes from the previous night in Frankfurt, including tour premiers of "Highway 29" (for the first time since the "Ghost of Tom Joad" tour) and both "I Wish I Were Blind" and "Mary's Place" on piano. Also on piano were "Incident on 57th Street", "Tougher Than the Rest" and the always welcome "Racing in the Street". That only left room for seven songs from "Devils & Dust", with no "Leah" for the first time. The 'JoJo' version of the show uses a completely different video than the one found on "'Neath The Arms Of Cassiopeia" from 'brucevideos'. It is essentially a series of clips because the filmer turns the camera off after every song. Consequently, most of the between-song chat and opening lines are missing. Two performances ("Reno" and "The Hitter") are absent entirely. The video quality is very much a good news/bad news/good news story. The good news is that the image is beautifully clean with solid and natural tones. It is completely free of the low level digital noise that plagues most videos from the tour. However, the bad news is that the camerawork is extremely shaky. The constant camera movement, coupled with overenthusiastic use of the zoom, leads to frequent loss of autofocus lock and so the picture often degenerates into a blur. Now back to the good news. The filmer takes up a position standing on a seat just a few rows back from the stage at the start of the encores and gets some terrific close-up shots. The audio is reasonably good, considering it comes from the cam. Clips of three songs from Frankfurt are also included, but camera shake renders them virtually unwatchable. The single DVD is authored with simple menus, which it should be noted contain a couple of errors ("Tougher Than The Rest" is mislabelled as "Tunnel of Love" and "Further On Up The Road" is not listed, although it does appear on the disc). To be fair to the filmer, he probably shot the video for his personal enjoyment only and so we should be thankful that he agreed to share. However, unless you have a personal attachment to this particular show, you are unlikely to return to this DVD after the first play.

version.name: Gothenberg 05
version.description: The "Devils & Dust" show in Gothenberg featured an astounding set list, but only a few extracts (including the tour premier "Fade Away") are included here. However, what makes this DVD remarkable is the fact that the video was shot from the second row. As you might expect, the footage is a little unsteady and there are many obstructions. Nevertheless, there are some amazing close-up views. The camcorder audio is unfortunately distant sounding and laden with echo. This DVD contains some of the best amateur shots of the tour ('any' tour, for that matter) and is a tremendous testament to the balls of the filmer.

version.name: Boston 05
version.description: The professional film crew were back for the second night in Boston for what might eventually become the official release from the Devils & Dust tour. Bruce wildly mixed up the set so that only ten songs were repeated from the first show. The intensity level was upped too, with dramatic performances of "Cautious Man", "Real World" and "Open All Night". "Lost in the Flood" was included as a nod to the old-time fans and there was a bullet mic reading of "Johnny 99". However, the biggest surprise was the impromptu cover of "Dirty Water" between the previously inseparable "Promised Land" and "Dream Baby Dream". On a lighter note, Bruce expanded the "hidden love songs" rap to explain the real hidden question was "will you pull your pants down". The amateur camcorder footage featured on this DVD was shot from the left side at the back of the theatre. It is handheld and so there is some camera movement throughout, but the filmer does a good job of preventing things from ever getting shaky. The picture is a bit dark and murky, but still acceptably good. The audio is strong and clear, but sadly the sync with the video is lost during the encores. The menus are exceptionally good, using a clever old-style movie theme. This is an enjoyable DVD, but the sync problems at the end of the second disc need fixing to elevate this to one of the better sets from the tour.

version.name: Boston 05
version.description: The professional film crew were back for the second night in Boston for what might eventually become the official release from the Devils & Dust tour. Bruce wildly mixed up the set so that only ten songs were repeated from the first show. The intensity level was upped too, with dramatic performances of "Cautious Man", "Real World" and "Open All Night". "Lost in the Flood" was included as a nod to the old-time fans and there was a bullet mic reading of "Johnny 99". However, the biggest surprise was the impromptu cover of "Dirty Water" between the previously inseparable "Promised Land" and "Dream Baby Dream". On a lighter note, Bruce expanded the "hidden love songs" rap to explain the real hidden question was "will you pull your pants down". The amateur camcorder footage featured on this DVD was shot from the left side at the back of the theatre. It is handheld and so there is some camera movement throughout, but the filmer does a good job of preventing things from ever getting shaky. The picture is a bit dark and murky, but still acceptably good. The audio is strong and the sync problems on the original version have now thankfully been fixed. A new Bonus Feature has been added to distinguish this version from the first release with the sync error. It is previously unseen camcorder clip of "Lonesome Day" from the Foxboro show towards the end of "The Rising" tour. Picture and sound quality are both crisp, but it suffers badly from constant crowd obstructions. The menus are exceptionally good, using a clever old-style movie theme. Although the picture quality is not quite as sharp as the best from the European leg, Boston 05 is still among the most enjoyable DVD sets from the tour.

version.name: Hollywood 05

songlist: Drive All Night (w/ Clarence & Little Steven)

version.description: The penultimate stop on the "Devils and Dust" tour was a make-up show that had been postponed and relocated due to a hurricane the previous month. The Florida fans were rewarded for the wait when two E Street Band members made guest appearances. Steve Van Zandt and local resident Clarence Clemons first came out for "Drive All Night". Steve returned for "Two Hearts" and the trio reformed in the encore for "Thundercrack". The casino setting inspired the tour premier of "Roll of the Dice" and rarities "Fade Away" and "Meeting Across the River" also made welcome returns. "Santa Ana" was back too, dedicated to all the "obsessive-compulsives" among the somewhat rowdy audience. This Mad Raving Stark Film was shot with a handheld camcorder from the balcony high on the left side of the hall. It is predictably unsteady and the filmer struggles to get a clear view at times. However, when it is good, it is very very good indeed. There are some very nice close-up shots, with pleasingly clear picture quality. The sound is about as good as you would expect from a camcorder mike. "Hollywood 05" is an average video of a memorable show.

version.name: Incident in Hartford

bonus: People Get Ready (w/ U2, Philadelphia 17 Oct 05)
All I'm Thinkin' About (NBC Today Show)

version.description: Hartford saw yet another radical shake-up of the set list, opening with two numbers on electric piano ("Back in Your Arms" and "Wreck on the Highway") and breaking out the ukulele on "I Wanna Marry You". Other highlights included the totally reworked "The Ties that Bind" and the recently debuted "Idiot's Delight". "You Can Look (But You Better Not Touch)" made its "Devils and Dust" tour premier. Unfortunately, these performances are all missing on the incomplete "Incident in Hartford" from BlackLab Productions. What we do get to see includes the classics "Lost in the Flood" and "Incident...", as well the other tour premier ("Something in the Night"). The handheld camcorder video is shot from a central location just a few rows back from the stage. Understandably, it is very unsteady and there are constant obstructions. However, there are some great close-up views at times, particularly during piano numbers. The picture quality is bright and sharp and the audio has been dubbed from the good audience recording from JB (although the sync isn't quite perfect in a couple of places). There is also an interesting set of bonus material included. The U2 guest appearance is a little blurry and the audio is poor, but it is a priceless moment nonetheless. The CBS Early Show segment features a comprehensive look at the making of "Born To Run" (timed to coincide with the release of the 30th Anniversary box set) including new interviews with Bruce, Steve Van Zandt and Jon Landau. The NBC Today Show performances will already be familiar to most collectors. It is disappointing that so many of the best tracks from the show are missing, but the close-up views and Extras make "Incident in Hartford" one of the better DVDs from the tour.

version.name: Solo in Nassau

songlist: Darkness on the Edge of Town
My Best Was Never Good Enough

version.description: Bruce's first show in the Nassau Coliseum since 1992 was unusual for not featuring a "Devils and Dust" tour premier, but the slightly sparse crowd was still treated to a nicely varied set. The first nine songs came from eight different albums, including "Stolen Car" as the opener, followed by "Living Proof" on pump organ. Next up was "Idiot's Delight", meaning the new album's title track was relegated to the four spot. "Johnny 99" on bullet mic returned for the first time since early in the tour and the ukulele came out for "I Wanna Marry You". "Solo in Nassau" is a two cam mix sourced from videos shot from opposite sides of the arena with handheld cameras. Both angles are very similar in quality, with low definition and quite a bit of grain in the image. They are also both quite unsteady. That said, it is all still very watchable. The audio comes from one of the camcorders and is reasonable enough. The standalone transfer has strangely been spanned across three discs, even though the bitrate used would easily allow the whole show to fit onto two discs. "Solo in Nassau" is reasonably enjoyable, but look for the authored two disc version instead of this one.

version.name: A Circus Town is Born
version.description: Bruce's anecdotes during his "Devils & Dust" show in Charlotte clearly revealed a fondness for the city in what was a warm and relaxed performance. "Long Time Coming" was prefaced with reminiscences about his cousin Frank and he joked the inspiration for setting "All I'm Thinkin' About" in 'Caroline' was simply because it rhymed with 'wine'. Musical highlights included back-to-back "Tunnel of Love" rarities on the keyboards ("When You're Alone/Two Faces") and a strong return to the piano for the triple-shot of "Nothing Man", "Real World" and "Racing In The Street". "Highway Patrolman" was dedicated to a local anti - Death Penalty organisation and the encores kicked off with a pair of classic oldies ("Blinded By The Light" and a loose "Wild Billy's Circus Story"). 'A Circus Town Is Born' from 'Cheesesteak Productions' features a 'Pavids & Ducci Film'. The opening song is shot from a reasonably steady handheld at the back of the arena. The picture quality is bright and sharp, with only minor amounts of digital noise in the dark backgrounds. After a short cut (the first of a few brief between-song edits), "Reason to Believe" is seen from a terrific angle from the floor in front of the stage. The picture quality is soft and grainy, but this source offers some amazing close-ups. The rest of the show continues with a mix of these complimentary views up to "Matamoros Banks", when it returns to the first source only. The video is accurately dubbed with excellent audience recorded audio from 'JB'. The title sequence and menu designs use a "Circus Story" theme and Disc 2 features Bruce's duet with Patti on "Brilliant Disguise" from the final CAA show towards the end of the tour as a Bonus. The picture quality of the bonus clip is very sharp and the sound is good, but the view is a little distant. The remarkable close-ups, great sound and high production values make 'A Circus Town Is Born' one of the very best sets from the tour. Miss it at your peril.

version.name: N/A

songlist: Lost in the Flood (Screen & Stage Shot)
Intro Jesus Was an Only Son (Stage Shot & Cut)
Intro Jesus Was an Only Son (Stage Shot & Cut)
Does This Bus Stop at 82nd St (Stage/Screen Shot)
My Best Was Never Good Enough

version.description:
This was first show since the release of the Born to Run 30th Anniversary box.  Bruce must of known this as he dedicated "Backstreets" with a "happy anniversary," to Jon Landau.  Set list highlights besides "Backstreets" include the second tour performance of "The Wall," the first-ever "Does This Bus Stop" on ukulele, "Santa Ana" in the main set and "Thundercrack" in the encore.
 
The camcorder footage is shot from the 2nd level center stage straight back.  The camera is hand held so there is some movement at times.  Also, because of the filmers location and the lack of the people sitting around him to stay in their seats, the filmer is forced to switch to filming the screen for several songs (See track listing below for details).  This results in the image quality to become very grainy due to the type of screens used at the arena.  The video quailty of the stage shot is soft and a little grainy but overall is fine.
 
The DVDs have been created by direct transfer of the master tape using a standalone recorder. Hence, there are no authored menus, song chapters or dubbing. Although the audio comes from the camcorder, it is remarkably clear and strong with some echo on the vocal.

capture.caption: Does This Bus Stop at 82nd St?

version.name: N/A
version.description:
Another amazing night for Philly with two tour debuts.  "Born in the U.S.A" opened the first of two Spectrum shows on bullet mic, and "Drive All Night," which hadn't been heard in concert since the European leg of the River tour (6/7/81).  Other rarities included  "The Ties That Bind," "Fade Away",  "Be True." Plus, "Highway 29," "Atlantic City" on guitar, and "Open All Night" in the encore.
 This single cam version of the first night in Philly was shot on a tripod.  The filmer stays "head to knee" on all the guitar songs, the only downside being when Bruce moves his head gets cut off the screen from time to time(although this is being quite picky).  As for Piano songs, the filmer keeps him right in the middle of the screen for an excellent shot.  As stated in other reviews, the picture quality is a little "soft and grainy" compared to some of the other new shows out there.  This is especially apparent when the stage lighting is more illuminated, but being shot on a tripod more than makes up for it.  There is also very little zooming, with the exception of "The Promised Land" and "Dream Baby Dream", when the filmer pans out to get a great wide shot.  Only the first half of "Jesus Was An Only Son" is filmed due to a tape change.  The standalone menu is the same style for this show as for the next night (11-9).  The audio, even though not dubbed, is surprisingly solid.
 Overall this is a very strong show from the last leg of the D&D tour, had the filmer added menus/chapters and dubbed audio, it could have been better, but its still toward the top for the tour.

version.name: Tonight There's Fallen Angels
version.description: Bruce is infamous for pulling out something special for Philadelphia crowds and the first of two "Devils and Dust" shows at The Spectrum was no exception. The tour premier of "Born in the USA" on bullet mic was used as the opener, but the real surprise was the first outing of "Drive All Night" since the "River" tour nearly 25 years earlier. "Fade Away", "Be True" and the reworked "The Ties That Bind" complete the strong "River" era representation. "Open All Night" in the encores helped wrap up a wild night. "Tonight There's Fallen Angels" from 'Cheesesteak Productions' features a previously uncirculated video of the show filmed by 'Fig'. It is shot from a central location at the back of the arena to give a relatively head-on vantage point. The handheld camerawork inevitably suffers from some slight jitter and the view is a little distant, but the picture quality is otherwise very good indeed. Bruce remains centre frame throughout and the rich colour tones are pleasingly solid. The accurately dubbed audio from 'Nicky C' is amazingly clear for an audience recording. Both instrumentation and vocal are extremely detailed and it is hard to image that an audience tape could sound much better. Also worthy of special mention are the beautiful graphics featured in the opening title sequence and menus. 'GChord' has also contributed another masterpiece for the cover art. It all adds up to a production of outstanding quality. The video doesn't quite match the very best of the tour, but the excellent audio and superb design makes "Tonight There's Fallen Angels" another unmissable title from the House of 'Cheesesteak'.

version.name: Philadelphia '05 2nd Night

songlist: Jesus Was an Only Son (start only)
Jesus Was an Only Son (ending only)

version.description: Bruce has become renowned for producing something special for his Philadelphia audiences, but nobody could have predicted what he would pull out of the bag for the second of two shows during the final month of the "Devils and Dust" tour. "Santa Ana" was played live for the first time in '32 years' and while most of the crowd were trying to figure out what they had just heard, he followed with the equally unexpected "Thundercrack". The third tour premiere was "Used Cars" and "Independence Day" made only its second appearance. Rare visits from "Adam Raised a Cain", "Janey..." and "Cynthia" added to a total of 41 songs performed across the two night stand. The evening was wrapped up with a version of "Dream Baby Dream" that clocked in at a full 10 minutes. This single cam video was shot from a tripod on the left side of the arena. The perfectly steady shot is a pleasant change from the constantly bobbing view we normally get, but it is let down slightly by the soft and grainy picture quality. The average audio is typical for a camcorder source. This is a standalone recorder transfer, so there are no menus or song chapters. It should also be noted that most of "Jesus Was an Only Son (start only)" is lost from the transition between discs. The steady camerawork lifts this one above the crowd, but there is still plenty of room for improvement.

version.name: Philadephia '05 2nd Night
version.description: Bruce has become renowned for producing something special for his Philadelphia audiences, but nobody could have predicted what he would pull out of the bag for the second of two shows during the final month of the "Devils and Dust" tour. "Santa Ana" was played live for the first time in 32 years and while most of the crowd were trying to figure out what they had just heard, he followed with the equally unexpected "Thundercrack". The third tour premiere was "Used Cars" and "Independence Day" made only its second appearance. Rare visits from "Adam Raised a Cain", "Janey..." and "Cynthia" added to a total of 41 songs performed across the two night stand. The evening was wrapped up with a version of "Dream Baby Dream" that clocked in at a full 10 minutes. The 'Atlantic City Productions' version of the show is a mix of two reasonably steady handheld cameras on opposite sides of the arena. The right side source gives a view with very nice picture quality. The definition is sharp and there is virtually no low level digital noise. The left side camera is unfortunately much poorer, with a soft and grainy image. The audio comes from one of the cameras and is reasonable, but a little distant. Both discs come with a short title sequence, but no authored menus or chaptering. The bitrate is also inexplicably low, with over half the capacity of the two discs going unused. Anyone expecting a fully polished production will be disappointed with this effort. Nevertheless, two cam mixes are always welcome and this one still offers a nice alternative to the earlier version.

version.name: Rutherford 05 Night
version.description: The second of two nights at the Continental Airlines Arena in New Jersey during the final month of the "Devil & Dust" tour featured a stellar set list. Celebration of the "Born to Run" 30th anniversary continued with the first ever solo piano "Meeting Across the River" and the tour premier of the 1975 album's title track. Many of the rarities were performed as dedications, including "Two for the Road" to Sirius Radio's Scott Greenstein, "Used Cars" to Bruce's father, "Frankie" to a Dutch fan and his son, and "Drive All Night" to another fan named Maria. There was no need to dedicate "Brilliant Disguise" because Patti appeared in person to perform the song as a duet. The great set list was matched by a warm and relaxed performance, with no sign of the cold that had hampered Bruce the previous night. This no-frills standalone transfer of the show features a video shot from the back of the arena for a relatively head-on view.
