The filmer primarily concentrates on the stage, but switches to the screen for the keyboard numbers. The camerawork is generally very steady, but there is the odd moment when Bruce wanders out of frame. The picture quality is decidedly average, with quite a bit of low level digital noise in the dark background. The camcorder audio is a little muffled, but otherwise very listenable. The more attentive viewers will notice there is a slight problem with the audio/video sync throughout Disc 2. There is much to enjoy here, but the underwhelming quality of the picture and sound detracts from one of the better shows of the tour.

version.name: Madison, That's Where the Fun Is
version.description: Bruce returned to Madison a year after the Kerry Election Rally for his first actual concert in the city since "The River" tour nearly 25 years early. He marked the occasion with a flurry of early material, including "Incident...", "Lost in the Flood" and a triple bill of "Growin' Up", "Wild Billy's Circus Story", and "Blinded By the Light" in the encores. Rarely performed songs from later in his career included "Valentine's Day" and "Across the Border" for only the second time this tour (this time on pump organ). He was in a joking mood, making reference to the Minnesota Vikings "Love Boat" scandal that was in the news at the time. He also apologised for taking so long to play Madison again, promising to come back with the E Street Band. The mighty talents of SDonkey and Cheesesteak Productions have joined forces to present the show on "Madison, That's Where the Fun Is". The main feature consists of a two cam mix taken from videos shot by Fig and SDonkey from similar positions on each side of the arena. Both sources are handheld, so the constant camera movement is inevitable. However, it is more stable than most handheld footage and both filmers do a good job of maintaining a central and unobstructed view of Bruce (albeit a little distant). The real revelation though, is the image quality of the right-side source. It is pin-point sharp and the dark tones are completely free of the low level digital noise that plagues almost every other video from the tour. Yes, black is actually black! The left hand view is softer and grainier, but still compliments the dominant angle nicely. The accurately dubbed audio has been remastered by Rockaway Rob to bring out the optimum sound quality with tremendously clear results. The set also includes a photomontage title sequence showing the venue and a credit sequence which includes a tongue-in-cheek memorial to a comrade who is no longer with us. It is topped off with a steady, full-frame, high quality screen shot and of "Stolen Car" from the Cleveland show earlier in the year. The complimentary angles, excellent image quality of the primary source, great dubbed audio and overall excellent production values makes "Madison, That's Where the Fun Is" a contender for the best DVD set of the tour. If you are the kind of collector that is only interested in a couple of DVDs from each tour, then this one should definitely be on your list.

version.name: Behind the Blood Brothers

songlist: Spirit in the Night (Backstage Acoustic Rehearsal)

version.description: When Bruce and the E Street Band reunited in 1995 to go back in the recording studio and shoot a promo video for the "Greatest Hits" album, film maker Ernie Fritz was there to capture the event for posterity. Some of his film was seen in the 80 minute documentary "Blood Brothers", but raw footage of the "Murder Incorporated" promo shoot at Tramps in New York has finally escaped the clutches of the ubertraders and made its way into general circulation. It has been released on DVD "silvers" under the title "Behind the Blood Brothers". The two DVD set combines Fritz's candid backstage footage with outtakes from Jonathan Demme's promo shoot to provide complete coverage of the day at Tramps. We get to see the band's on-stage afternoon rehearsals, backstage acoustic rehearsals, makeup sessions, chats with fans inside and outside the club and even Clarence doing the Striptease in his dressing room! Several run-throughs of "Murder Incorporated" for the promo video are included, together with parts of the concert that followed. There are also scenes of the backstage self-congratulation after the show and an interview with Demme. Finally, there are some transitional shots of the Tramps sign and the view out of an aircraft window. The set contains some wonderful moments, ranging from the intimate backstage renditions of songs like "You Can Look...", Bruce talking to a fan about his guitar with great pride, through to the spirited show finale of "Little Latin Lupe Loop". However, it should be understood that this is a copy of the unedited raw film and has been assembled in an extremely rough fashion. It consists of a series of relatively short single camera clips, ranging from just a few seconds to a couple of minutes in length. Consequently, virtually all of the performances are incomplete. There are lots of technical problems throughout, including tape speedup, freeze frames, blank screens and audio drop-out. Thankfully though, these glitches are largely confined to the beginning or end of the various clips. The audio is also very uneven, with Bruce's vocal often back in the mix. Despite the problems, this is clearly a very low generation source and so the picture quality is extremely good. The DVDs have been created using a standalone recorder and so there is no authoring or indexing. Disc 1 of the version shown here has also been duplicated a second time on a standalone recorder, resulting in double menus, a loss of picture quality and a minor offset in the audio/video sync. Disc 2 has been padded out with the TV broadcast version of the April '95 Sony Studios show in excellent quality. "Behind the Blood Brothers" (a.k.a. "Tramps '95") offers a fascinating glimpse of a landmark event in Bruce's career. It forms an essential part of any self-respecting Springsteen DVD collection.

version.name: 2006 Grammys
version.description: This particular version of Bruce's performance of "Devils & Dust" at the 2006 Grammy Awards was circulating via Bit Torrent just hours after the show ended. It is an excellent quality capture of a 4:3 digital TV broadcast, but is as "bare bones" as you can possibly get. There is not even a menu, let alone Bruce's jam on "In the Midnight Hour" from later in the ceremony. It's very nice as far as it goes, but a 16:9 version with the second performance would have been even better.

version.name: ...and the Grammy goes to... Bruce Springsteen

songlist: In the Midnight Hour (w/ Sam Moore et al)

version.description: The 'JerseyBoy0303' version of the Bruce's appearance at the 2006 Grammy Awards contains both "Devils & Dust" and the All Star tribute to Wilson Picket. It is captured from what appears to be an analogue German TV broadcast, judging from the faint lines rolling interference throughout. It is nice enough for those that can't wait for a better quality transfer.

version.name: Barcelona
version.description: This ancient handheld camcorder video of Bruce and the Band on the European leg of "The River" tour has been in circulation in various high gen versions for many years. However, it can now be seen in much improved quality via this new DVD that uses a VHS tape dubbed directly from the master as its source. The video is shot from the right side of the arena, with stage equipment partially obstructing the view. There is also a strange smearing effect across the image. The audio is dull and distant. It is undoubtedly much better than all the versions that have gone before, but is still very poor by today's standards. The incomplete clips of 10 songs from the show have been transferred as two separate Titles, running for a total of 26 minutes. Whether you view this is a priceless treasure, an interesting curio or just plain unwatchable depends very much on how you feel about the rare opportunity to see Bruce arguably in his prime.

version.name: Atlanta '05
version.description: Five years earlier on the Reunion tour, Atlanta fans were lucky enough to enjoy two world premier performances, namely "Further On (Up the Road)" and "American Skin (41 Shots)". There weren't any new songs when the "Devils & Dust" tour rolled into town, but Atlanta was still blessed with (to quote Bruce) a "back-to-back, never-played-before double header". "Sad Eyes" saw the light of day for the first time since its appearance on "Tracks" in 1998 and then came the big one - the first ever live performance of "Valentine's Day" from "Tunnel of Love". It was an extra special moment because "Valentine's Day" was the only song from a regular studio album to have never been played to a paying audience. The other notable highlight was the rarely performed "Nothing Man", dedicated to "The Rising" producer and local resident Brendan O'Brien. The video of the first three songs on this simplistically authored DVD is disastrous. The filmer seems to have the camcorder on a low quality setting, resulting in poor resolution and a frame rate akin to a 1920's silent movie. The view from the right side of the stage is also very shaky. Fortunately, the filmer skips "Lonesome Day" in order to change both position and camera settings. Things are much better when the video resumes from a slightly more central angle, but definition and steadiness still leave a lot to be desired. The camera motions seems to decrease as the show progresses, so by the time we get to "Sad Eyes/Valentine's Day" it is actually pretty watchable. The camcorder audio is surprisingly good throughout. Most viewers will probably switch off after making it far as the premiers and fails to notice the end of the main set and the encores are missing entirely. The menu seems to be a template from a PC authoring package, but virtually no effort has been made to customise it. There are also no Chapter stops whatsoever, making it hard to jump ahead to the interesting bits. Atlanta '05 was a milestone show on the "Devils & Dust" tour and deserves a quality outing on DVD. Sadly, this is not it. Die-hards may still want to pick it up for the debut of "Valentine's Day".

version.name: Bremen '88 TV Report
version.description: The German TV news report contained on this DVD documents Bruce's appearance in Bremen on the European leg of the Tunnel of Love tour. It covers the band's arrival by plane, roadies setting up the stage and the gathering crowd. There is a short interview with Clarence Clemons, but his voice is covered by the German-language narration. The real items of interest are the incomplete clips of "Tunnel of Love" and "Boom Boom" from the show itself. The duration of the report is 16 minutes, but the on-stage footage only lasts around 3 minutes. The source appears to be a 3rd or 4th generation VHS recording of the broadcast, but the image is still reasonably clean. The disc also contains a well executed slide-show of professional-looking stills. Pro-shot footage is always a welcome addition to any collection, but you may want to wait for these clips to appear in a compilation rather than seeking out this dedicated disc. NB: The disc plays without sound on some standalone players due to compatibility issues with the audio format.

version.name: You'll Catch Zero and Terry in Trenton

songlist: It's Hard to Be a Saint in the City
Jesus Was an Only Son (intro cut)
Santa Claus is Comin' to Town

version.description: After a remarkable seven months, the "Devils & Dust" tour staged its finale in Bruce's home State of New Jersey. Donna Summer's "Last Dance" was the appropriate choice of P.A. music as the lights went down in Trenton. The show was surprisingly similar to the previous night, including the instrumental opener "Rumble" as a tribute to the recently deceased Link Wray. The new arrangements of "Saint in the City" and "Song for Orphans" also returned, but Bruce couldn't let the event pass without four tour premieres. The biggest surprise was the first outing for "Zero and Blind Terry" in over thirty years. "Fire" got the bullet mic treatment as another nod to Wray (who covered the song in '78) and Patti came out for a duet on "Mansion on the Hill". The fourth tour premiere was a family affair, with a total of 16 friends and relatives (including Bruce's 3 children) joining him on stage for a slightly early "Santa Claus is Coming to Town". All that was left was a series of thanks and name checks before "Dream, Baby, Dream" for one last time. "You'll Catch Zero and Terry in Trenton" from Black Lab Productions uses a handheld camcorder video shot from the back of the theatre. The filmer often zooms out between songs and the view gets very shaky until he homes in on his subject again. Once Bruce is centre-frame, things are much more stable. The view feels a little distant and there is the occasional partial obstruction from an audience member's head. Picture quality is very good, particularly during the more brightly lit portions of the show. An excellent audience tape from 'JB' is used for the audio source, but the sync is a little adrift at times. "You'll Catch Zero and Terry in Trenton" falls somewhere in the middle of the field of "Devils & Dust" shows in terms of technical quality, but it is essential as a representation of a landmark performance.

capture.caption: Santa Claus is Comin' to Town

version.name: Live on Good Morning America
version.description: Just like "The Rising" four years earlier, Bruce chose to launch his new album "We Shall Overcome; The Seeger Sessions" by performing live on ABC's "Good Morning America". Once again, Bruce was up at the crack of dawn to perform from the Convention Hall in Asbury Park on the release date itself, while a taped interview was screened the day before. The DVD opens with the interview, but then cuts to the next day with an interminable series of links included by virtue of the fact that the presenter is standing on the boardwalk surrounded by fans. Amongst the seemingly endless weather reports, there is a brief clip of "When the Saints Go Marching In". We then finally get to see "Jacob's Ladder" and "O Mary Don't You Weep" in full. The source for this transfer appears to be a VHS tape of an analogue broadcast and there are some faint lines of interference rolling diagonally across the screen throughout. Nevertheless, it is still of a more than acceptable quality. "Live on Good Morning America" will doubtless be superseded by a better quality version (16:9 HD source, anyone?) at a later date, but it was a welcome opportunity to catch the new band just hours after their TV debut.

version.name: ABC Good Morning America
version.description: Just like "The Rising" four years earlier, Bruce chose to launch his new album "We Shall Overcome; The Seeger Sessions" by performing live on ABC's "Good Morning America". Once again, Bruce was up at the crack of dawn to perform from the Convention Hall in Asbury Park on the release date itself, while a taped interview was screened the day before. This DVD from 'lamplight' only includes the two live performances (together with the brief clip of "When the Saints Go Marching In"), so you will have to look elsewhere for the interview. The source is a DVR recording of a 4:3 digital satellite broadcast. Picture quality is very good, but there are some noticeable compression artefacts. It's a nice enough version of the Seeger Sessions Band's TV debut, but there is still plenty of room for improvement.

version.name: New Orleans JazzFest

songlist: How Can a Poor Man Stand Such Times and Live

version.description: Rehearsal shows aside, Bruce's appearance at the New Orleans Jazz & Heritage Festival (a.k.a. JazzFest) was his first concert with The Seeger Sessions Band. The three songs here represent the performances that were webcast live by MSN. The .wmv webcast stream was captured in .avi format and re-encoded again for DVD. It is therefore unsurprising that resulting video suffers heavily from the multiple compressions. The frame rate is very low and the picture is blocky. The soundboard audio also leaves a lot to be desired. There are no menus or chapter stops. This is a crude attempt to create a DVD from the webcast, but it is still eminently watchable and will suffice until a more careful conversion emerges.

capture.caption: How Can a Poor Man Stand Such Times

version.name: New Orleans JazzFest Webcast

songlist: How Can a Poor Man Stand Such Times and Live

version.description:
The three songs here represent the performances that were webcast live by MSN (New source clips - no logos). Interesting footage of the band performing live for the first time.
For those that wanted a somewhat upgraded version of these excellent performances (Now with menus!).

capture.caption: How Can a Poor Man Stand Such Times

version.name: Bruce Springsteen: The Seeger Sessions
version.description: "Bruce Springsteen: The Seeger Sessions" is a slightly extended version of the documentary film that was included on the DVD side of "We Shall Overcome". The band can be seen recording tracks in Bruce's home studio and chatting about the origins and meaning of the music. It ran on US cable channel CMT during the month following the album's release. There is about 10 minutes of extra footage, notabley a now complete take of "Erie Canal" and a previously unseen "Jacob's Ladder". There is also some additional banter with the band and Bruce can be seen listening to a playback of "Froggie Went a Courtin". The source of the DVD appears to be a digital broadcast, so picture quality is very good. However, a relatively low bitrate has been used (leaving half the disc empty) and so there is still plenty of room for improvement. The disc has been authored with a nice main menu, but no song selection menu. Most collectors will want to track this one down, but the superior picture and sound on the official release will probably outweigh the extra footage found here when it comes to repeat viewings.

version.name: Amsterdam Nova TV Interview
version.description: Shortly after the Seeger Sessions Band appearance in Amsterdam on 16 May 2006, an exclusive interview with Bruce was made available on the website of Dutch TV channel Nova. The lengthy chat covers the musical and political landscape in which the new album is set. The discussion is interspersed with several clips from the show itself that appear to be taken directly from the arena video screen feed. We get to see parts of "John Henry", "O Mary Don't You Weep", "Pay Me My Money Down" and "We Shall Overcome". Unsurprisingly, the contrast is poor and the image is grainy. Still, this is much better quality than other Springsteen webcasts (Kerry Rally, Jazzfest) that have been converted to DVD in the past. It is well worth getting hold of a copy.

version.name: Bruce Springsteen with The Seeger Sessions Band (BBC TV Special)

songlist: How Can A Poor Man Stand Such Times and Live?

version.description: After just four dates on the Seeger Sessions tour, Bruce brought his largest ever band to one of the smallest venues he's ever played for a very special show for the BBC. The concert in St Luke's (a converted church and home of the London Symphony Orchestra) was later broadcast on both radio and TV. Bruce showcased seven tracks from the new album, plus the new "Poor Man.." centrepiece. It is beautifully filmed and a joyously exuberant performance. There were at least four different DVD transfers of the TV special circulating on the internet within hours of the screening. However, the davechapman version was unique among these because it was sourced direct from a DAB (Digital Video Broadcasting) signal. This made it possible to author the disc using the MPEG-2 video stream without any further compression or re-encoding. The result is sound and picture digitally identical to the original. The disc is presented in glorious 16:9 anamorphic widescreen. It has no menu at all, but there are chapter stops at the start of each song. More slickly packaged versions will inevitably follow, but this is as good as it can possibly get from a pure audiovisual perspective. The term "essential" can be over used, but this one is simply essential.

version.name: BBC 4 Sessions: Bruce Springsteen, St Lukes, London (HOJO)

songlist: How Can a Poor Man Stand Such Times and Live?

version.description:
The night after Bruce reawoke ghosts in Hammersmith, he played a special show for the BBC at St Lukes Church in London. To be broadcast a few days later on both the radio and television, the band played for around 90 minutes with a couple of songs repeated. The full unedited version has yet to appear but this DVD captures the 60 minute broadcast in perfect quality.  
With only 300 people in attendance, the setlist contains most of the standards from We Shall Overcome: the Seeger Sessions. The broadcast captures the mood perfectly and includes what might normally be considered outtakes, such as the false start to Jacob’s Ladder and Bruce’s disbelief before Mrs McGrath that they left the organ behind. And Blind Alfred Read’s one fan makes an appearance too!  
The DVD utilizes two sources to gain the best possible quality: the m2v video file from the DVB capture and PCM audio from HOJO’s own XP recording. Also included is the original MPEG-1 audio from the original DVB capture as well as a Dolby Digital 5.1 Surround Sound Mix. Definitive!

capture.caption: How Can A Poor Man Stand Such Times

version.name: Milano 2006

songlist: How Can a Poor Man Stand Such Times and Live?
You Can Look (But You Better Not Touch)
When the Saints Go Marching In

version.description:
Bruce's visits to Milan have built a reputation for exceptional shows and the Seeger Sessions Band appearance was no exception. Bruce had great fun with the crowd interaction. He even had to halt sing-alongs to be able to start the next song, but it was all in good spirits. There was some set list shuffling at the start of the show, moving "Jesse James" to the opener. However, the biggest surprise came when Bruce debuted the 'Texicali' arrangement of "Ramrod" in the encores. The show also continued beyond "Saints..." for the first time, with "Buffalo Gals" being used as the new closer. The video featured in this DVD was filmed by 'Bruga' from a tripod at the rear of the arena, giving a fairly distant view. Apart from some ragged pans, the picture is very steady. The image quality is amazingly clean and sharp, although slight overexposure means that Bruce's face is whited-out when he is in the spotlight. The camcorder audio is a little muffled, but more than good enough. The discs have been authored by 'Luke' with a simple song-selection menu (note, Dan Tucker and
Cadillac Ranch are transposed on the Disc 1 menu). Although "Milano 2006" was one of the first DVDs to emerge from the Seeger Session Tour, the steady camerawork and sharp image mean that it will stand up well against other releases.

version.name: Milano 2006 (FedeUD)

songlist: How Can a Poor Man Stand Such Times and Live?
You Can Look (But You Better Not Touch)
When the Saints Go Marching In

version.description:
Two things are guaranteed whenever Bruce hits the stage in Milan: an outstanding performance and a multi-cam DVD!  2006 was no exception with FedeUD producing a 6 camera-mix, perfectly dubbed with astounding sound from Crystal Cat, that should find a place in every collection. With cameras located around the arena, including the pit, and fleeting proshot clips from Italian TV also included in the mix, this DVD has a rare feel of “being there”. The camera work is very steady, mostly filmed from tripods, and the editing ensures there is rarely a bad shot. Overall, the production is very good, with menus and motion menus being used to good effect. However, it is worth noting that a mistake on Disc 1’s menu means Old Dan Tucker links to Cadillac Ranch and vice versa. Purists may also fail to appreciate the song titles appearing on the screen ahead of each song.
 
As for the performance, the setlist is fairly representative of the first European tour, although this is the first time that “Saints” did not close the show and Ramrod makes its tour debut. As ever in Italy, it’s the passionate audience that adds an extra dimension to the show with Bruce almost finding himself accompanying them!
 
This is a wonderful document of the first leg of the tour with the Seeger Sessions Band and will comfortably stand the test of time as one of the very best audience-shot DVDs of this, or any other, tour.

version.name: Amsterdam 06

songlist: How Can a Poor Man Stand Such Times and Live?
You Can Look (But You Better Not Touch)
When the Saints Go Marching In

version.description: Amsterdam was mid-way through the first leg of the Seeger Sessions Tour and Bruce stuck to the tried and trusted set list. The only variation was just the second outing for "Long Black Veil". This incomplete video of the show was filmed by 'Willem' with a handheld camcorder from a central location in the hall. The majority of the footage features the stage, but there are several switches to the screen. It starts out very shakily, but becomes steadier after the first couple of songs. The picture is very clean and reasonably sharp, but there is some slight pixilation and temporary loss of focus when the filmer uses full zoom. It is presented in 16:9 anamorphic widescreen, which does great justice to the large band. The camcorder audio is a little thin and distant. The disc has been authored by 'It's Boss Time' with an odd opening sequence, but no menu. There are also no chapter stops whatsoever, so you will have difficulty if you want to skip straight to "Long Black Veil". The widescreen view is nice, but the lack of proper authoring will prevent this from getting many repeat trips back to your DVD player.

version.name: AOL Sessions: Volumes 1 and 2

songlist: How Can a Poor Man Stand Such Times and Live?
Bring Em Home (If You Love Your Uncle Sam)
When the Saints Go Marching In
Bring Em Home (Late Night With Conan O'Brien)
bonus: How Can a Poor Man (The Tonight Show)
Pay Me My Money Down (Late Night With Conan O'Brie
Pay Me My Money Down Video

version.description:
During the North American leg of the Seeger Sessions Tour, Bruce embraced technology and provided a video stream on AOL after 18 of the shows. AOL Sessions uses these videos, downloaded at 700K and converted to NTSC (MPEG-2 720x480 29,97fps VBR 8000kbps, Linear PCM 48000Hz 1536kbps), with excellent results. 
While the performances, video and audio are all top notch, the production doesn’t quite meet the same standards. Volume 1 is split into separate titles and makes it impossible to move between tracks without returning to the menu. This problem isn’t apparent on Volume 2 but the Conan O’Brien footage hasn’t been chaptered so, again, it is not possible to move easily between tracks.  
The bonus footage on Volume 2 differentiates the collection from other similar AOL collections but probably isn’t enough to override the production errors and make this the set to seek out.

capture.caption: Pay Me My Money Down Video

version.name: Pay Me Or Go To Milwaukee

songlist: How Can a Poor Man Stand Such Times and Live?
You Can Look (But You Better Not Touch)
When the Saints Go Marching In

version.description:
With Patti not in attendance, the Seeger Sessions Band were one red-headed woman down but the performance didn’t suffer. An appropriately “loose” show for Milwaukee saw Bruce’s guitar fail during Jesse James and a polka version of Ramrod during the encore. Only the second Further On (Up the Road) with the Seeger Sessions Band featured the tremendous voices of all the vocalists too. And no show in Milwaukee would be complete without a drive through the Wisconsin night in the funky arrangement of Cadillac Ranch! 
The DVD production is tremendously slick, with a nice introduction and a slideshow filling in a gap during Old Dan Tucker. The video is nicely shot from a single camera high above the stage on the left hand side of the arena. On occasion, some of the camera work is a little unsteady and the zoom is used a little too enthusiastically but these are minor quibbles and inevitable whenever a single camera is trying to capture so much action on stage. For reference, and kudos, the show was filmed by JTT; the audio mixed and remastered by NEO; it was digitally mastered and authored by Fig; artwork was designed by GChord; Executive Producer credits go to Joan Fontaine; and SDonkey obtained the master tapes. An all-star cast! 
This is definitely a worthy addition to any collection but shouldn’t be considered a must-have.

version.name: Devils And Dust: Rarities Collection

songlist: It's Hard To Be A Saint In The City(Trenton 22/11)
Santa Claus Is Coming To Town  (Trenton, 22/11)

version.description:
Love it or loathe it, the Devils and Dust tour was interesting, to say the least. On more than one occassion, Bruce surprised the audience with stand out performances of songs that many figured were either forgotten, or that the man himself would never play live. Once the tour was over, a look back provided an education how Bruce supplied a healthy dose of "nuggets" for the long time fans. 

The Devils And Dust: Rarities Collection, which spans 4 discs (including the later added "Europe" disc), is a comprehensive document to these nuggets. A very ambitious project technically, as well as artistically, and Brucevideos pulls it off in style. Much like the famed "Flynn Audio Compilations" that are much sought after at the end of any tour, Brucevideos has started (?) a video representation that could well be regarded as highly as Flynn's one day - we will have to wait and see.

From the opening performance on disc one with "Rumble", to the closing of the set with "Maria's Bed", the collection offers a variety of rarely performed songs from the Devils and Dust Tour. All songs have been beautifully mixed one in to the other, so as to give the sense that the entire collection is like "one big long concert". However, each song stands on its own when viewed at random as well. The video sources, while being from a wide variety of already circulating material (none of it proshot), in most cases has not been altered from the original - and unfortunately this collection suffers slightly due to this.  The mood gets broken every so often when the viewer watches one clip in stellar quality, only to have the next one be in a lesser quality. A very minor thing, but noticable.

The audio is what really shines through. The mix of the audio is such that each clip is almost seemlesly intigrated with the next, as if that were the way they were originally produced. The sound is even throughout, and it is evident that a great deal of care went into the audio dub of this collection. No easy task considering the vast variety of source material.

Devils And Dust: Rarities Collection, is a "must have". With all the standout performances, and "live debuts" contained, it would be hard to pass this one by. With the added high production values of Brucevideos, it is even more of one that belongs in every fan's collection.

[Edit: The "Europe" disc is in the PAL format]

version.name: Bologna 2006 (FedeUD)

songlist: How Can a Poor Man Stand Such Times and Live?
You Can Look (But You Better Not Touch)
When the Saints Go Marching In

version.description:
After a 3 month break, Bologna witnessed the first night of the second European tour of 2006. With “The River” and “This Little Light of Mine” appearing in the set for the first time, this hinted at things to come over the next two months; tour debuts almost became the norm, with Bruce reaching into his back catalogue and reinvigorating some old classics in new musical arrangements.  
FedeUD has added to his reputation for producing multi-cam DVDs with this 5 cam effort. The remixed audio is good and the motion menus are nicely done. However, unlike the earlier outstanding 6 cam mix of the show in Milan during May, this production is marred by some shaky camera work, particularly the screenshots, and some bizarre editing choices. A tremendous amount of work has clearly gone into this: the video switches between cameras every few seconds but this means perfectly clear and steady shots are too often sacrificed for obstructed or shaky shots. FedeUD has perhaps been too keen to utilize all the cameras when a better experience might have been obtained by placing more emphasis on longer edits from a couple of the cameras. 
There is no doubting the effort put into this and, all in all, this is a good production However, it could have been even better- less would definitely have been more!

version.name: Shea Stadium: The Soundchecks

songlist: Back In Your Arms Again (4 October 2003)

version.description:
As the Rising Tour drew to a close in New York, this 30 minute DVD captures Bruce and the E-Street Band working hard before the shows to rehearse songs, some that would become tour debuts. Bruce is in playful mood, dancing with Patti during “Man’s Job”, and if you thought that speech before “Back In Your Arms Again” during the final show of the tour was improvised… you’d be wrong! Reports suggest "New York City Serenade" and "If I should Fall Behind" formed part of the soundcheck on the first night, and that "I Wish I were Blind" was played during the final soundcheck: if true, none of these have been captured here. 
The DVD looks to be shot from halfway back: to the left of the stage on 1 October and the right of the stage on 4 October. Mostly stageshot, with the odd screenshot, it is mostly centred on Bruce but captures other band members as he moves around the stage. The audio is also very clear and the production is good, although the menus make a couple of errors: they make reference to 2004 and the second"Johnny 99" is taken from the final night rather than the penultimate night. 
Another release in TattooDad’s quest for uber material, this DVD is very welcome and a good insight into the preparation that goes into shows. Practice, practice, practice!

version.name: N/A

songlist: Darkness on the Edge of Town

version.description:
This DVD starts out with the audio only from Red Headed Woman. The filmer then takes quite awhile to get a steady shot (somewhere around Trapped). Get ready for plenty of shots of the speaker system. Aside from the struggles early to get a clean shot, it also suffers from many generational loss issues included unbalanced colors, blurred image and tracking problems. 
Even the solid audio is betrayed by the higher generation copy with a high level of tape hiss. There isn’t much in the way of cuts except for Cover Me, which isn’t complete on either disc. There’s no real reason to hunt this one down until someone does a better transfer with a lower generation tape.

version.name: Breathless In Paris

songlist: Twist And Shout - Do You Love Me

version.description:
Taken from the release notes:
The complete professionally shot concert. This can arguably be considered the biggest and most important Springsteen bootleg release for over 25 years. Fortunately this DVD set is worthy of that accolade. I'm sure every Bruce fan will join me in thanking Tattoodad for initiating the Uber series that has delivered more gems than we could have hoped for in only a few months. We must also thank the source for his generosity, and Digi-TOx for his efforts in authoring this masterpiece.

Truly, this represents "MUST HAVE" more than any other Bruce release to date. Its that good! If you dont have it yet, go get it!

capture.caption: Twist n Shout-Do You Love Me

version.name: Born In The USA Clips

songlist: Darkness on the Edge of Town-Oct. 2, 1985
Born to Run- LA Coliseum- Sept. 30, 1985

version.description:
Released as part of the "Uber Series", the Born In The USA Pro Shot Clips DVD is a collection of various footage from Bruce's most popular career period. The footage collected here is in great quality, although many of the songs are either cut, or marred with timecode stamps (or that annoying 'blue diamond'). The audio is line fed and is excellent. The dates and locations are the best guesses possible. 


The interesting thing about this release, is how it was released. With no menus to speak of, and little fanfare, the DVD was made available by Brucevideos (but does not contain the trademark quality of their past releases). 'Half-Assed' would be the term to use here. But still, a very nice addition for those that want to recall Bruce at the height of his popularity as a cultural icon.

capture.caption: Darkness on the Edge of Town

version.name: The Concert For The Rock N Roll Hall Of Fame

songlist: Whole Lotta Shakin' (With Jerry Lee Lewis)
Darkness On The Edge Of Town

version.description: From the broadcast HBO special. Bruce's appearances only (plus guests). Quality is pretty good considering its from VHS over 10 years old. Incomplete - as it is missing a couple of performances by Bruce that were broadcast. Overall, a nice disc that "screams" for it to be played LOUD.

dvdLocation.venue: Just A Prisoner Of Rock N Roll - 70s Collection

version.name: Just A Prisoner Of Rock N Roll - 70s Collection

songlist: It's Hard To Be A Saint In The City
I Don't Want To Go Home

version.description: An excellent compilation of various sourced proshot video of Bruce early in his career. The entire set was obviously crafted with care by HOJO Productions as the video presented is excellent (considering the age of most of this footage). The entire 2 disc set is presented as a dedicated effort to the memory of much missed former SPL member, "july14th,1985", who had passed away. A fitting tribute. There are some minor flaws however, here and there, but considering the historical significance of this footage, not a major concern. Fans of the 70s era will no doubt want to seek this one out. Fans new to Bruce should also seek it out as it serves as a great document on what made Bruce one of the greatest live performers ever.

version.name: Sun City (Home Video Version)
version.description:
The 1985 "Sun City" Video and subsquent "Making of Sun City" Documentary that cronicled the Anti-Aparthid Anthem written by Little Steven. With such artists as Bruce Springsteen, Bono, Bob Dylan, Hall & Oats, plus many, many others who joined to record this surprisingly successful movement. This version contains the entire music video that was used to promote the song's release, as well as the complete version of the documentary (a shorter "edited" version appeared on MTV). 

Also on the disc is a nice pro-shot version of "Sun City" sung live by Little Steven and Bruce Springsteen, from the Ritz, NY, 1987-October-08. This did not appear on the Home Video but was added as a little bonus for this DVD (With thanks to Brucevideos).

dvdLocation.venue: Musicares Person of the Year 2006 Tribute

version.name: Millworker
version.description: A moving and powerful solo acoustic performance, honoring James Taylor, at the Musicares Person of the Year 2006 Tribute. This single song DVD, while short on quantity, makes up for it with quality. An outstanding source was used (most likely a direct digital capture), and it is apparent with the visual and auditory display. Fantastic!

version.name: Light of Day 7 - Never Be Enough Time

songlist: Never Be Enough Time - with Joe Grushecky

version.description: Not a lot information came with the release of this little gem, but the song is from the Light of Day 7 to benefit Parkinson's Disease. Bruce joins Joe Grushecky and The Houserockers for a very powerful performance of "Never Be Enough Time". Although it is a single song DVD release (which I suspect there is a full version of this show out there), the performance and steady camera work make this a very enjoyable number. As a little added 'bonus', there are a series of photos presented of Bruce at various Light Of Day shows past.

version.name: Santa Comes to Red Bank

songlist: Baby I Like You-Mark Pender and La Bamba
I Want you-Mark Pender and La Bamba
I'll be Home for Christmas-Mark Pender and La Bamb
Pretty Little Angel Eyes-Gary US Bonds
We Wish you A Merry Christmas-Gary US Bonds
Who Says You Can't Go Home-Jon Bon Jovi
Waiting on a Sunny Day-Bruce Springsteen
10th Ave. Freezeout (Bruce with Jon Bon Jovi)
Santa Claus is Coming to Town (with all)

version.description: A fine release from "Blacklab Productions". The 'All-Star Holiday Show' was an energic and entertaining performance by all involved in support of the "PALS" organization. Evidence of this, of coarse, is what this DVD shines with. While the frequent obstruction of people's heads and whatnot, get in the way of a good view, as well as the camera shake that follows, it somehow adds to the feeling that you are at the show. Even though the video does suffer from this quite a bit, the audio used for dubbing makes up for most it. All together, a very enjoyable DVD to experience. Another fine hand-held release.

capture.caption: Santa Claus is Coming to Town

version.name: Yet Another AOL Videos Compilation

songlist: How Can a Poor Man Stand Such Times and Live?
Bring Em Home (If You Love Your Uncle Sam)
When the Saints Go Marching In

version.description: Yet another review of an AOL compilation... A nicely put together set of Bruce's entire AOL webcast videos. The clips have been seemlessly linked, and produce a nice 'flow' to whole set. The menu is a nice motion type, with audio. Where this set suffers, however, is in the encoding of the video and audio. Right from the start of the first video, it is apparent that 'heavy filtering' was used in the process. The video look murky and the audio sounds muddy. According to the release notes, additional compression was used for the audio (AC3) and, unfortunatly you can hear the difference. Its too bad, as overall, the compilation was nicely put together.

capture.caption: How Can a Poor Man Stand Such Times

dvdLocation.venue: 18 Nights of Bruce Springsteen: The Story So Far...

version.name: 18 Nights of Bruce Springsteen: The Story So Far...

songlist: How Can A Poor Man Stand Such Times And...
Bring Them Home (If You Love Your Uncle Sam)
bonus: How Can A Poor Man Stand Such... (Jay Leno Show)

version.description: The first, of what turned out to be many, compilation of Bruce's webcasts on AOL, "The Story So Far..." was released as 'teaser' of sorts when it came out. With only seven of the broadcast videos represented (plus a bonus video of Bruce on Jay Leno), brucevideos was so excited by the event that they released it anyway. An excellent compilation quality-wise, as the video and audio are stellar considering the source material. And the menu, using the AOL announcement page, was a nice touch. Still, it is incomplete, and that is really a shame. Brucevideos indicated that a 'follow up' version, or complete version would follow, but it never was to be. With a release like this, the probable outcome would have most likely been one of the best collections. However, there are lots to choose from now. This DVD is a nice momento, but not a must have or anything. You can do better obtaining one of the complete sets out there instead.

version.name: Italian Land

songlist: O Mary Don't You Weep (Verona, 5 Oct 2006)
If I Should Fall Behind (Udine, 4 Oct 2006)
This Little Light Of Mine (Udine, 4 Oct 2006)
Further On Up The Road (Perugia, 7 Oct 2006)
How Can A Poor Man... (Perugia, 7 Oct 2006)
Pay Me My Money Down (Caserta, 8 Oct 2006)

version.description:
When Bruce and the Seeger Sessions Band returned to Europe in October 2006, the third leg of the tour kicked off with a 7 night stand in Italy. 7 nights to folk! And swing! This DVD compilation captures portions of each night and shows a band in typically boisterous form, if not quite hitting the heights seen a month or so later. 

This 3 DVD set, which runs for approximately 228 minutes, has a number of pleasing technical features: its been digitally mastered; has PCM stereo; has interactive menus; and is available in 16:9 widescreen. The audio is mostly very good, particularly on the first two DVDs. All shows are captured from steady single cameras and, despite some being positioned on the floor of the arena, all produce largely unobstructed shots of the stage. Occasionally, the camera pans away to capture the audience and this produces a good sense of the infamous Italian atmosphere. 

The fact that this is a compilation of several nights and as a set it doesn't quite flow (admittedly this is a criticism that some official releases- Live in New York City and Live in Dublin- have also suffered!) and some songs are unecessarily repeated. But these are minor criticisms- this is certainly an excellent production and a good reference for anyone who didn't catch the final stretch in Europe .
